lines.text:
Ye- e- e- e- eah, baby!

That meat carves so smoothly. You can see the 
blood shimmer~

lines.speaker: Otis
lines.text: Now this...

lines.speaker: Otis
lines.text: Now this is a meal!

The steam of the freshly carved meat wafted into 
the nostrils of a drooling Otis.

A knife stabbed into the ground, freshly bloodied 
by the act.

lines.speaker: Otis
lines.text: Ah~

Otis fell limp to the ground with meat and bottle in 
hand.

lines.speaker: Otis
lines.text:
Meatier morsel than has ever met my mouth? Meet 
my beer and the sun!

What great company. Alas, such company calls for 
the perfect lunch.
He took a swig of the beer.

lines.speaker: Otis
lines.text: Ah...

lines.speaker: Otis
lines.text:
...

Perfect, eh? Maybe not quite? Somethin's a 
missing, I'd say.

lines.speaker: Otis
lines.text: What have we here?

lines.speaker: Otis
lines.text:
You wouldn't happen to be on death's door, are 
you?

A face appeared in Otis's skyward eyeline. Cainan 
looked down on the limp body below.

lines.speaker: Otis
lines.text: Eh? You're blocking the sun.

lines.speaker: Cainan
lines.text:
Then you are not in need of medical attention?

You have gone limp in the middle of a field. It is a 
natural inquiry, no?

lines.speaker: Otis
lines.text:
Can’t a laddie-or-lassie eat a meal in the dirt without 
someone ass-uming they are lyin’ six lengths under 
it?

lines.speaker: Cainan
lines.text: Then you are in good spirits. That is good news.

lines.speaker: Cainan
lines.text:
Might I recommend eating arrangements less... dirt
orientated?

lines.speaker: Otis
lines.text: Heh, a little dirt never hurt no one.

lines.speaker: Cainan
lines.text: If you say so.

lines.speaker: Otis
lines.text:
Snarky little bastard, aren't you?

Really, what at this point could possibly do ol' Otis 
in?

lines.speaker: Otis
lines.text:
Not even the damned demonic moon's curse could 
kill me!

lines.speaker: Cainan
lines.text:
I imagine some individuals here doing well at such a 
task.

lines.speaker: Otis
lines.text:
Hah! I've heard of stranger tides, yeah.

Would not even mind a cocky son-of-a-bitch coming 
over here and giving me a tussle!

Their blood could make a half decent condiment for 
my meal.

lines.speaker: Cainan
lines.text: You paint... quite a picture.

lines.speaker: Otis
lines.text:
Hmm...

Matter-of-the-fact... stay right there and don't 
move a muscle.

Otis raised his hands and made them into "L"s that 
formed a "frame" around Cainan.

lines.speaker: Otis
lines.text: Them's the look.

He took another drink as he shifted to a sitting 
position.

lines.speaker: Otis
lines.text:
You'll do. Come on and sit with me.

Have some meat and be merry for once in your life.

lines.speaker: Cainan
lines.text: I appreciate the offer, but why?

lines.speaker: Otis
lines.text:
A perfect meal isn’t perfect without the wrong 
company to enjoy it with!

lines.speaker: Cainan
lines.text: "Wrong... company"...? Not the "right" company?

lines.speaker: Otis
lines.text:
Nothing is “right” when you're with bastards and 
scalawags, like you and I!

No need to deny it.

lines.speaker: Cainan
lines.text:
I do suppose we'd make an odd pair. A bit of an 
"odd couple" paradigm, at that?

lines.speaker: Otis
lines.text:
Ha! With that murderous look in your eyes?

Nothing makes a meal more spicy and delectable 
than the threat of death looming over it.

lines.speaker: Cainan
lines.text:
...Is that so? I can't say I appreciate said 
sentiment.

lines.speaker: Cainan
lines.text:
"Murderous" seems more apropos to you, though? I 
am a man of faith, after all.

lines.speaker: Otis
lines.text: Oh-ho-ho~ We got a choir boy, then?

The bottle of beer jolted upward again as more 
alcohol flowed into Otis.

lines.speaker: Otis
lines.text:
Am I wrong, though? It isn’t like we are ‘lightly 
tickling’ the bastards that get in our way.

lines.speaker: Cainan
lines.text:
Those I pass I judgment on are those that broke 
their oath to the Goddess.

I do not take such a responsibility lightly.

From my days in the crusades to my responsibilities 
as an auditor, I will not regret my service of the
Goddess.

lines.speaker: Otis
lines.text: The crusades?

lines.speaker: Otis
lines.text:
Oh, did you get one of those fancy smancy titles? 
What was it?

lines.speaker: Cainan
lines.text: *Sigh*...

lines.speaker: Cainan
lines.text: Some call me the "Azure Rook", yes.

lines.speaker: Otis
lines.text: And why's that? What'd you do?

lines.speaker: Cainan
lines.text:
I gained a reputation for strategy and tactics. My 
tales were one of wit, valor, and intellect.

lines.speaker: Otis
lines.text:
So you were REALLY good at figuring out how to 
kill people?

lines.speaker: Otis
lines.text:
No need to be so moody. If anything I'm in awe of 
it.

lines.speaker: Cainan
lines.text:
Am I not allowed to disagree with your... 
assessment?
A knife stabbed into a slab of meat.

lines.speaker: Otis
lines.text:
Eh, call it an instinct.

Come on, killer. Sit down and be merry.
Otis stuck out the stabbed meat towards Cainan.

lines.speaker: Cainan
lines.text:
I'll bite.

Both your food and your "bait".

Cainan reached past the outstretched meat to grab 
the clean slab of meat still in Otis's other hand.

lines.speaker: Otis
lines.text: Eh?

lines.speaker: Cainan
lines.text: What's wrong? Dirt never hurt anyone, no?

lines.speaker: Otis
lines.text: Yeah, yeah.

Cainan sat down onto the ground and retrieved a 
clean cloth from his pack.

He placed it on the ground and prepared it to use 
as a placemat for the meat.

lines.speaker: Cainan
lines.text:
What brings a person to be such a... 'scaredy-cat' 
around a Covenant faithful?

lines.speaker: Otis
lines.text: Hmm... I guess it'd be...
Otis pointed the tip of the knife towards his eyes.

lines.speaker: Cainan
lines.text: The eyes? My eyes?

lines.speaker: Otis
lines.text:
It ain't that complicated. I've seen the bullshit 
plenty.

As Otis the merchant and Otis de pirate, people 
were never that complicated.

lines.speaker: Otis
lines.text:
Intuition's a skill. If it means you ain't the one 
holdin' the satchel in a raw deal, then ya good.

lines.speaker: Cainan
lines.text:
A healthy skepticism for your “fellow man” is not an 
ill thing to have.

lines.speaker: Otis
lines.text:
What I'm saying is that it's the little things.

Maybe it's an unhealthy gait, ‘dem being weighed 
down by their weapon hidden behind their back.

Maybe it is what they are wearing, a clean pair of 
boots that shows they are richer than they are 
tellin’ ya.

lines.speaker: Otis
lines.text:
Or, my favorite, the eyes they walk in and share 
with ya.

lines.speaker: Cainan
lines.text: I get the first two, but...the eyes?

lines.speaker: Otis
lines.text:
The eyes are the window to the soul, mister 
“man-o’-faith”!

They tell a life story in all your pretty, citrus-colored 
glory, killer!

lines.speaker: Cainan
lines.text: Hmm...

lines.speaker: Otis
lines.text:
For most people, they shine like uncut gems, rich 
for the taking!

For the folks around us, these mercenaries, they 
are dulled with apathy. They've got their fill.

lines.speaker: Otis
lines.text:
Most got a flicker of starlight in their eyes, like you 
and I.

lines.speaker: Cainan
lines.text: Are you suggesting I am a damned soul?

lines.speaker: Otis
lines.text: Ain't we all?

lines.speaker: Otis
lines.text:
Those sitting up in the night sky are just 'dem that 
aren't scrapping at salvation down here, yeah?

lines.speaker: Otis
lines.text:
It ain't that hard to see the flicker of that 
damnation in the eye.

You've seen the Little Blue Hound and Miss High 
Horse?

lines.speaker: Cainan
lines.text: You mean... the young Anton and Lady Charlotte?

lines.speaker: Otis
lines.text:
They got that hunger. That somethin' missin'.

It's like when they stare down ya, their souls flicker 
out tryin' to grasp at anything and everything to
fill what's missin'.

lines.speaker: Otis
lines.text: It's a bit different for bastards like you and I.

lines.speaker: Otis
lines.text:
We don't hunger. We crave.

Flesh, food, gold, and glory... There ain't no 
satiatin' it.

There's always more. There's the endless abyss 
from top to bottom.
Otis drank another swig of beer.

lines.speaker: Otis
lines.text:
When I look in the mirror, I see starlight alright. It's 
deep. All the way down.

lines.speaker: Otis
lines.text: Same when I turn your way, killer.

lines.speaker: Cainan
lines.text:
Or mayhap your impulse control has been lost from 
the alcohol.

lines.speaker: Otis
lines.text:
Hey, hey! This smaller body might be more a 
lightweight than my old one, but I’m barely buzzed.

lines.speaker: Cainan
lines.text:
An amusing thought, as much as your “intuition” is. 
If this is it “buzzed”, I’d woe to see it when you
are actually drunk.

lines.speaker: Otis
lines.text:
Then let's get you in on this action!

Let out “Murderous Drunkard Cainan”, all ‘em 
ambitions laid out to bear!

lines.speaker: Cainan
lines.text:
I am not one to drink much even as a social 
obligation. I've no plans to indulge myself as such.

lines.speaker: Otis
lines.text:
Tsk. Now 'dem's how you tell me you're 
untrustworthy.

lines.speaker: Otis
lines.text: Sure I can't tempt you to?

lines.speaker: Cainan
lines.text: That is... a mighty cut.

lines.speaker: Cainan
lines.text:
It was only a matter of time when you played with 
your food as such.

lines.speaker: Otis
lines.text:
Argh! Goddess's pinky that stings!

Could ya do something instead of actin' like ya my 
mother?

lines.speaker: Cainan
lines.text:
It looks clean enough of a cut. With some medical 
care it should heal soon enough.
Cainan patted Otis near the wound.

lines.speaker: Otis
lines.text: Grk! Do ya have to do that?!

lines.speaker: Cainan
lines.text: What can I say? I had a "craving" to do as much.

Cainan chuckled and rose to his feet. He started 
towards the camp to get a healer and medicine.

lines.speaker: Otis
lines.text: Ay... Of all the ways to ruin a nice lunch...

As he walked, he pulled out his sword.

The sun shined brilliantly off of it, and he positioned 
it to see the reflection of himself in the blade.

lines.speaker: Cainan
lines.text: Windows to the soul, huh?

lines.speaker: Cainan
lines.text: What tomfoolery...

title: SP: Nora x Jude c - Talk

lines.text: A splurge of rice and meat landed on my plate.

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text: Thanks.
It didn't look particularly appetizing.

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text: (This slop again.)

lines.speaker: Nora
lines.text:
I replaced a rice portion with some beans. Beans 
are an excellent food for those training.

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text:
(She... does well with the ingredients she works 
with.)

lines.speaker: Nora
lines.text: Next.

I walked away, but a shadow of orange got caught 
in the corner of my eye.

Turning back to look, I saw a plate with more of 
said orange than mine.

lines.speaker: Nora
lines.text:
I replaced some rice with an extra vegetable 
serving.

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text: Ugh... carrots? Really?

lines.speaker: Nora
lines.text:
Eat a little and world might be a little more clear to 
you.

lines.speaker: Nora
lines.text:
Anyways, you should stop avoiding them or your 
health will deteriorate.

lines.speaker: Nora
lines.text: Next.

I turned my head back to see another person lining 
up for food.

lines.speaker: Jude
lines.text: Crap. She's cooking again...

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text: It's not...
An ominous odor rose from my food.

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text: It's not that bad...

lines.speaker: Jude
lines.text:
You do recall I signed up with you guys specifically 
to get away from her cooking, right?

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text:
I- I'll let Charlotte know to expand your cuisine 
budget a little.

lines.speaker: Jude
lines.text: Dammit...

I sat down to eat, and Charlotte soon joined me.

Charlotte had started trying to separate the carrots 
from the rest, but the mix was too elaborate to do 
so effectively.

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text: You might as well just eat the carrots.

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text:
Wanna play a game?

Each time I win, you trade some rice for a carrot.

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text:
And each time I win, you actually have to eat a 
carrots?

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text: What? No, I wouldn't-

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text: Better not hesitate. It's two carrots per now.

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text:
...

Fine.

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text: What's the game?

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text: I didn't think that far ahead.

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text: *Sigh*, let's make it simple, then.

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text: How about we bet on that?
I pointed to Jude approaching Nora for food.

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text:
What he gets. How much of it he eats. What Nora 
does. That sort of stuff.

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text: Deal. That's an easy one.

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text: I bet that...

lines.speaker: Jude
lines.text: Hello. Miss. Cook.

lines.speaker: Nora
lines.text: Are you going to hold your tongue this time?

lines.speaker: Nora
lines.text: Good.
Nora dumped a half portion onto Jude's plate.

lines.speaker: Jude
lines.text: Half...?

lines.speaker: Jude
lines.text: Are you just being cheap?

lines.speaker: Nora
lines.text:
Cheap is sustainable. It keeps a group running, from 
families to armies.

lines.speaker: Jude
lines.text: Still... half...?

lines.speaker: Nora
lines.text:
I gave you the amount you finished last time. Don't 
waste it.

lines.speaker: Jude
lines.text: Whatever.
*Crunch*

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text: Ugh...

Charlotte slowly chewed the carrot as she tried to 
keep it away from her taste buds.

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text: You're just going to taste it more that way.

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text: Shut up, you-

She quickly gulped down the food she was 
chewing after she got a distinct taste of the carrot.

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text:
After she went out of her way to customize 
entrees, I figured she'd be all about making him eat 
a serving.

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text:
I might have... mentioned something about Jude's 
high cuisine budget to her...

Nora, finished with her duties, grabbed her 
portions.

Her plate was a mishmash of whatever was left and 
had a lighter serving than standard.

After eying Jude tucked away in a corner, she sat 
herself across from him.

lines.speaker: Nora
lines.text: Now, that wasn't so bad, was it?

lines.speaker: Nora
lines.text: Wait, you've barely touched it?!

lines.speaker: Jude
lines.text: I'm eating it... at my own pace.

lines.speaker: Nora
lines.text: Then take a bite.

lines.speaker: Jude
lines.text: I- I can't do it with you watching me.

lines.speaker: Nora
lines.text: You're eating, not going to the bathroom.

lines.speaker: Jude
lines.text: Tsk.

lines.speaker: Nora
lines.text: Have you even tried it? Are you not hungry?

lines.speaker: Nora
lines.text: And to think you wanted a full serving.
Jude's stomach growled.

lines.speaker: Jude
lines.text: I'll invoke my right to silence.

lines.speaker: Nora
lines.text: *Sigh*... You need to eat. You'll die otherwise.

lines.speaker: Jude
lines.text: So be it.

lines.speaker: Nora
lines.text: Could you stop acting like a little kid?

lines.speaker: Nora
lines.text: What is so wrong with the food?

lines.speaker: Jude
lines.text:
You sure? You yelled at me the last time we tried 
this.

lines.speaker: Nora
lines.text: Just answer.

lines.speaker: Jude
lines.text: *Sigh*

lines.speaker: Jude
lines.text:
The beans are poorly marinated. The vegetables 
are insipid and old.

The meat is gamey and cooked to be more char 
than actual meat.

lines.speaker: Jude
lines.text: And none of it has any seasoning whatsoever.

lines.speaker: Nora
lines.text:
We need salt and such for preservatives. We can't 
waste it on the food itself.

We're not... We're not the decadents of Lockhart.
Charlotte sneezed in the background.

lines.speaker: Jude
lines.text: What's the point of food if it doesn't taste good?

lines.speaker: Nora
lines.text: To live.

lines.speaker: Jude
lines.text: A life not worth living, maybe...

lines.speaker: Nora
lines.text:
The food is good enough. It's tolerable.

Why do you have to be like this?
Jude nibbled on a few chewy pieces of meat.

lines.speaker: Jude
lines.text: Do we have any rice left?

lines.speaker: Nora
lines.text: You haven't even finished what's on your plate.

lines.speaker: Jude
lines.text:
Trade me, then.

I'll take some of your extra rice and you can have 
the rest of my mystery meat.

lines.speaker: Nora
lines.text: If it'll get you to actually eat...
The two swapped parts of their servings.

lines.speaker: Jude
lines.text: Thanks. This'll be plenty.
Jude stood up from his seat.

lines.speaker: Nora
lines.text: You're still at this?

lines.speaker: Jude
lines.text:
Nah. With this I might be able to make some rice 
pudding.

lines.speaker: Jude
lines.text: Finally...
Jude skipped off towards the kitchenette area.

lines.speaker: Nora
lines.text: D- Don't touch tomorrow's supplies!

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text: Rice pudding?

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text:
Don't even think about it. You've still got like 10 
carrots to get through from our bets.

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text: Hmm...

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text: I think I'll get some rice pudding.
Charlotte jumped to her feet.

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text: But the bet?

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text: Sue me, I'm a decadent.
She said as she slipped away with Jude.

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text: *Sigh*...

title: SP: Otis x Mariel C - Talk

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text: Urgh... That stings.

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text: Do we really need to do this? It isn't that bad.

lines.speaker: Mariel
lines.text:
If we let injuries go unattended, they'll just build up 
into bigger ones down the line.

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text: I guess...
A burst of blue magic sparkled from her heirloom.

lines.speaker: Mariel
lines.text: All done. Thankfully your wound was very light.

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text:
You're going down your list of everyone, right? 
Should I grab the next person?

lines.speaker: Mariel
lines.text: I believe you were the last holdout.

lines.speaker: Mariel
lines.text: Wait... unless..

Mariel stepped over to her medical ledger and 
flipped through her notes.

lines.speaker: Mariel
lines.text:
Actually, I don’t think Otis has ever reported for 
one of these.

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text: Sounds about right.

lines.speaker: Mariel
lines.text: What was that?

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text: Did I say that out loud?

lines.speaker: Mariel
lines.text:
Clearly and articulately.

Do elaborate.

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text:
I don't know... He's like a cat, right? Just... that 
sort of thing.

lines.speaker: Mariel
lines.text:
Really? Petty stereotypes? I didn't think you had it 
in you.

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text: I- I'm not trying to say all nekolyn are...
Mariel glared a little harder.

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text: A- Are like... that...

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text: Just that cantankerous guy.

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text:
Freaks out when you touch him, licks his wounds, 
sneaking extra fish when we have it...

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text:
I'm sure you're right. I'm just jumping to 
conclusions. You should go do an exam 
anyways.

lines.speaker: Mariel
lines.text:
I'll choose to ignore the parts not about the 
medical exam then.

lines.speaker: Mariel
lines.text: I'll get him healthy if its the last thing I do!

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text:
Well, if you need bait...

Don't forget to bring some fish.

lines.speaker: Mariel
lines.text: Sorry! I hope I'm not interrupting anything!

lines.speaker: Otis
lines.text:
*Yawn*... Nay, just about ta’ settle in for a wee 
nap is all.

Otis rolled onto his hands and knees and began to 
stretch his arms in a very catlike manner.

lines.speaker: Mariel
lines.text: Uh...

Mariel raised an eyebrow at the odd behavior, but 
decided not to comment.

lines.speaker: Mariel
lines.text:
I was just hoping to do the regular medical exam. 
You know, just like everyone else?

lines.speaker: Otis
lines.text: Sounds like that sort of custom, ya.

lines.speaker: Mariel
lines.text: Then shall we...?

lines.speaker: Otis
lines.text:
I'll be good, lassie.

Been in fights worse than anythin’ your pretty head 
could imagine. An old neko like me can be takin’ 
care o’ himself.

lines.speaker: Mariel
lines.text: But wouldn't you be better off if I-

lines.speaker: Otis
lines.text: Sorry, lass. But now ya startin' to interrupt my nap.

Otis began to draw the tent flap to cut out Mariel's 
access.

lines.speaker: Mariel
lines.text: W- Wait...
A familiar idea popped into her head.

lines.speaker: Mariel
lines.text: You can have my grilled fish ration.
Otis perked up immediately.

lines.speaker: Otis
lines.text: Er, what’s that now?

lines.speaker: Mariel
lines.text:
Hrm? Oh, nothing.

I'm not a big fan of fish, so I was thinking of sharing 
my portion when the day for it comes up.

But since you’re a big strong pirate and all, I doubt 
you really need it.

lines.speaker: Otis
lines.text:
No need for acts. A pirate I may be, but I also be a 
merchant, aye?

lines.speaker: Otis
lines.text:
I can sniff out that quid pro quo when you serve it 
up.

lines.speaker: Mariel
lines.text: Then... is it a deal? Fish for medical care?

Otis bit his lip and seemed to be weighing his 
options.

lines.speaker: Otis
lines.text: Blast it... You actually make a fair bargain...

lines.speaker: Otis
lines.text:
Fine! I accept.

Now... as soon as we get that fish, you can...

lines.speaker: Mariel
lines.text: Nope! Exam first. Now, even.

lines.speaker: Otis
lines.text: Argh...
In the near future...

lines.speaker: Mariel
lines.text:
Hm?

When did we run out of milk? I
thought we just resupplied?

lines.speaker: Mariel
lines.text: *Sigh*... Water it is then?

Mariel closed up the supplies and turned away in a 
hurry.

As she rounded a corner, something caught her 
attention from the corner of her eye.

lines.speaker: Mariel
lines.text: Wait... Is that Otis...?

Off in the distance was Otis with a cup filled with 
milk.

lines.speaker: Mariel
lines.text:
Oh, it was just Otis that finished off the milk.

That's good to... know...
*Lick*

lines.speaker: Mariel
lines.text: ...What?

Otis had stuck his tongue in the milk and lapped it 
up like a cat.

lines.speaker: Mariel
lines.text: Did he... That was really cute...

lines.speaker: Mariel
lines.text: No, no... That was just a coincidence...
Otis did it again.

lines.speaker: Mariel
lines.text:
I need to get going...

Maybe we should keep more milk in stock...?

lines.speaker: Mariel
lines.text: Then we also need...

Mariel turned the corner as she approached another 
shop.

lines.speaker: Otis
lines.text: Argh. This itch...
Otis was walking front of her.

lines.speaker: Mariel
lines.text: An itch? I have a remedy that he might like?

lines.speaker: Mariel
lines.text: Or...

Otis had scooted up to a nearby building and 
started scratching himself by rubbing up on it.

lines.speaker: Mariel
lines.text: Does he normally...

Mariel rubbed her eyes.

But Otis had already rounded the corner and left by 
the time she finished.

lines.speaker: Mariel
lines.text: Huh...?

lines.speaker: Otis
lines.text: Urgh...
At a dining spot, Mariel found Otis in discomfort.

lines.speaker: Mariel
lines.text: Are you okay? You don’t look so good.

Otis grabbed a napkin from nearby and seemed to 
cough up something into it.

lines.speaker: Otis
lines.text: Bleh…er, apologies, lass. It just be a hair-

lines.speaker: Otis
lines.text: Just a... somethin' in my throat.

Otis dropped the napkin into the fire and paced off 
from his finished dinner.

Mariel turned to see the napkin burning, only to 
notice small strands sticking out of it.

lines.speaker: Mariel
lines.text: Hair...ball...?

lines.speaker: Mariel
lines.text: I- It couldn't be...

lines.speaker: Mariel
lines.text: Another glancing cut.
Mariel covered her mouth and released a yawn.

lines.speaker: Mariel
lines.text: Sorry. It's just been a long day.

The princess moved to ministrations of other parts 
of Otis.

Otis turned towards his cut and...

...gave it a lick?

lines.speaker: Mariel
lines.text: What are you doing?

lines.speaker: Otis
lines.text: Doing what?
Mariel blinked and shook her head.

lines.speaker: Mariel
lines.text: N- Nothing...

lines.speaker: Mariel
lines.text: It really has been a long day...

Mariel pushed aside the tent flap and entered to 
see...

lines.speaker: Otis
lines.text: ZZZzzzzz...

lines.speaker: Mariel
lines.text: Oh, is this not my... I'm... sorry...

Her words trailed off as it appeared Otis stayed fast 
asleep.

lines.speaker: Mariel
lines.text: *Sigh*...
She sat down near him.

lines.speaker: Mariel
lines.text: This is my tent. You need to-

lines.speaker: Otis
lines.text: *Purrr*...
Otis had shifted in his sleep to nuzzle against Mariel.

lines.speaker: Mariel
lines.text: Cute...

lines.speaker: Mariel
lines.text: Oh... N- No... I'll just... just sleep in your tent.

Jumping to her feet, Mariel was soon out of the 
tent.

Otis's eyes opened.

lines.speaker: Otis
lines.text: Haha...

lines.speaker: Otis
lines.text:
So there I was, axe clenched in me one good 
hand...

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text: (There's Otis's story time.)

As I approached, my foot slipped on some mud and 
I stumbled forward.

lines.speaker: Otis
lines.text: *Hiss*!

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text: Argh! What'd you scratch me for?!

lines.speaker: Otis
lines.text:
For falling all over me like a drunk barmaid right in 
the middle o me story!

Was jus’ gettin’ to the best part, too!

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text: Whatever...

I stumbled over to the edge of the group and 
Mariel followed me.

lines.speaker: Mariel
lines.text: Wow, you're bleeding.

lines.speaker: Mariel
lines.text: Otis really can be like... that... can't he?

lines.speaker: Mariel
lines.text: I have my heirloom in my tent. Just wait a second.

She headed off towards her tent and I doubled 
back to Otis.

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text:
You didn’t have to actually scratch me, you damn 
salty pirate!
Otis laughed heartily and slapped me on the back.

lines.speaker: Otis
lines.text: Salesmanship, lass. Salesmanship

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text: Then I expect hazard pay. Backpay, even.

lines.speaker: Otis
lines.text: Greedy little kid, aren't ya?

lines.speaker: Otis
lines.text:
A merchant's word is his coin, though.

Here ya go. Best coin I've spent since joinin' ya lot, 
anyways.

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text: Yeah, just don't overdo it.

I took the money and pocketed it before I heard 
the sound of footsteps approaching.

lines.speaker: Mariel
lines.text: Here, Pup. Let me see it.

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text:
Right... It isn't too bad...

It's uh... not the first time...

title: SP: Otis x Mariel B - Talk

lines.speaker: Mariel
lines.text: Honestly... How do you even get like this?

lines.speaker: Mariel
lines.text:
I'm going to run out of... mh! ...bandages at this 
rate!

lines.speaker: Otis
lines.text: Keh!

Mariel tightened the bandage a bit too 
enthusiastically and then turned to rummage 
in her bag.

lines.speaker: Otis
lines.text:
Are ya daft, lass?

Dem's no glory without guts in berserkin'.
Mariel froze and slowly turned to Otis.

Despite the daggers from Mariel's eyes, Otis simply 
shrugged.

lines.speaker: Otis
lines.text: Keh! Again!? Too tight.

Still staring, Mariel had went to tighten the 
bandages further.

lines.speaker: Mariel
lines.text:
In my medical opinion, less blood loss will result in 
less ridiculous words coming out of you.

lines.speaker: Otis
lines.text:
And how'd you stranglin' me suppose to help 
that?!

lines.speaker: Mariel
lines.text:
Don't pretend you don't know what blood pressure 
is.

lines.speaker: Otis
lines.text: It does have a familiar ring to it...

lines.speaker: Otis
lines.text: Ack!

With a another tightening of a bandage, Otis lashed 
out at Mariel.

She instinctively leaned away from the scratching 
motion.

lines.speaker: Mariel
lines.text: Otis... B- Bad kitty!

She leaned in and clapped her hands right in front 
of his face.

lines.speaker: Otis
lines.text: Lass... I didn't know you were like that...

lines.speaker: Mariel
lines.text: W- What?

lines.speaker: Otis
lines.text: Did ya... really just say that?

lines.speaker: Mariel
lines.text:
Say... w- what? But you... You went to scratch me 
like some... tomcat?

lines.speaker: Otis
lines.text: For shame, lass.

lines.speaker: Mariel
lines.text:
I know, I know. The whole “cat thing” with 
Nekolyn is an ugly stereotype. It's just that-

lines.speaker: Mariel
lines.text: What about the milk stuff and... the h- hair...

lines.speaker: Mariel
lines.text: ...the hairball...

lines.speaker: Otis
lines.text:
Are you imaginin' things? Misremembering them, 
even?

lines.speaker: Mariel
lines.text: I... I mean...

Mariel's mouth moved like she was about to say 
something, but her expression became regretful.

lines.speaker: Mariel
lines.text:
Never mind. I’m sorry.

And after I scolded Pup about it, too…

lines.speaker: Otis
lines.text: Pup?

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text: He's like a cat, right? Just... that sort of thing.

lines.speaker: Mariel
lines.text: I took the words too close to heart...
She fidgeted some as she looked away regretfully.

lines.speaker: Mariel
lines.text:
I ended up... wanting your actions to be more 
catlike, it seems...

lines.speaker: Otis
lines.text: That so, lass?

lines.speaker: Otis
lines.text:
Ah well, I think I've got the appropriate 
punishment.
Otis turned away and pointed to his head.

lines.speaker: Otis
lines.text:
Exposit therapy, or somethin' what have you?

Face your sins head on by doubling down on them.

lines.speaker: Mariel
lines.text: I'm not... sure what you mean?

lines.speaker: Otis
lines.text: Pet me like ya damn cats.

lines.speaker: Otis
lines.text:
Now that ya regret ya actions, do them again to 
rub some salt in the wound.

That way ya don't do it again.

lines.speaker: Mariel
lines.text:
Oh, I couldn't... I would want to make you go 
through that.

lines.speaker: Otis
lines.text: Just do it already! I can take it!

Mariel raised her hand.

Slowly but surely, she started to pet Otis.

lines.speaker: Otis
lines.text:
...

Heh... now she'll...
Otis sat there trying to keep a straight face.

lines.speaker: Mariel
lines.text:
You’ll probably think this is silly, but it made me a 
little... nostalgic.

lines.speaker: Otis
lines.text: Hm?

lines.speaker: Mariel
lines.text:
When I was a young girl, I really wanted a pet 
kitty.

My parents forbid it, though. They... 
understandably would not sway on that 
for good reason.

lines.speaker: Otis
lines.text: That so?

lines.speaker: Mariel
lines.text:
In hindsight, maybe I tried to subconsciously live 
out my childhood fantasy through you.

Mariel gave another petting stroke and Otis's ear 
twitched a little.

Otis sat there, with facial expressions twitching on 
his face like he was jumping between thoughts 
rapidly.

lines.speaker: Otis
lines.text: Well, then we'll just have to-

lines.speaker: Otis
lines.text: *Clears throat*...

lines.speaker: Otis
lines.text:
We'll just have to keep up this theraputanical 
doing, then, yeah?

lines.speaker: Mariel
lines.text: I don't understand?

lines.speaker: Otis
lines.text:
That be the port side of it, but on the starboard... 
tis been a long time since I’ve heard such a story.

lines.speaker: Otis
lines.text:
Tell ya what.

This whole thing started with a deal, so why not be 
lettin’ it end with one?

lines.speaker: Mariel
lines.text: What kind of deal?

lines.speaker: Otis
lines.text:
I'll let ya get this out of your system with more 
private sessions like this.

Otis reached behind him and pulled Mariel's hand 
back to a position to keep petting him.

lines.speaker: Otis
lines.text: That... That'd work. Ah...

lines.speaker: Otis
lines.text:
In return, you pamper me when ya can. An offerin', 
of a sort.

lines.speaker: Mariel
lines.text: Like bring you extra fish and milk and stuff?

lines.speaker: Otis
lines.text: Hey now, lass.

lines.speaker: Mariel
lines.text: S- Sorry...
Mariel began to pet even more.

lines.speaker: Otis
lines.text: Milk ain't bad for the bones.

lines.speaker: Otis
lines.text: But I do love a good fish.

lines.speaker: Otis
lines.text: Not cause of the neko trite, mind ya.

lines.speaker: Otis
lines.text:
I've lived most of my life on the sea. It's good for a 
bit of glorious nostalgia.

lines.speaker: Mariel
lines.text: I think... I think that could work.

lines.speaker: Otis
lines.text: Now get o’er here. I’m still bleedin’.

lines.speaker: Mariel
lines.text: Oh, right.

Mariel reached back to her supplies and towards 
Otis again.

lines.speaker: Mariel
lines.text: There, all done.

lines.speaker: Otis
lines.text: Thank ye, girl. Now, if ye don’t mind...
Otis plopped down into Mariel's lap.

lines.speaker: Otis
lines.text: Theraputetics time proper now.

lines.speaker: Mariel
lines.text:
Eep! What are you…

Oh, I get it.
She began stroking Otis’ head gently.

lines.speaker: Mariel
lines.text: Good... uh... kitty...?

lines.speaker: Otis
lines.text: *Purring noises*
I began to trod off in the direction of Otis’ tent.

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text:
(Crap, I'm out of loose coin after losing that 
hand...)

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text:
(I wonder if Otis has any more jobs? I do have an 
idea to mess with Mariel he might like.)

lines.speaker: Mariel
lines.text: Pup?

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text: Ack!
I jumped back from the sudden blonde girl surprise.

lines.speaker: Mariel
lines.text: Are you okay?

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text: Yeah, you just startled me.

lines.speaker: Mariel
lines.text:
Sorry about that. But why so jumpy? Sneaking off 
somewhere?

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text: N- No...

lines.speaker: Mariel
lines.text:
Really? Since the only thing in that direction is Otis' 
tent.

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text:
Y- You know the cantankerous guy. Likes to 
scratch and lash out and... ya know...

Thought I might ask him to calm it down?

lines.speaker: Mariel
lines.text:
Hmm...

You know... A little birdy told me you've been 
losing at cards a lot recently...

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text: I mean... I guess...?

lines.speaker: Mariel
lines.text:
So... Otis has been paying your card game debts in 
return for help messing with me?

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text: Ah... that...

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text: So he told you?

lines.speaker: Mariel
lines.text: Nope. You did. Just now.

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text: Oh.

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text: OOOOHHHHH?!

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text: I- I deny everything...

lines.speaker: Mariel
lines.text:
Aahaha... Pup, you’re just too genuine to function 
as much of a liar.

lines.speaker: Mariel
lines.text: Some like that sort of thing though...

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text: Huh...?

lines.speaker: Mariel
lines.text: Nothing. Have a good night.

Mariel began walking off without another word.

There seemed to be an unusual spring in her step.

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text: (Is she happy about something?)

lines.speaker: Mariel
lines.text: I suppose it all worked out in the end.

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text: (I'm still broke, aren't I...?)

title: SP: Charlottte x Ben C - Talk

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text:
"America"...?

What's that? A town?

lines.speaker: Bennett
lines.text: Uh... Something like that.

lines.speaker: Bennett
lines.text: If it doesn't ring a bell, then it isn't important.

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text:
Never heard of it... Does that make you from the 
Outlands down south?

lines.speaker: Bennett
lines.text:
I... doubt it, but who knows? Too much is a 
mystery to me.

lines.speaker: Bennett
lines.text:
Not like this is the first time I've woken up not 
knowing where I am.

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text:
We'll make sure no one takes advantage of you 
while you're with us, at least.

lines.speaker: Bennett
lines.text: "Take advantage" of me...?

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text:
Right, like those pirates back at that tavern we 
found you at.

Trying to prey on a vulnerable girl like that. It 
makes me sick.

lines.speaker: Bennett
lines.text: I guess that makes sense.

lines.speaker: Bennett
lines.text:
Maybe I was just too drunk to process it like 
that...?

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text: They didn't steal anything from you, did they?

lines.speaker: Bennett
lines.text: Not sure I have anything to-

Bennett had reached back to a pocket when she 
stopped talking.

Pulling out a shiny small rectangular object, 
Bennett stared at it without much expression 
on her face.

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text:
So they didn't just take everything, at least? 
What've you got there?

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text: Hello? Bennett, you okay?

lines.speaker: Bennett
lines.text: Hm?

lines.speaker: Bennett
lines.text:
Oh- Oh... yeah. Nothing important. I didn't have 
anything valuable on me anyways.
Bennett quickly stowed away the object again.

lines.speaker: Bennett
lines.text:
Well, that's enough for today. I think I'm going to 
crash for a while.

Bennett jumped up to her feet and started off 
towards her tent.

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text: Hm...

As Charlotte was waking up the next day, she saw 
Bennett wander out of camp.

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text: So obvious.

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text:
She does seem sort of... out there. Maybe I should 
keep an eye on her just in case anyone weird 
comes along?

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text: She's... looking at that thing again.

lines.speaker: Bennett
lines.text: ...one bar...?

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text: Why is she holding it up to the sky...?

lines.speaker: Bennett
lines.text: How is it here...?

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text:
Hm? Did I see... light coming off it? 
No... that couldn't...

lines.speaker: Bennett
lines.text:
Are there just frequencies similar to a radio tower 
or something?

lines.speaker: Bennett
lines.text: Maybe this really is a waste of time?

Sighing, Bennett put the object back into her 
inventory.

lines.speaker: Bennett
lines.text: Ack! What... What are you-!?

A face greeted her as she looked up,
and she jumped back in a fright.

lines.speaker: Bennett
lines.text: *Sigh*...

lines.speaker: Bennett
lines.text: Are you trying to kill me?

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text:
Doing a good enough job of that yourself.

I stopped trying to hide that I was following you a 
while ago.

lines.speaker: Bennett
lines.text: You... what?

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text:
Is this how it happened before we met you? How 
you got pulled into all that in Ranakstown?

You just... wandered off in the middle of the night 
with no care for your own safety?

lines.speaker: Bennett
lines.text:
...I can take care of myself. You don't need to 
worry.

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text:
It's common sense. You're a pretty girl by yourself 
at night.

You're inviting unnecessary danger. 
It is just reckless.

lines.speaker: Bennett
lines.text: I... I mean...

lines.speaker: Bennett
lines.text:
I guess... I've never really thought about that 
before.

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text: *Sigh*... Of course!

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text:
What's so important that you needed to do this, 
anyways? I might as well help.

lines.speaker: Bennett
lines.text: You really don't need to-

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text: Tell me.

lines.speaker: Bennett
lines.text: You really don't...
Charlotte stared daggers into Bennett.

lines.speaker: Bennett
lines.text: *Sigh*... If you insist.
Bennett took the object out.

lines.speaker: Bennett
lines.text:
This is a device from where I am from. A phone.

It's a device used to communicate with others. It 
wirelessly transmits electromagnetic waves.

Those waves are transmitted over certain bands 
of frequency constantly by a radio signal tower.

And...

lines.speaker: Bennett
lines.text: See, this is more of a pain to you than not.

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text: No... just... I'm not sure what half those words are.

lines.speaker: Bennett
lines.text: Haha... ha...

lines.speaker: Bennett
lines.text:
The point is that my phone is indicating it is picking 
up a weak signal.

lines.speaker: Bennett
lines.text:
It isn't actually... you know... working as a phone, 
though, despite that.

So I was trying to figure out why.  Since 
I wouldn't expect that to be possible here.

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text: Hmm...
Charlotte rubbed her temples.

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text:
You're not like... a secret genius or something, 
are you?

lines.speaker: Bennett
lines.text: God no.

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text:
Hmm... signal...?

Is it anything like magic lines?

lines.speaker: Bennett
lines.text: Now you've got me at a loss...

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text:
They're conduits for magical energy.

Some more modern tech pulsates the flow of magic 
to encode information.

lines.speaker: Bennett
lines.text: It might be... similar...ish...

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text: Here, let me...

Charlotte, before Bennett could react, grabbed the 
phone from her.

lines.speaker: Bennett
lines.text: No, no no no! Don't-

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text:
So it's like a light of some sort?

"Twitter"... "Discord"... What are all these symbols 
on it?

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text: Huh?! It moved?! Why did it all move?!

lines.speaker: Bennett
lines.text: That's a complicated question to answer and-

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text: Why is there an image of naked ladies on-

lines.speaker: Bennett
lines.text: NO! NO NO NO!

Bennett reacted like a snake snapping at its victim 
as she grabbed the phone back from her.

lines.speaker: Bennett
lines.text: Never that! Th- That's... That's private!

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text:
What did I just...

What... in the Goddess's name was that?

lines.speaker: Bennett
lines.text: Completely inconsequential, that's what it was!

lines.speaker: Bennett
lines.text:
It's going to run out of battery soon anyways. So it 
really doesn't matter.

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text: I could get you more power cells.

lines.speaker: Bennett
lines.text: Are they DC voltage?

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text: Are they what?

lines.speaker: Bennett
lines.text: Then oh well! We tried!
Bennett started taking steps back.

lines.speaker: Bennett
lines.text: Like you said, we shouldn't be out alone at night.

lines.speaker: Bennett
lines.text:
Seriously... don't worry about it. 
You have bigger problems.

lines.speaker: Bennett
lines.text: Have a nice night!

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text: Yeah... you... too...

lines.speaker: Bennett
lines.text:
Ugh... What... is...

What is that weight?

lines.speaker: Bennett
lines.text: Oh crap, did I change again?

Bennett rose from her sleeping position to view the 
world around.

lines.speaker: Bennett
lines.text:
Wait, no. No I didn't.
Something's in my way...

lines.speaker: Bennett
lines.text: The hell is up with this...

lines.speaker: Bennett
lines.text: This box?!

A heavy box had been placed on top of the 
sleeping Bennett.

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text: Morning.
Charlotte scavenged among the box's contents.

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text: So explain what you said yesterday again.

lines.speaker: Bennett
lines.text:
Are you still going on about that...?

It really is-

lines.speaker: Bennett
lines.text: Ugh... Can you get this box off me?

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text: Are you going to cooperate?

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text: I've got all day.

lines.speaker: Bennett
lines.text:
Are you sure? You have so many more important 
things to spend your time on.

lines.speaker: Bennett
lines.text: My issues are mine, not yours...

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text: I don't hear an answer~

lines.speaker: Bennett
lines.text: Ha... haha... Of course this'd happen.

lines.speaker: Bennett
lines.text:
Fine. If you want to so bad that you're gonna force 
the issue, then I guess I should.

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text:
Perfect. Then let's start with this step by step. 
Power was a concern, yeah?

lines.speaker: Bennett
lines.text: Probably.

Bennett looked out towards the ragtag setup 
Charlotte had quickly cobbled together.

lines.speaker: Bennett
lines.text:
Heh... haha...

Hey... You got... potatoes here?

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text: ...Why?

lines.speaker: Bennett
lines.text:
I don't know... Just sort got the vibe of a "science 
fair" for a second there.

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text: Science... fair...?

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text: That sounds... fun. What is that?

lines.speaker: Bennett
lines.text: Maybe I should... just shut up...

title: SP: Otis x Satia C - TODO - Parnips

lines.text:
Argh!

Haha! Down with you!

F- Fall back!

lines.speaker: Otis
lines.text:
Nyahaha, men! Get every last crate!
Make it quick, this boat will be
going down any second now!

lines.speaker: Noble Merchant
lines.text: W- Why are you doing this?!

lines.speaker: Otis
lines.text:
Why not!? The men be restless. And
who am I to deny such a plunder as
yours?

lines.speaker: Noble Merchant
lines.text:
Nekolyn bitch, you’ll pay for this!
You clearly don't know who you're
stealing from!

lines.speaker: Otis
lines.text:
Failing memory, have you? 
That'd be my line.

lines.speaker: Noble Merchant
lines.text:
What are you...? Is your brain
rotten from lapping the rancid
phalli of these barbarians?!

lines.speaker: Otis
lines.text:
Ah shucks. You do be doing me a
favor by making this even more fun~

On my mark!
The pirates let out a cheer in unison.

lines.speaker: Otis
lines.text: Three!

lines.speaker: Noble Merchant
lines.text: Your ship?! You truly are unhinged!

lines.speaker: Otis
lines.text: Two!

lines.speaker: Noble Merchant
lines.text: You'll destroy it!

lines.speaker: Otis
lines.text: One!

lines.speaker: Noble Merchant
lines.text:
You truly wish to carve your own
ship through mine?!

lines.speaker: Otis
lines.text: Like a pig.

lines.speaker: Otis
lines.text: NOW!

lines.speaker: Crow A
lines.text: Stop.

lines.speaker: Crow A
lines.text: That didn't happen.

lines.speaker: Crow B
lines.text:
Just imagine the risk-reward of
destroying your own ship...

lines.speaker: Crow A
lines.text: Yeah, for some extra bacon.

lines.speaker: Crow C
lines.text: I mean... it could have happened.

lines.speaker: Crow B
lines.text: Don't encourage him.

lines.speaker: Otis
lines.text:
Ha! You lot would do the same if you
knew the guy's supply chain.

lines.speaker: Crow A
lines.text:
Eh... We're professionals. I mean...
really? All that over bacon?

Some crispy bacon is good in the
morning, but a ship is way more
useful long term.
It's like...

lines.speaker: Crow C
lines.text: Like two bacon?

The Nightless Crow got his head thwacked for the 
comment.

lines.speaker: Crow B
lines.text:
And that's all assuming what you 
said was even true.

lines.speaker: Otis
lines.text:
Ye of little faith.

Give a little more and you could be
eating like royalty.

lines.speaker: Satia
lines.text: *Clears throat*...

lines.speaker: Otis
lines.text:
Ah! If it isn't the mama bird
herself. How long've you been there?

lines.speaker: Satia
lines.text:
Long enough to see your little tale
fall apart.

lines.speaker: Crow B
lines.text:
Wait, should we bail before we get
caught in the crossfire?

lines.speaker: Crow A
lines.text:
Nah, no way! I've never seen a
proper 'cat fight' before, let alone
half-a-literal one.
Satia gave a judgmental glare at Otis.

lines.speaker: Otis
lines.text:
Scary. 

Not afraid your face will get
stuck like that?

lines.speaker: Otis
lines.text: Pretty as it'd be.

lines.speaker: Satia
lines.text:
Half-assed flirting? I guess it is
true what they say about pirates.
She slid onto a nearby seat to sit down.

lines.speaker: Otis
lines.text: Eh?

lines.speaker: Satia
lines.text: That you're the bandits of the sea.

lines.speaker: Satia
lines.text:
No brains. No honor. No common sense
enough to work an honest day's work.

lines.speaker: Otis
lines.text: But a good fuck, yeah?

lines.speaker: Satia
lines.text:
You'd think a women's intuition
would offer you even a little sense.

lines.speaker: Otis
lines.text:
Careful about the scowl, birdy. I
know from my ol' body how
permanent...
Otis traced his hand in a line around his eyes.

lines.speaker: Otis
lines.text: ...wrinkles can be.

lines.speaker: Satia
lines.text: You've lost more than wrinkles in your face.

lines.speaker: Satia
lines.text:
Your old shriveled up balls only
live on through your gall to brag
about damaging civilian supply lines.

lines.speaker: Otis
lines.text:
Ack! They were basically asking for
it!

lines.speaker: Otis
lines.text:
No guards worth a damn, a drunkard
at the helm... 

Easy targets, the lot of them.

lines.speaker: Otis
lines.text: And can you really say 'no' to bacon?

lines.speaker: Satia
lines.text:
What a poor little kitten. Did someone forget to 
feed you and your brutes?

lines.speaker: Otis
lines.text:
Ay! At least me men have the balls
to take what they want.

lines.speaker: Otis
lines.text:
You still trying to baby that little
Puppy-dog you've got leashed up
here?
So scrawny, ya starvin’ ‘em!

lines.speaker: Otis
lines.text:
‘Please, mama bird, I need some
more…!’ they must cry every night!
Satia's head turned slowly towards Otis.

lines.speaker: Crow C
lines.text: Why'd they stop talking?

lines.speaker: Crow B
lines.text: SHH! They might kill us!

lines.speaker: Otis
lines.text: Fine. Lines not to cross...

lines.speaker: Satia
lines.text:
So the embers of sense flicker their final, dying 
flame.

lines.speaker: Otis
lines.text: That they have, mama.

lines.speaker: Satia
lines.text:
Must you? I have... 

...never been a mother.

lines.speaker: Otis
lines.text:
Now that’s a lie-and-a-half! What other
sort of scoundrel fusses over
scrubbing teeth?

lines.speaker: Satia
lines.text:
Everyone has their reasons. 

Ones I have no interest in sharing with
your kind.

lines.speaker: Otis
lines.text: Neko-kind?

lines.speaker: Satia
lines.text: Murderer-kind.

lines.speaker: Otis
lines.text: Tsk. All that shite lost was his boat and bacon.

lines.speaker: Crow C
lines.text: *Gasp*! So he did ram it?

lines.speaker: Crow A
lines.text: Shut it!

lines.speaker: Otis
lines.text: And maybe... one or two men... Or three...

lines.speaker: Otis
lines.text:
But ya must really like the smell of
noble dick to jump on one so willingly.

Satia, in the middle of taking a sip from her drink, 
stopped as she was.

lines.speaker: Satia
lines.text:
My distaste is for the method.

As I said, you're like any bandit.

Mindless violence.

lines.speaker: Otis
lines.text:
So the violence is fine if ya got
yourself an excuse?

lines.speaker: Otis
lines.text: Sent by the big bad noble to do 'is biddin'?

lines.speaker: Otis
lines.text: At least fight for yourself, would ya?

Satia, still frozen mid sip, started 
moving again.

She took a deep breath.

lines.speaker: Otis
lines.text: What? Cat got your tongue?

lines.speaker: Satia
lines.text: This is going nowhere.

lines.speaker: Satia
lines.text:
I don't believe you're even capable
of fighting like a proper Crow can.

You cannot fight to a tactic. A
purpose. A path forward for everyone
to be safe and thrive.

lines.speaker: Otis
lines.text: That a challenge? Not even a hard one!

lines.speaker: Satia
lines.text: More like a test.

lines.speaker: Satia
lines.text:
To see if you're a liability. If you're a bandit to
your core when things truly matter.

lines.speaker: Otis
lines.text:
Raising the stakes, eh? Now I sort of wanna do it 
when ya got me blood boilin' like this.

Willing to sweeten the deal? Put some bacon on 
top to wet the appetite?

lines.speaker: Satia
lines.text:
Sure, I'll answer whatever propositions
your 'kind' may have.

lines.speaker: Otis
lines.text:
Not just that, birdy.

WHEN I win? I get that AND...

Otis recoiled back a little as he looked to 
ponder his current thought more.

lines.speaker: Satia
lines.text: Heh... Cat got your tongue?

lines.speaker: Otis
lines.text: Fuck it.

lines.speaker: Otis
lines.text:
If I win...

Then I get ta fuck ya!

lines.speaker: Satia
lines.text: Excuse me?

lines.speaker: Crow A
lines.text: Rest-in-pieces, Otis…

lines.speaker: Crow B
lines.text:
It’s like she’s deadset on diggin’
her own grave…

lines.speaker: Crow A
lines.text: She?

lines.speaker: Crow A
lines.text:
Shite. Which was it again? I can't
keep track anymore.

lines.speaker: Otis
lines.text:
I've never mounted a Mama Bird
before.

I expect ta see the goddess up in
the skies with ya!

lines.speaker: Satia
lines.text: ...Incorrigible.

lines.speaker: Otis
lines.text: Heheh.

lines.speaker: Satia
lines.text:
Very well. If you don't fail miserably, as you will, we 
can do whatever nonsense you've dreamed up.

lines.speaker: Otis
lines.text: For real?

lines.speaker: Otis
lines.text: I'm not going to let ya forget this, ay.

lines.speaker: Satia
lines.text: Save the date, then.

lines.speaker: Otis
lines.text: I'll be looking forward to it.

Otis's hand reached out, and then Satia extended 
her own to confirm the deal on.

Both had devious looks on their faces, like 
they were stifling laughs.

They turned on their heels, and the laughing 
started leaking out as they walked away 
from each other.

lines.speaker: Crow A
lines.text: ...What the hell was that…?

lines.speaker: Crow B
lines.text: I... don't know..

lines.speaker: Crow A
lines.text:
You think we're gonna get pulled in on that fight? 
The one they end up staking the bet on?

lines.speaker: Crow B
lines.text: I... hope so...? Maybe...?

lines.speaker: Crow C
lines.text:
Hmm...

You know, this really puts me in the
mood for some bacon.

title: SP: Pup x Norde C - Begining

lines.text: I raised the sword to my eyeline.

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text: Yeah, that's sharp now.

Getting up, I sauntered over to the weapon rack 
to put the sword back into storage.

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text: Hm?

I passed by a set of swords that had been 
designated for training purposes.

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text:
When did these get so bad?

I couldn't even buff out the problems with some of 
these...

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text:
...

(It's been too long since we updated our training 
arms, I think.)

My head turned towards a nearby tent.

Soft voices could be heard from within.

lines.speaker: Norde
lines.text:
Then we'd be able to send people back to this 
town for supplies if we get boxed in.

lines.speaker: Fellow Crow
lines.text:
Yeah, we can scout out that path for additional 
threats first, though.

lines.speaker: Norde
lines.text: Then we'll need to-

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text: Hello, fellow Crows.

lines.speaker: Fellow Crow
lines.text: Were you expecting company?

lines.speaker: Norde
lines.text: No.

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text: We've got a problem.

lines.speaker: Norde
lines.text: We're busy.

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text: Are you?
I turned to the Nightless Crow he was talking to.

lines.speaker: Fellow Crow
lines.text: Oh, well... We were just finishing up anyways.

lines.speaker: Norde
lines.text: We are busy.

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text:
Perfect.

So we've got an issue with the training gear.

A lot of it is just completely on it's last legs. We 
need replacements.

lines.speaker: Norde
lines.text: There are more important issues to worry about.

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text: But there's always something "more important".

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text:
That's why it's gotten as bad as it has in the first 
place.

Norde lowered his head a little a took a deep 
breath.

lines.speaker: Norde
lines.text:
Then go fix it.

If it truly is so important, then you can deal with it 
yourself.

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text:
You know I don't have that much control over our 
spending.

Norde lowered his head again and took another 
deep breath.

lines.speaker: Norde
lines.text: Then earn it.

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text: What?

Norde raised himself to his feet, towering over 
Pup's current stature.

lines.speaker: Norde
lines.text: A test of strength.

lines.speaker: Fellow Crow
lines.text: Sir, what are you talking about?

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text: (A test of... strength.)

I could feel my blood boil a little when presented 
with the words.

lines.speaker: Norde
lines.text: A duel. Now.

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text: Deal.

lines.speaker: Fellow Crow
lines.text:
W- What?!

Oh, for fuck's sake... You two are doing this again?

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text:
...

Why am I here?

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text: You're the piggy bank

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text: Would you mind rephrasing that?

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text: Ah, woops.

lines.speaker: Norde
lines.text: You are our primary financier at this time.

lines.speaker: Norde
lines.text:
It was appropriate to deem you the
judge of this.

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text: *Sigh*... Can we not, then? This is stupid.

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text: No.

lines.speaker: Norde
lines.text: No.

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text:
Yeah, well next time I'm gonna shop around for 
mercenaries to hire instead of just going with the 
first one to save me, then.

Pup and Norde continued staring each other down 
with weapons at the ready.

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text: *Sigh*... Fine, let's just not kill each other, yeah?

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text:
Then we'll start in... 

3... 

2...

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text: Go!

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text:
(Dammit. I'm constantly on the defensive.)

(Maybe if I-)

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text: (A heavy... strike... I almost missed blocking that.)

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text: Hey! I said no killing each other!

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text: (Maybe if I...)

With the blades clashing, I let go of my weight and 
let his attack follow through downwards.

But I slipped out with the screech of the sword's 
steel as it slid along his blade.

Without the counter to stabilize his center of 
gravity, Norde began falling towards the ground.

Before he could catch his balance...

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text: How'd you like this!
He rolled out of the way!

lines.speaker: Norde
lines.text: You... Grh...

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text: Heh. How'd you like that?

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text: Is it that hard to try to not kill each other?!

I slipped towards Norde again, once again trying to 
use his heavy strikes against him.

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text: Take this!

Shimmering bits of steel rained through the air all 
around, as the sword shattered on impact.

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text: No...

A blade was pointed at me after I was knocked to 
a vulnerable state on the ground.

lines.speaker: Norde
lines.text: Judge?

An awkward silence fell over the scene, but 
Charlotte begrudgingly went through with her 
role here.

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text:
Yeah. It seems pretty definitive to me.

Norde wins.

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text: Dammit...

lines.speaker: Norde
lines.text:
Hmph. A spoiled child, still.

And that ill-fitting weakness for Ivan's child.

lines.speaker: Norde
lines.text: We're done here.
Norde began to turn away.

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text:
To go to the point of fighting and that's all you 
have to say?
Norde stopped.

lines.speaker: Norde
lines.text:
...

It is for the best to end this here.

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text:
You can say whatever you're thinking, you know?

I'm no child anymore.

Norde bit his lip as a silence settled in.

But then he turned back towards me.

lines.speaker: Norde
lines.text: You killed Ivan.

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text: What?! That's complete unfair to claim-

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text:
What?! You can't just say that! We don't even 
know if-

Norde shot a look at Charlotte that stopped her 
words in their tracks.

He turned back towards Pup.

lines.speaker: Norde
lines.text:
Ivan Baranov was a great man.

A protector, a liberator... A hero.

A man whose very presence could raise the 
downtrodden to heights they could've never 
dreamed of.
He was a hero beyond the platitudes of those who 
could only wish for better.

He was someone who had the strength to change 
the world in front of him.

lines.speaker: Norde
lines.text: But you, his child... are not.

lines.speaker: Norde
lines.text:
You are but a pup he kept at his side. One he was 
ever vigilant with regards to.

An anchor that dimmed that splendor of his 
potential.

lines.speaker: Norde
lines.text: I've watched him.

lines.speaker: Norde
lines.text:
Before your time. And after he showed up with 
you to the Crows that day.

For every miracle he could've created, you were 
there to pull him back down into the depths.

An anchor that he dragged through the dirt... until 
the end.

lines.speaker: Norde
lines.text: You are no hero.

lines.speaker: Norde
lines.text:
I have seen a true hero. And now I have seen one 
fall.

You are no hero.

And you never will be.
Norde dropped his weapon and turned to leave.

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text:
What was that?!

How dare you try and lay that sort of blame on 
Pup?!
He started walking away.

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text:
Get back here!

Apologize or... or...

Or I'll give the victory to Pup!
Norde stopped and turned back partially.

lines.speaker: Norde
lines.text: Would you rather I lie?

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text: (So he said it.)

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text: Urgh...
I raised myself to my feet.

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text: Are you going to just let him say those vile lines?

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text: I am... no child anymore.

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text:
Though I guess I always had a feeling it was 
something like that.

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text: You shouldn't put up with that treatment.

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text:
I did ask for it.

(And... I can't even bring myself to disagree, to be 
honest.)

Norde.

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text:
If that's what you think, then that's what you 
think.

I've known you long enough to know you're being 
sincere, and I can't say I've ever changed your 
mind before.
But...

But someone has changed your mind before... 

My father.

lines.speaker: Norde
lines.text: What...?

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text:
It just means I need to be strong, right?

Strong enough that you'll have no choice to 
acknowledge it.

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text: Just like you did with my father.
Norde turned back to walk away again.

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text: Urk!

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text: Hey!

I fell to a knee, but Charlotte helped catch me 
before I fell entirely.

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text:
What is wrong with you? That was completely 
unacceptable.

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text:
He's right... I'm not my father. I'm honestly not 
even close to him.

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text:
But I still want to be strong. To find my strength.

Then, one day...

One day Norde will...
My fist tightened with determination.

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text:
And how are you going to do that if all the training 
equipment is broken?

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text: Ha... hahaha... ha...

title: SP: Norde x Satia B - Begining

lines.speaker: Satia
lines.text: Norde, there you are.

lines.speaker: Satia
lines.text: Would you have a moment?
The scribbling of a pen suddenly stopped.

lines.speaker: Norde
lines.text:
...

I am... very busy.

lines.speaker: Norde
lines.text: I suppose a few minutes can be spared.

lines.speaker: Satia
lines.text:
Excellent.

Now... Have you come to a decision
about armor repairs?

lines.speaker: Norde
lines.text: *Sigh*... This again?

lines.speaker: Norde
lines.text:
As I've said before, we need to review our 
inventory before making any decision on the topic.

lines.speaker: Satia
lines.text:
And it would be awfully irresponsible for it to be 
left unfinished after all this time.

lines.speaker: Norde
lines.text:
Yes, but not via myself. It was not my assignment.

The pup was thrown that bone.

lines.speaker: Satia
lines.text: But... I never heard anything from Pup?

lines.speaker: Norde
lines.text: Is this truly a question for me anymore?
Norde started to pick up his feather pen again.

lines.speaker: Satia
lines.text:
...

Come to think of it, I haven't seen Pup around 
lately?

Like every time we see each other, there's some 
hurry to end it.

lines.speaker: Norde
lines.text:
You say that as if it is new.

The pup avoiding your... encumbering disposition 
is not a new phenomenon.

lines.speaker: Satia
lines.text:
So the chats with you are so plentiful then?

With your own overwhelming mirth and friendly 
disposition?

lines.speaker: Satia
lines.text: It seems WE are being avoided.

lines.speaker: Satia
lines.text:
And I can't really blame anyone but us after the 
late night arguments we've had lately.

Remember how much the others have been 
yawning lately?

lines.speaker: Norde
lines.text: A surprising depth of self-awareness... for you.

lines.speaker: Satia
lines.text: Maybe try it for yourself.

lines.speaker: Norde
lines.text:
*Sigh*... Then shall we conclude this more civilly 
this time?

Norde fidgeted with his pen as he wrote and 
erased thought after thought within his mind.

lines.speaker: Norde
lines.text: We can fix the armor ourselves. Frugally.

lines.speaker: Satia
lines.text:
Imagine how long that'd take... and we're not 
exactly professionals.

lines.speaker: Norde
lines.text:
Our current funds can't afford professional 
craftsmanship.

lines.speaker: Norde
lines.text:
If self repair is not an option, then the only other 
one is to wait until our coffers restore themselves.

lines.speaker: Satia
lines.text:
You know as well as I that the Crows have weaker 
members that could die with subpar equipment.

lines.speaker: Norde
lines.text: And such is the nature of combat...

lines.speaker: Norde
lines.text:
Perhaps some need to learn how to parry instead 
of relying on armor so heavily?

lines.speaker: Satia
lines.text: You... You're impossible.

With a flip of her hair and a visually evident attempt 
to restrain her anger, Satia walked out of the tent.

lines.speaker: Satia
lines.text:
Damn... ugh... Stupid seedy parts of these damn 
towns.

As she attempted to dry her shoe, a noise peeked 
her interest from a nearby tavern of questionable 
repute.

lines.speaker: Drunk Noble
lines.text: Why does... everything keep spinning?

With barely a warning, the man was slumped into 
the dirt of the street below.

A clink and a clank reverberated in Satia's ears as a 
hefty coin pouch fell to the ground beside the 
man.
Satia poked at the man.

lines.speaker: Satia
lines.text:
You... awake? Alive?

...
Her eyes traveled to the coin pouch again.

lines.speaker: Satia
lines.text: Goddess forgive me.

Satia grabbed the bag and tried to walk away.

But a voice quickly came from her starting place.
...a thief?!

lines.speaker: Rowan
lines.text:
No, my dear man. I say much the
opposite.

lines.speaker: Constable
lines.text:
Let me get this straight...

You’re saying your manservant told your 
bodyguard– this woman -you went to the wrong 
tavern.
And when she saw that man lying face down, she 
thought he was you?

lines.speaker: Rowan
lines.text:
With such, mon ami, the final curtain falls on my 
dire tale of mistaken identities and 
grand incompetence.

lines.speaker: Constable
lines.text:
...

So why'd she pick up the coin purse?

lines.speaker: Rowan
lines.text:
Why, she was merely doing her due diligence to 
verify if I had been robbed!

You are aware of the town district in question?

lines.speaker: Constable
lines.text:
Yeah, I guess ya got a point... uh... What was your 
name again?

lines.speaker: Rowan
lines.text: It is as I said before. I am Duke Malos!
Rowan flashed his heirloom towards the man.

lines.speaker: Rowan
lines.text:
Head of the grand Malos estate, poet 
extraordinaire, orchestrator of the…

lines.speaker: Constable
lines.text:
Yes, yes. I don’t need to hear all of that again.

Damn nobles and their endless titles…

lines.speaker: Rowan
lines.text:
What was that, good sir? I’m afraid you’ll have to 
speak up.

lines.speaker: Constable
lines.text: Er… it was nothing, Duke.
With that, Satia's manacles were unlocked.

lines.speaker: Rowan
lines.text:
Wise decision. I’ll be sure to send a token for your 
kindness once I return to court.

Now come along, Jules. And you’d better believe I’ll 
be docking your pay for a mistake like this.

lines.speaker: Satia
lines.text: Yes... sir...

lines.speaker: Satia
lines.text: That was... something else? Impressive, even.

lines.speaker: Rowan
lines.text: "Duke Malos" will always be here to help.

lines.speaker: Rowan
lines.text:
But, mayhap your gratitude be better serviced 
torwards the puppetmaster?

Rowan directed a nod towards behind Satia, and 
she turned to see Norde before her.

lines.speaker: Satia
lines.text: You mean Norde had...?

Satia turned back, only to find Rowan already 
having disappeared into the crowd.

lines.speaker: Norde
lines.text:
A reckless move. The Nightless Crows thrive on our 
reputation and you just tried to throw that away.

lines.speaker: Satia
lines.text: I know... I know all that, just...

lines.speaker: Norde
lines.text:
And... these towns are not behind execution when 
nobles are involved.

lines.speaker: Satia
lines.text:
We needed funds. Remember the armor situation?

People may die without it.

lines.speaker: Norde
lines.text:
I remember. But this is becoming a trend of 
problematic behavior.

lines.speaker: Norde
lines.text: This has happened before...

lines.speaker: Young Norde
lines.text:
Thank you. I shall use this well crafted blade for a 
worthy cause.

lines.speaker: Blacksmith
lines.text: Not if you don't pay, hero boy.

lines.speaker: Young Norde
lines.text: Ah... right... The agreed upon compensation was...

As Norde reached for his funds, a flicker of flame 
danced around the blacksmith's hand.

lines.speaker: Blacksmith
lines.text:
Argh! Dammit! ...Just... Just leave the money on 
the counter...

The blacksmith hurried to quell the forge's flame 
and Norde paid.

Norde began to leave with his companion, Satia, in 
step behind him.

But she stopped.

And her eyes darted between the busy blacksmith 
and a sword rack near the door.

lines.speaker: Young Norde
lines.text: Are you out of your mind?!

The hushed whisper matched the timing of Satia's 
hands wrapping around a sword's handle.

lines.speaker: Young Satia
lines.text:
No, more like finally screwing it on straight.

I’m sick and tired of slaving away as a helping hand 
for people acting like heroes.

lines.speaker: Young Norde
lines.text: Heroes don’t steal. Common criminals do.

lines.speaker: Young Satia
lines.text:
Oh, get off your high horse. As if none of you even 
care to give me a chance.

You've barely been in the Crows and they're 
already giving a lizard like you a weapon.

lines.speaker: Young Satia
lines.text:
Didn't you want to save others? Come on, "hero". 
Let's go actually save a few other-

lines.speaker: Blacksmith
lines.text: What's going on here?

The blacksmith appeared before the two youths 
standing in the doorway.

His eyebrows lowered as he put two and two 
together.

lines.speaker: Blacksmith
lines.text: I’m afraid I’m going to have to call the-

lines.speaker: Young Norde
lines.text:
We want to buy it.

She... She needs a weapon, too. I forgot to 
mention it before.

lines.speaker: Blacksmith
lines.text: ...Fine.

After another chunk of money was placed in the 
blacksmith's hands, the two exited the shop.

lines.speaker: Young Satia
lines.text:
Norde, I can’t believe you actually… I mean, you 
didn’t have to…

lines.speaker: Young Norde
lines.text:
Not another word. Just make sure you make use of 
it. Make it worth it.

lines.speaker: Young Satia
lines.text: You know... You're not that bad, are you?

lines.speaker: Young Norde
lines.text:
And your half of the cost will come out of your 
food budget.

lines.speaker: Young Satia
lines.text: Ah... There's the lizard boy I know...

lines.speaker: Satia
lines.text:
You know, I still have that sword.

It’s been beaten to hell over the years, but I’ve 
never once thought about discarding it.

lines.speaker: Norde
lines.text: Don't change the subject.

lines.speaker: Norde
lines.text:
The point is that you have a history of reckless 
decisions when easy choices aren't available.

lines.speaker: Satia
lines.text:
But doesn’t that story prove... ‘it only matters if 
your heart is in the right place?’

lines.speaker: Norde
lines.text:
Maybe. But we were young and dumb then, Satia. 
Things are rarely so simple.

lines.speaker: Norde
lines.text:
Ivan taught us better than this. And
 now that he's gone...

lines.speaker: Satia
lines.text:
Then what do you propose to solve the armor 
issue?

lines.speaker: Norde
lines.text: I don't know. But not this...

lines.speaker: Satia
lines.text: Oh, your story.

lines.speaker: Norde
lines.text: I said "no stealing".

lines.speaker: Satia
lines.text: Not that part. The part how we paid for it before.

lines.speaker: Norde
lines.text: Taking it out of our... food budget?

lines.speaker: Satia
lines.text:
Yeah, but we could do it from our two payrolls in 
general.

lines.speaker: Norde
lines.text: That'd only work partially.

lines.speaker: Satia
lines.text:
Enough to cover for the important armor repairs? 
To cover what we can't cover in the normal 
budget?

lines.speaker: Norde
lines.text:
You do know, one of these days I may not always 
be around to bail you out anymore.

lines.speaker: Satia
lines.text:
For what it’s worth, Norde, I hope that day never 
comes.

lines.speaker: Norde
lines.text: *Sigh*...

lines.speaker: Norde
lines.text: You're not the only one.

lines.speaker: Noble
lines.text: Ah, I don't believe one word of-
Rowan pulled in Tatiana for a kiss.
*Smooch*...!

lines.speaker: Tatiana
lines.text: O- Oh... my...

lines.speaker: Rowan
lines.text:
For you kind lady of mysterious allure, I would give 
my soul.

lines.speaker: Tatiana
lines.text: Y- You flatter me... dear stranger.

lines.speaker: Rowan
lines.text:
Shall we run atop the wind together? We shall buy 
a palace and live happily ever after!

lines.speaker: Tatiana
lines.text:
Sounds... enticing. How about you go rent a 
wagon for our escapades?

lines.speaker: Rowan
lines.text: I will not let you down, my love!

Tatiana turned back to the noble as Rowan bolted 
off.

lines.speaker: Noble
lines.text: I- I... even my wife doesn't...

Rowan spun around the corner to whisk himself out 
of sight.

lines.speaker: Rowan
lines.text: Hmm...
He raised his hands to his lips.

lines.speaker: Rowan
lines.text: That kiss was... it felt weird this time...?

Rowan peeked around the corner to see Tatiana 
being handed a bag of money and smiling.

lines.speaker: Rowan
lines.text:
That smile... that wicked smile... why does it 
torture my heart to see?

lines.speaker: Rowan
lines.text: Hmph! Keep it professional! I must!

lines.speaker: Rowan
lines.text: ...or maybe...?

Shaking out his pause, Rowan strode to gain the 
commission of a wagon.

lines.speaker: Tatiana
lines.text: Rowan!

She had turned a corner, entering Rowan's vision, 
while half sprinting.

lines.speaker: Rowan
lines.text: Of course, my lady~
The wagon started moving and Tatiana jumped on.

lines.speaker: Noble
lines.text: You! That’s the witch! The liar! The wench!

He trailed after it, not able to catch it but still 
within speaking distance.

lines.speaker: Tatiana
lines.text: I am sorry, have we met before?

lines.speaker: Noble
lines.text: You..!
Guards surrounded the noble.

lines.speaker: Noble
lines.text: N- No! It was her doing! I... I didn't...!

lines.speaker: Tatiana
lines.text: You see that guy's face when the guard's got him?

lines.speaker: Tatiana
lines.text:
"Oh no! I had consequences to my actions! Buah 
buah buah!"

lines.speaker: Rowan
lines.text:
What a magnanimous portrayal, despite the "buah" 
brigade at the end.

lines.speaker: Rowan
lines.text: It feels almost... professional.

lines.speaker: Tatiana
lines.text: Oh, shut up you.

lines.speaker: Tatiana
lines.text: Guy was such a sore loser, in the end.

lines.speaker: Tatiana
lines.text:
Imagine being so incompetent that you need to 
resort to swindling children just to "win".

lines.speaker: Rowan
lines.text: Indeed...

lines.speaker: Tatiana
lines.text:
The hammer of justice hits hard, though. Like that 
guy exploiting widows from before.

lines.speaker: Rowan
lines.text: Mhm... clean windows... right...

lines.speaker: Tatiana
lines.text: "Windows"...? You alright?

lines.speaker: Rowan
lines.text: Ah... yes... I am...
The wagon stopped as it reached it's destination.

lines.speaker: Rowan
lines.text:
Or... uh... I was thinking of the smiling faces of the 
orphans when they hear of our deeds.

lines.speaker: Tatiana
lines.text:
Right. It's the kids we're doing this for. They make 
it all worth it.

Having arrived in the poor sector of the town, 
Tatiana jumped off from the wagon.

lines.speaker: Rowan
lines.text:
Love...? Love has never been this... And alas, 
professionality is key here.

Rowan turned his head to see Tatiana discreetly 
distributing the money to orphans that were 
scammed.
She soon returned to the wagon's side.

lines.speaker: Tatiana
lines.text: Something up?

lines.speaker: Rowan
lines.text:
I was just admiring how beloved the professionalism 
of our process has become.

lines.speaker: Tatiana
lines.text: Well, yeah, we did do it all in secret.
Tatiana climbed onto the wagon again.

lines.speaker: Tatiana
lines.text:
It is a bit sad to not do any of this out in the open, 
though.

lines.speaker: Tatiana
lines.text:
Maybe we can bring back the Armored Bandit for 
another round of heroism?

It's gotta have been long enough.

lines.speaker: Rowan
lines.text: A... thought to consider.
The wagon began moving again...

lines.speaker: Rowan
lines.text:
........................!

Ah... I cannot just roam about these thoughts and 
fantasies anymore...!

lines.speaker: Rowan
lines.text: There is something I must attempt.
Rowan turned to a confused Tatiana.

lines.speaker: Tatiana
lines.text: What? What was it you just said?

lines.speaker: Rowan
lines.text:
Oh, sweet green tulip. Whose face covered in iron 
hides a beauty no man has seen.

lines.speaker: Rowan
lines.text: My love blossoms for thee, my dearest Tatiana!

lines.speaker: Tatiana
lines.text: Is this... the routine? Practice?

lines.speaker: Tatiana
lines.text: Aren't you supposed to be more aggressive with it?

lines.speaker: Rowan
lines.text: What?

lines.speaker: Tatiana
lines.text: *Clears throat*...

lines.speaker: Tatiana
lines.text:
You're supposed to... give it a little "oomph"! You 
gotta sell that love shit.

lines.speaker: Rowan
lines.text: Then... you are asking me to be more aggressive?

lines.speaker: Tatiana
lines.text: Y- Yeah!

*Thump*

Rowan leaned in with his hand on a box on the 
wagon. His other hand placed itself on Tatiana's 
cheek.
His head slowly... slowly approached.

Tatiana's heart skipped a beat, and...

Their lips touched.

...........

lines.speaker: Tatiana
lines.text:
Y- Yeah... like... like that...

That... T- That'd sell it, for sure...

lines.speaker: Rowan
lines.text: That was no act, my budding flower.

Rowan had not moved. The two were inches from 
one another.

lines.speaker: Rowan
lines.text:
I can detail your enthralling nature, should you 
want.

lines.speaker: Rowan
lines.text: Another step in the grandeur of the hunt~

lines.speaker: Tatiana
lines.text: Eh...ah...EH?!

lines.speaker: Rowan
lines.text: Of course, I can give you time to think.

lines.speaker: Tatiana
lines.text:
But you're like... a prince. A noble. I'm the noble 
boogeyman. The armored bandit...

W- Wouldn't that be... scandalous?!
