She stretched out as she allowed herself to relax.

lines.speaker: Tatiana
lines.text:
Mmm... Ah~

That should take care of those bandits. Hopefully, 
they never steal again.

lines.speaker: Tatiana
lines.text: Another win goes to THE Armored Bandit!

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text: Are you proud of yourself?

Appearing from around a corner, Elliot had 
ambushed Tatiana.

She stepped back in unease, for once cursed by 
the shadows instead of blessed.

lines.speaker: Tatiana
lines.text: ...Pretty much, yeah.

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text: Do you think you could do better?

lines.speaker: Tatiana
lines.text:
Yeah, maybe I could've punched them both in one 
motion. Not like they were strong.

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text: That isn't... quite what I meant.

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text:
You have powers, powers that can be used for 
good, and yet you use them recklessly.

lines.speaker: Tatiana
lines.text:
Heh? Are you saying I should've let them steal from 
an old lady?

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text:
No. More that... sneaking around and ambushing 
them... is uncouth.

Rather than relying on scare tactics, you should 
fight your enemies head on.

lines.speaker: Tatiana
lines.text: *Sigh*...
Tatiana started walking past Elliot.

lines.speaker: Tatiana
lines.text:
Very funny.

Lettin' people see my face and identity defeats 
a lot of the purpose of the Armored Bandit.

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text:
I am not saying that you reveal your identity. I am
just saying to fight honestly.

Tatiana continued, and Elliot followed along as they
exited the area.

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text:
You lurk in the shadows, yet you wear a gallant suit 
of armor.

The clanking of the armor would make it pretty 
obvious to anyone with competent skills of 
detection.
Would it not be better place yourself as example? 
In a setting all can see and learn from? Like a duel.

lines.speaker: Tatiana
lines.text: *Sigh*... where do I even start?

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text:
But you could be... like a knight. An "Armored 
Knight", like the heroes from myths and legends of 
old.

lines.speaker: Tatiana
lines.text:
First of all, 'Armored Knight' doesn't have the same
zing as Armored Bandit.

lines.speaker: Tatiana
lines.text:
Second, it's not like I chose to be the "Armored
Bandit". They named me that way because of how 
I act.
The corrupt nobles were too proud of themselves 
to admit they were defeated by some random 
person they never heard of before.
But because I sneaked and ambushed them, they 
named me the Armored Bandit. I never chose that 
name.

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text:
You still have the opportunity to be more than 
that. An example for people to see and strive 
towards.

lines.speaker: Tatiana
lines.text:
Yeah, well, I'm here to help. Not play games and 
duel shit.

lines.speaker: Tatiana
lines.text:
You underestimate how easy they make it when 
you're hidden. Add to that the fear factor from the 
legend, and it's easy pickings.

lines.speaker: Tatiana
lines.text:
The frightful face of those snub bastards makes the 
job all the sweeter.

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text: Would it hurt to simply try, though?

lines.speaker: Tatiana
lines.text:
Ya think I haven't tried a direct approach before?

Even without the fact that they can call
reinforcements, it can make things worse.

She looked back at Elliot, who seemed doubtful of 
her conclusion.

lines.speaker: Tatiana
lines.text:
...

It was... a small-time noble closing an orphanage
because the building was "too ugly".

lines.speaker: Tatiana
lines.text:
I thought I taught him a lesson, but he was back at
harassing the orphanage a day later.

lines.speaker: Tatiana
lines.text:
This shit doesn't work on noble blood unless you
actually strike fear into their hearts, ya know?

lines.speaker: Tatiana
lines.text:
Besides, what's the problem with all this?

Isn't it good enough that the "Armored Bandit" is
helping people?

Why does it have to be in the middle of the day, or
honor-y and the like?

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text:
Heroes are meant to inspire hope, not fear.

I... used to listen to stories about how the 
Armored Bandit would come and take me away if I 
didn't behave.

lines.speaker: Tatiana
lines.text:
Heh, so you're one of them.

What, you scared of me or somethin'?

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text:
My concern is that you just validate them.

You strike fear into the hearts of your victims... but
you also strike fear into the hearts of those you 
want to help.

lines.speaker: Tatiana
lines.text: Hmm...

lines.speaker: Tatiana
lines.text: BOO!

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text:
...

As I was saying...

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text: Conserving hope is a very fragile endeavor.

lines.speaker: Tatiana
lines.text:
Tsk. Common folk love the Armored Bandit, I'll have 
you know.

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text:
For a time, perhaps.

The nobility is the original source for much of
culture. It trickles down, as it were.

With your actions, it is fertile soil to drive that
belief amongst even common folk.

If, for nobles, you are an uncouth evil thief, so will
the general opinion be in time.

lines.speaker: Tatiana
lines.text: I am NOT a dirty evil thief.

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text: I am not saying you are... but...

lines.speaker: Tatiana
lines.text:
Tsk... Look. If you are not going to offer any REAL
solutions, then I'm not going to hear it.

Fighting in broad daylight would not be as effective,
and way more dangerous.

'Til that changes, just keep your own fears of the 
dark and the boogeymen to yourself.
Tatiana turned on her heel, and she walked away.

As she disappeared into a tent, Elliot was left
standing there.
Elliot stood still, breathing calmly.

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text:
I am not afraid... 

...anymore.

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text: *Clears throat*...

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text:
...and for that reason, I believe that getting 
supplies from the northern town rather than the 
southern town would help our prospects more.
Charlotte paced back and forth as she spoke.

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text: Hmm...

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text: Well, that didn't come out so bad.

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text: Maybe one more time, since no one else is here, yet...

Charlotte spoke in a low volume while moving,
presenting to an imaginary crowd.

She had arrived a bit earlier to the meeting place in
order to practice a bit.

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text: Hm?

lines.speaker: Reagyn
lines.text:
Ah! Apologies, I was told that the meeting was 
going to be at a later time.

lines.speaker: Reagyn
lines.text: Oh...

lines.speaker: Reagyn
lines.text:
*Clears throat*...  
Apologies. I thought I was late. I...
assumed I'd be the first here.

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text:
Ah yeah, I'm just here practicing my oration a bit. 
Can only ever find the time in between stuff 
nowadays.

Reagyn took a seat, took out a bundle of notes, 
and starting to scan over them.

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text: So... how've you been handling it here?

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text:
I know from experience that there's a learning 
curve for working with mercenaries.

Reagyn did a double take, looked at Charlotte, then 
at her notes, and then at Charlotte again.

lines.speaker: Reagyn
lines.text: Oh, ah... you were talking to me?

lines.speaker: Reagyn
lines.text: Hmm... it has been... workable, I guess.
Reagyn returned to her notes immediately after.

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text:
So... the weather... always colder than you would
imagine, am I right?

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text: I never get to wear what I want.

Without looking away from her notes, 
Reagyn responded.

lines.speaker: Reagyn
lines.text: I would recommend wearing an additional layer.

The echoes of the gentle breeze from outside 
filled the room once again.

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text:
...

I guess... 

Mind if I just keep practicing?

lines.speaker: Reagyn
lines.text:
It would give me time to go over the notes I prepared,
so that would be good. Please don't mind me.

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text: *Clears throat*...

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text: Yadda yadda, introductions, introductions...

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text:
As you all know, about 75% of our budget is going
towards weapon repair-

lines.speaker: Reagyn
lines.text: Closer to 78%.

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text: ...I was rounding.

lines.speaker: Reagyn
lines.text: Understood.

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text:
...

About 78% of our budget is going toward weapon 
repairs. However, we only manage to procure 50% 
of the material we need from-

lines.speaker: Reagyn
lines.text: Around 46%.

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text:
...

...We only manage to procure ABOUT 46% of the
materials we need...

Charlotte paused and waited for a correction 
that never came.

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text:
...from the enemies defeated. Therefore we need to get
some iron from nearby-

lines.speaker: Reagyn
lines.text: Plus coal.

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text: Reagyn. You were reading your notes, weren't you?

lines.speaker: Reagyn
lines.text:
It's no problem. I can multi-task to help with your
presentation.

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text: ...but not help with anything fun...
Charlotte said in a low voice.

lines.speaker: Reagyn
lines.text: Hm? Did you say something?

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text: Oh nothing. Just... 'thanks for the help'.

lines.speaker: Reagyn
lines.text:
No need to worry, I'll make sure to not neglect my 
own notes review for the meeting.

lines.speaker: Reagyn
lines.text: Please don't mind it and continue.

lines.speaker: Reagyn
lines.text:
I think you were about to talk about going to a 
nearby mining town.

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text: ...Right.

lines.speaker: Norde
lines.text: ...Good, some people are actually on time.

Charlotte sighed in relief at the sight of another
person.

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text: Oh, thank the goddess...

lines.speaker: Norde
lines.text: Has Pup come by?

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text: No? Are we waiting on that?

lines.speaker: Norde
lines.text: Hmm... Can you give me the cost rundown as we wait?

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text: Sure, I don't mind.

Charlotte gave Norde the rundown, which then 
turned into an actual meeting after a certain person 
did not show up.
Not naming who.

Reagyn paid close attention to what Charlotte was
saying, often referring to her notes before 
switching her attention back to Charlotte.

Norde and Reagyn asked a couple of questions at 
the end, to which Charlotte responded confidently.

Afterward, Norde and the rest of the Crows stood 
up and left, leaving only Reagyn and Charlotte, who 
were cleaning up.

lines.speaker: Reagyn
lines.text: Miss Charlotte... may I speak with you for a moment?

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text: Sure, Reagyn, what's up?

lines.speaker: Reagyn
lines.text:
I just wanted to congratulate you on the 
presentation, it was succinct and to the point.

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text: Aw, thanks.

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text:
I made it so because a certain someone tends to 
doze off if the meeting is too long.

It took me a while to figure it out, so I'm glad you
think it went smoothly.

lines.speaker: Reagyn
lines.text:
I did have... a few points of feedback, if you're open
to it.

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text: Uh... I guess?

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text:
Lay 'em on me.

I'm sure my plans aren't perfectly refined, after all.

lines.speaker: Reagyn
lines.text: Thank you.

With the folder lowered, Reagyn looked Charlotte 
in the eyes.

lines.speaker: Reagyn
lines.text:
First, the village you posed a trade with wants a
resource we lack an abundance of.

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text:
I figured we could shore up that supply by 
bartering as we move.

We have the advantage of not being in one place, 
after all.

lines.speaker: Reagyn
lines.text:
That wasn't mentioned in the presentation. But
understood. I assume it was for brevity.

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text: Something like that.

lines.speaker: Reagyn
lines.text:
There was also the issue of the local village being 
out of the way and through more rough terrain.

That's a cost of both time and general resources.

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text: Well, I assumed...

lines.speaker: Reagyn
lines.text: Assumptions can be fatal to an army, Miss Charlotte.
Charlotte stood there for a second, silent.

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text:
Uh... wait. You're acting like there's some crazy
assumption in there.

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text:
It's a forageable, too. If we forage as we move, 
then our supply is greater than a village's demand.

lines.speaker: Reagyn
lines.text: A valid point.

lines.speaker: Reagyn
lines.text:
But... It'd be hard to imagine the troops agreeing 
to such given recent developments and the current 
mood.
Might it be a bit demeaning to be asked to 
forage each day as they move?

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text: They're mercenaries, they already-

lines.speaker: Reagyn
lines.text:
I think it is possible though, if someone can 
convince them. I can make an attempt.

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text:
Sure, you do that. Go talk to the... mercenary
"troops"...
Charlotte turned, exiting the tent.

lines.speaker: Reagyn
lines.text: Second...

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text: Wonderful, you had more.

lines.speaker: Reagyn
lines.text:
I recall some expedition research that concluded 
local coal deposits were low quality here.

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text:
Weren't you the one that brought up coal in 
the first place?

lines.speaker: Reagyn
lines.text:
I just offered the info that it was in low supply, not
a specific suggestion on how to acquire it.

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text: Well, then we can use green magic to refine it.

lines.speaker: Reagyn
lines.text:
Isn't substance refinement a very intricate process 
for magi?

Will the magic users here have the patience for 
that? They're not nobles, but mercenaries.

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text: Won't know until you try.

lines.speaker: Reagyn
lines.text:
A bit speculative, but I suppose we can put a pin in
it.

Thirdly-

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text: Hey.
Charlotte stopped walking and turned to Reagyn.

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text:
You know, if I didn't know better, I'd say you were
trying to insult me.

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text: Do I know better?

lines.speaker: Reagyn
lines.text:
I... What? Why would I ever do that? Lockhart is a
valued ally of the Kingdom, and you are of a 
respected station there.

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text:
...

You know it's getting really hard to tell if you're
being condescending or not.

lines.speaker: Reagyn
lines.text:
No, is this not the norm for a lady in your place?

Lockhart is known for being business first, so-

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text: Eh? Are you insulting my people now?

lines.speaker: Reagyn
lines.text: I-

lines.speaker: Reagyn
lines.text:
...

Apologies, that was not my intent. I harbor no ill-
intent in my reference to Lockhart.

lines.speaker: Reagyn
lines.text:
I... simply saw the need to correct some 
fundamental mistakes. For your position and 
responsibilities-

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text: Okay, that's it-

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text: H- Hey! Sorry that I'm late.

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text:
I was training, then ate before coming...

Then I felt sleepy, and...

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text: Oh, sorry, Charlotte...

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text:
I didn't realize you were in the middle of one of 
your passionate, captivating speeches.

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text:
...

Hmph.

Charlotte bumped into me a little as she stormed 
out of the area and into another tent.

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text: Was I... Was I THAT late?

lines.speaker: Reagyn
lines.text:
*Sigh*...

I only meant that her position like required many
advisers that did the same as I did.

Reagyn started to step in the opposite direction 
that Charlotte went.

lines.speaker: Reagyn
lines.text: Yes, yes you were THAT late.
And left.

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text: I... Damn.

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text: I always liked Charlotte's speeches.

lines.speaker: Tatiana
lines.text:
...

Why am I paired up with you?

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text:
I would say 'By the Goddess's will'.... 
but... Norde made the list.

lines.speaker: Tatiana
lines.text:
Did you do something to piss Norde or the Goddess 
off?

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text:
...

Perhaps that is a question better pressed in 
your direction.

lines.speaker: Tatiana
lines.text: Oi. I was the one to ask.

lines.speaker: Shopkeep
lines.text:
*Clears throat*

... 

Ehh... is that everything you are
going to get?

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text:
Apologies for my associate. I do not believe she
intended to scare you.

lines.speaker: Tatiana
lines.text:
Oi. You started it. You were too picky when 
choosing the vegetables.

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text: *Sigh*... Yes. That will be everything.

lines.speaker: Shopkeep
lines.text: Well... it's going to be...

A hefty price was uttered out of the shopkeeper's
mouth.

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text:
That seems... a bit much for just a bunch of
vegetables.

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text: If it was because of my companion. She is sorry.

lines.speaker: Tatiana
lines.text: Oi.

lines.speaker: Shopkeep
lines.text: Oh! No no no... it's actually because of...

The shopkeeper lowered her voice and pulled in 
Elliot and Tatiana a bit.

lines.speaker: Shopkeep
lines.text:
The local lord increased the taxes... again... making
breaking even harsher and harsher.

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text:
The lord must be putting it to good use, right? Or
maybe the land was struck by a natural disaster
recently?

lines.speaker: Shopkeep
lines.text:
Nah, not any famine or natural disasters. I can't say
I've seen any new public works projects start 
either. Just more and more taxes.
Don't know a soul that isn't struggling to get by
despite this having been a well off town since I was 
a lass.

lines.speaker: Tatiana
lines.text: Hmph. Sounds like typical noble behavior to me.

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text: Hmm...

As the two paid and then walked away from the 
stall, they glanced at one another.

The two turned their backs to each other, 
parting ways.

lines.speaker: Noble
lines.text:
12001, 12002, 12003, 12004...

...and 12005 gold pieces from those poor and dirty
peasants.

lines.speaker: Noble
lines.text:
Ugh... I really must wash my hands, though. Who 
knows what blight the poor put on these coins 
before relenting them...
Maids! Maids! Come here and wash my hands!

Soon after, a group of maids appeared from behind 
a very decorated door.

The leader of the maids carried a small sun-shaped
necklace around her neck.
The maids began to wash the hands of their lord.

All the while, the noble ogled his money, waiting 
for it to be cleansed of the "poverty odor" so he 
could, once again, caress it with all his attention.

lines.speaker: Head Maid
lines.text:
...S- Sir...

One of the goddess's teachings says...

"Those who only seek the shine of the coin, shall 
lose the light of the sun, cursed to live in the 
moon's shadow."

lines.speaker: Noble
lines.text:
Pft! You suggest this coin is not mine to do as I 
wish?

I demand it because I have need of it. I deserve it.
He relaxed back in his chair.

lines.speaker: Noble
lines.text:
Why, I would lose sleep without them! How would 
I be able to afford my wine? Or luxurious clothes?

How can an economy run without the money 
flowing to the providers, after all?

It would be a humanitarian crisis, as well! Are you
saying I should die of thirst!?

Or how about my horses, cows, and exotic birds? 
Would you rather I kill the animals?!

The head maid, with a shocked expression, took a 
step back and was at a loss for words

lines.speaker: Noble
lines.text:
The alternative would be... Ugh... The poor do not 
make use of the coin.

I must make the world turn, woman.

lines.speaker: Head Maid
lines.text:
I am just offering the teaching of the Goddess for 
your soul's salvation.

But I see you will have a wonderful time in this life.

Now... if you excuse me, sir. We will take our leave.

The maids funneled into the same candlelit 
hallway that they came from.
*Thump*
*Thump*

lines.speaker: Noble
lines.text: Hm? What were those sounds?

As the noble opened the door to his estate, two of 
his guards laid flat on the floor, unconscious.

lines.speaker: Noble
lines.text: There is no time for a nap. Wake up!

The noble tapped the guards with his feet, but 
they did not respond.

lines.speaker: Noble
lines.text: N- Now is not... Come on... I told you to wake up!

The noble's tap became a kick, but the guards 
still did not wake up.

With the moon shining over the patio, a lone figure
stood opposite to the noble.
The armored figure reflecting the light of the-

lines.speaker: Noble
lines.text: Guards! Guards! We are under attack!

The noble ran away from the door and shouted 
into his enormously wealthy mansion...

But all he could hear were the echoes of his 
shouts.

lines.speaker: Noble
lines.text: G- Guards...?

The deeper he went into his mansion, the more 
eerily quiet and darker it felt.

lines.speaker: Noble
lines.text: M- Maids...!?

The hallways that were normally adorned with
candlelight were dark and devoid of life.

lines.speaker: Noble
lines.text: Anyone...?

From the corner of his eyes, the noble could see a
long-haired, blonde woman, whose hair reflected 
the moonlight that shone through the window.

lines.speaker: Noble
lines.text: Wait can you tell me-

But as soon as the noble approached her, 
she vanished.

lines.speaker: Noble
lines.text: W- What is happening?!

The noble continued to walk through his mansion,
looking for any sign of light.

It was then that he saw a maid running into a lit 
room and closed the door immediately after.

lines.speaker: Noble
lines.text: Open up! It is your lord!

A sliding peephole smaller door opened within the
smaller door.

lines.speaker: Head Maid
lines.text:
I am afraid we cannot do that, sir.

You have been tainted by the shadow of the 
moon. Of Zened!

Your avarice has cursed your domain and if we 
don't act, we will too shall suffer the 
consequences!

lines.speaker: Noble
lines.text:
Shadow of the moon!? What sort of nonsense are 
you spouting?

lines.speaker: Head Maid
lines.text:
I tried to warn you, sir! Your incessant seek for
wealth at the cost of others has doomed your oath 
to the Goddess!

She raised her hand, showing an intricately sun-
decorated lit candle aggressively pointing at the 
noble 
And waiving it as if trying to scare a wild animal.

lines.speaker: Head Maid
lines.text: May the light of the sun purify you!

lines.speaker: Noble
lines.text: Open up, or I will kick the door down. Myself!

With those words, she slammed the sliding smaller 
door shut, in the noble's nose.

lines.speaker: Noble
lines.text:
W- When all of this is d- done, you are all f- fired
and-

The noble continued walking in his 
empty dead mansion.

Whatever life he could find were unconscious 
guards, or maids held up in a room with candles.

lines.speaker: Noble
lines.text: ...Maybe... if I lit a candle... I'll be safe... right?

With a flick of a match, the noble rose the lit candle
upwards.

lines.speaker: Noble
lines.text: See! I am not cursed by Zened!
*Swoosh*

Those who only seek the shine of the coin shall 
lose the light of the sun, cursed to live in the 
moon's shadow.

A feminine but stern voice echoed through the 
empty mansion, ringing the noble's ears 
multiple times.

Monsters shall look to kill you to steal your gold.
People, whom you trust, will backstab you.

You shall forever live in fear, as long as you seek 
the light of the coin.

lines.speaker: Noble
lines.text: B- But... what can I do!? Is it too late to change?
The voice did not answer.

Tatiana was waiting outside, looking on with a 
menacing expression.

Still bothered by their previous interactions, Elliot's
words echoed in her mind about trying to be more
gallant-like.

lines.speaker: Tatiana
lines.text:
I took care of all the guards. I can go for the noble
when he tries to flee.

Surely enough, the noble exited his mansion with a 
sack full of gold and valuables.

As Tatiana was preparing her speech, the noble 
dropped all his money to the ground in front of 
Tatiana.

lines.speaker: Noble
lines.text:
I am sorry! Please don't curse me by the shadow of 
the moon! I can change!

The noble desperately crawled towards her as 
though seeking HER help.

lines.speaker: Tatiana
lines.text: The shadow... of the... what?

lines.speaker: Noble
lines.text:
Here! Have all the gold I have accumulated! Surely 
this will make the Goddess forgive me!

lines.speaker: Tatiana
lines.text: Uhh... sure... and...  *Clears throat* ...

lines.speaker: Tatiana
lines.text:
I hope you have learned your lesson foul doer... 
err... Don't ever be greedy again, or I will come 
back!

lines.speaker: Noble
lines.text:
I have learned my lesson! Please, give me the light 
of the sun back!

lines.speaker: Tatiana
lines.text:
The light of the...? 

Err... give away the money to the needy before 
the sunrise and your curse will disappear...?

lines.speaker: Noble
lines.text:
I will do so! Thank you so much for a second 
chance!

lines.speaker: Tatiana
lines.text: That was... easier than expected.

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text: Agreed.

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text:
Without the guards and with your imposing 
armored figure, the legend felt way more impactful.
Elliot stepped from the shadows of the mansion.

lines.speaker: Tatiana
lines.text: Legend...? Wait, you had a hand in all of this?

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text:
It seems we struck at the same time.

I used the teachings of the Goddess, about how 
evil doers' light, like candle lights, get snuffed out 
due to Zened's, the moon's, influence.
Elliot raised an arrow along with a bow.

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text:
I sneaked in and snuffed out all the candles.

Every time the noble tried to light a candle, I just
fired an arrow and snuffed it out from a distance.

lines.speaker: Tatiana
lines.text:
Sneaking around? Didn't you tell me not to do 
that?

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text:
Well... I tried do... something else instead. 

At first, at least.

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text:
Bless the maids, but they did not pick up on my 
plan.

lines.speaker: Tatiana
lines.text: Hmph. So you used my approach.

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text:
It was more a patchwork of my own intent
and your approach, in a sense. 

And it... may have worked better than I even 
anticipated my original plan to.

lines.speaker: Tatiana
lines.text: Haha...

lines.speaker: Tatiana
lines.text: Ah... well...

lines.speaker: Tatiana
lines.text:
I guess just standing in front of the enemy can also 
be intimidating in its own right.

lines.speaker: Tatiana
lines.text:
Especially if you got a heroic reputation like you 
keep gawking about.
The two turned towards each other.

title: SP-Atticus x Tatiana C - New Event

lines.speaker: Crow
lines.text: *Pant*...  *pant*...

lines.speaker: Atticus
lines.text:
Come now, is that all? I can see why I was asked to
help conduct combat training.

lines.speaker: Crow
lines.text:
*Pant*... Knew you were some kinda old 
legend but...

I thought time would have made you easier to take 
on.

The Nightless Crow, nursing his wrist, leaned over 
to pick up his disarmed blade.

lines.speaker: Another Crow
lines.text: All that rock really doesn't slow you down at all?

lines.speaker: Atticus
lines.text:
Best never to judge from appearances. That goes 
for everyday life and on the battlefield.
As he said so, he sheathed his own weapon.

lines.speaker: Atticus
lines.text:
Hmm... Now. how about you lot train amongst
yourselves for a bit?

Think about your loss here and reflect on how 
to improve through that training.

lines.speaker: Atticus
lines.text:
As this was a pair exercise. I suggest each of you 
perform reps until you've got it down to instinct.

lines.speaker: Crow
lines.text: R- Right.

All the Crows stood up straighter than before, 
like they were struck with a sense of authority 
they weren't used to.

lines.speaker: Another Crow
lines.text: Hey, you want to pair with me?

lines.speaker: Crow
lines.text:
Oh thank the Goddess. That'd be easier than the 
old guy.

lines.speaker: Another Crow
lines.text: Pft. We'll see about that.

lines.speaker: Atticus
lines.text: Haha...

The Crows all started to pair up to work on the 
lessons Atticus had left with them.

Seeing enough 'defeat' in their eyes to motivate 
them, Atticus stepped aside.

With a slow and controlled motion, he sat down to 
watch over the group. 

He moved as though one could feel a creaking 
sensation with each inch he lowered.

As he did, he noticed someone watching him out 
of the corner of his eye.

lines.speaker: Tatiana
lines.text: Hmm...

Tatiana tilted her head as she saw to the 
maintenance of her own gear, looking on as 
Atticus lifted his stone arm towards his lap.

Her motion stopped for a second, but after a 
moment of consideration, she turned towards him.

lines.speaker: Tatiana
lines.text: ...Hey, mind if I join you?

With a creak, Atticus turned his head towards the
einlyn youth.

lines.speaker: Atticus
lines.text:
Why, hello young miss.

Yes, it'd be no trouble to talk.
Tatiana nodded and causally made her way over.

lines.speaker: Atticus
lines.text:
It was... Tatiana, correct? You've made a name for
yourself around the camp, from what I've heard.

lines.speaker: Tatiana
lines.text:
Good. Means I don't need to introduce myself 
then, and saves us both some time!

She stepped across Atticus's vision and took
a seat on a nearby stump.

lines.speaker: Tatiana
lines.text: Kinda surprised about the whole...
She motioned towards Atticus's stone body.

lines.speaker: Tatiana
lines.text:
Thought that was just part of the stories to claim 
how tough you were.

Not that... you actually were made of the stuff.

lines.speaker: Atticus
lines.text:
A mix of both, I'd imagine.

Most tales about me pre-date this.
He let out a dry chuckle.

A silence set in, with Tatiana sneaking looks at
Atticus, as though she wanted to say something.

lines.speaker: Tatiana
lines.text:
So... Those nobles and Covenant folk...

They pay you well, yeah?

Like... enough to make working with them as 
somethin' you can swallow?

lines.speaker: Atticus
lines.text:
You may want to be more specific on your 
meaning.

I'm afraid you're catching this old man off-guard.

lines.speaker: Tatiana
lines.text:
Oh, come on, you know what I mean.

You've dealt with them directly. How they treat 
non-homlyns and anyone without a golden pacifier.

lines.speaker: Atticus
lines.text:
Hmm... if you must know. Yes, they pay well.

Enough so that it'd have been irresponsible for me 
to not have taken this position.

lines.speaker: Tatiana
lines.text:
Okay, so it WAS a matter of money.

Guess that would make sense, at least. Lots of 
people have their price, after all.

lines.speaker: Atticus
lines.text: Hmm...
Atticus slowly raised up a finger.

lines.speaker: Atticus
lines.text:
No care for the "why"? Why it would have been
"irresponsible" to not have taken the job?

lines.speaker: Atticus
lines.text:
Though... thinking entirely in terms of coin...?
That would indeed be a very 'noble' perspective.

lines.speaker: Tatiana
lines.text: I... was getting to that.

lines.speaker: Tatiana
lines.text:
Y- You'd think an old timer like you would've 
learned some patience.

lines.speaker: Atticus
lines.text: Haha...

Atticus looked on at Tatiana with a considerate and
warm smile.

lines.speaker: Atticus
lines.text: By all means, then.

Tatiana opened her mouth, about to talk but 
clearly caught off guard.

lines.speaker: Tatiana
lines.text:
As... As I was going to say.

I can only assume the money was for something so
important you couldn't turn down the nobles' 
offer?

She looked away, with her face clearly annoyed 
and trying to hide her fluster.

lines.speaker: Tatiana
lines.text: Don't need to treat me like...
She mumbled beyond Atticus's hearing.

But she kept one eye open with it peeking towards
Atticus as though she tried to hold her tongue on
saying anything more.

lines.speaker: Atticus
lines.text: Right you are.

lines.speaker: Atticus
lines.text:
There is rarely a point in life when all paths before
you are appealing in every aspect.

He reached down with his good arm, feeling and
fidgeting with his stone one opposite of it.
His gaze had lost its focus on Tatiana.

lines.speaker: Atticus
lines.text:
One makes choices not for himself.

...

lines.speaker: Atticus
lines.text: A father makes choices not for himself.

His head raised, turning once more to 
the einlyn youth.

lines.speaker: Atticus
lines.text:
A father makes choices for his family's chance to
flourish.

lines.speaker: Tatiana
lines.text: I... well...

lines.speaker: Tatiana
lines.text: ...I see what you mean.

lines.speaker: Atticus
lines.text: To be clear. I am proud of each decision I made.
A silence lingered for a time.

lines.speaker: Tatiana
lines.text:
I guess I can at the very least understand someone 
that can do that.

lines.speaker: Atticus
lines.text:
I'm of the mind that we all will eventually face
choices like that.

I imagine you will in due time... or even already 
have perhaps.

Atticus pushed himself up. His movement was stiff 
as he pulled his right side along with the rest of 
him.
On his two feet, he stretched a little.

lines.speaker: Atticus
lines.text: With that, I must return to my duties.

lines.speaker: Atticus
lines.text:
The mercenaries look like they've been getting a 
handle on that exercise I provided.

lines.speaker: Atticus
lines.text: Unless you had something more for me?

lines.speaker: Tatiana
lines.text:
Ah, well...

Nah. No.

I wouldn't want to keep you here.

If anything I should get going myself.

Tatiana got to her feet as well, scuttling to the 
other side of the stump seat to keep her distance.

lines.speaker: Atticus
lines.text: Hmm...

lines.speaker: Atticus
lines.text: Don't be afraid to have a chat with this old soldier.

lines.speaker: Atticus
lines.text: I'm always willing to make a little time.
The two parted on slightly awkward terms.
Each to their own tasks.

Tatiana made her way to a different part 
of the camp.

lines.speaker: Tatiana
lines.text:
Tsk, guy really went there.

Thought I'd get something out of that...

But...

lines.speaker: Tatiana
lines.text:
*Sigh*... So that's why.

Family, eh?

...

lines.speaker: Tatiana
lines.text:
Yeah, I guess everyone has their price. 
In one way or another.
With the training Crows...

lines.speaker: Crow
lines.text: What'd she want?

lines.speaker: Atticus
lines.text: That Tatiana girl?

lines.speaker: Crow
lines.text:
Yeah. She's not the sort I'd think would talk to
someone hired by the Covenant.

lines.speaker: Atticus
lines.text:
You think so?

Hmm... You know... It reminds me of my how my 
own children were at a point.

lines.speaker: Atticus
lines.text: I think... she's still working it out.

lines.speaker: Crow
lines.text: Working what out?

lines.speaker: Atticus
lines.text: What she wanted to ask me.
I blinked.

lines.speaker: Jakson
lines.text: *Happy bark*!

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text: Dammit...
I blinked rapidly.
My eyes stung from the staring contest.

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text:
Fine. Take the bedding. It's not like I haven't slept
on the ground before.

lines.speaker: Jakson
lines.text: *Happy bark*!

lines.speaker: Norde
lines.text:
A messenger just came by.

They said that the bedding purchase was 
delivered successfully.

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text: Perfect timing, Norde.

lines.speaker: Norde
lines.text:
Mm... It isn't as though I can control when the
messenger arrives.

lines.speaker: Norde
lines.text:
Of what i can control, though... I am surprised by 
the need for more bedding.

lines.speaker: Norde
lines.text:
I could have sworn that the recent supply refresh
purchased enough to suit our current numbers...

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text: Ah... well...

I looked over at Jakson while trying to not let 
Norde notice.

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text: (He never counts Jakson in those, since he's a dog.)

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text:
Mistakes like that are bound to happen every once 
in a while, yeah?

lines.speaker: Norde
lines.text:
Regardless, the bedding needs to be picked up 
from the nearby town.

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text: It's not here?

lines.speaker: Norde
lines.text: Like said, we simply received the delivery message.

lines.speaker: Norde
lines.text:
It was delivered to the store, since we were 
passing this town on our way to our next 
destination.
So...

lines.speaker: Norde
lines.text: It's in your hands now.

With raised hands, I watched on as Norde made a 
bit of a exaggerated "cleaning my hands of this" 
motion.
...and as he walked away with his job done.

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text: Tsk.

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text:
(Why not just send the bedding instead of a 
messenger?)

lines.speaker: Jakson
lines.text: *Confused whine*...?

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text:
Looks like we've got a mission to complete before 
the day's out.

lines.speaker: Jakson
lines.text: *Eager bark*!

After trekking to the nearby town, 
we had procured the admittedly 
mediocre sleeping cot.

lines.speaker: Shopkeep
lines.text:
I know we don't have those normally in stock, 
but... you sure you want a cheap one like that?

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text:
It's okay. It's easy to carry and not too expensive 
to replace if we need to ditch it.

lines.speaker: Shopkeep
lines.text:
...

Should I ask?

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text: Don't worry about it.
Tying it up like a backpack, I lifted it up.
And with that, we started on our way back to camp.

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text: There we go. Let's head back, boy.

lines.speaker: Jakson
lines.text: *Happy pant*

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text:
(While we're here, maybe we should pick up some 
other supplies?)

(Aren't we running low on... uh... running low 
on...)

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text: (What was it again? It was-)

lines.speaker: Jakson
lines.text: *Bark*!

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text: Grk!

Surprised and dazed, I jumped to my feet 
to see a horse and its rider galloping 
away from me.

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text:
Yeah! You run away! You- You..! *Sigh* ...Damn
that asshole. What, was he drunk or something?

I turned, only to see the sleeping cot snapped 
in two and off to my side.
My body slumped down onto the ground.

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text: I'll just...

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text: I'll just sleep here.
Jakson approached me and started to lick my hand.

lines.speaker: Jakson
lines.text: *Confused whine*...?

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text:
I know I said it'd be cheap to replace, but we can't 
do it this soon...

My weary eyes stared at the earth beneath
my buttocks.

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text:
The ground is same ground wherever you go, after 
all?

Why not embrace it for once in my-
A heavy, furry weight plopped down on top of me.

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text:
J- Jakson...?

Hey, boy... please... get off?!

Sort of... hard to breath...

lines.speaker: Jakson
lines.text: *Panting*

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text:
F- Fine! I'll get up and head back to camp! Is that
what you want to hear?

lines.speaker: Jakson
lines.text: *Happy bark*!

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text:
*Sigh*... I wasn't really going to sleep here, you
know?

lines.speaker: Jakson
lines.text: *Confused whine*...?

I gave him a few scratches, and he willingly obliged 
me to allow me to stand once more.

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text: Hah...
I felt the cold of the night on my skin.

Getting to sleep would be a true challenge
for me this time.

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text:
Ugh... 

(What spectacular timing for a cold night 
to hit...)

I couldn't do much else outside of shiver and pull 
the blanket up more.
Or so I thought. The blanket pulled itself back.

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text: (Wait, no... That doesn't make any sense...)

A certain brown fuzzball was sliding himself into the
blanket with me.

Jakson slid all the way to the top. He didn't do 
much else as he settled down into a sleeping 
position.

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text: (That's... warm...)

The blanket didn't fit properly now, but I found
comfort in cuddling up with the teddy bear in front 
of me.
The living, breathing, slobbering teddy bear.
The night wore on and sleep started to take me.
Sleepy thoughts faded as my consciousness left me.
The sounds of existence blending into eternity.
And the darkness of it became absolute.
Every tick of a second carried on and on...

...until a final twinge of the thought burst from 
the rapidly disappearing crack of the mind.

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text:
(Doesn't this mean that the bed I left... for Jakson 
to use... is currently unoccupied...?)

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text: *Sigh*...

lines.speaker: Bandit
lines.text:
Look 'er. We found some loot on that ol' lady, we 
did.

lines.speaker: Another Bandit
lines.text:
We sure did, boss. We just had to... persuade her 
a bit.

He held a knife, waving it about, as the two rushed
from their crime into the shadows of the alleyway.

lines.speaker: Bandit
lines.text: Nothing a good ol' show of force can't beat, right?

lines.speaker: Another Bandit
lines.text: You're right on that boss.

lines.speaker: Echoing Voice
lines.text: A... show of force, you say?

lines.speaker: Bandit
lines.text: Are ya deaf? A show of force, I said.

lines.speaker: Another Bandit
lines.text:
Yeah, a show of force he sa-

Gwahh...!

From the cover of the night, a hulking cluster of 
metal showed itself and quietly rushed the bandit 
into the dark of unconsciousness.

Then, as quickly as it appeared, it dipped into 
another shadow cast by the moon.

lines.speaker: Bandit
lines.text:
Heh..?! Where did...

...

Show er'self, I say!

Ya with da police? What about the deal we 
struck?!

Slowly, the cluster of metal revealed itself to be a
person in plated armor, glistening with the light of
the moon.

lines.speaker: Bandit
lines.text:
You er'... you er' the Armored Bandit, you er'...

You er' a bandit... just like us, you er'!

lines.speaker: Bandit
lines.text:
GHAAA...!

Ya... knocked me out... ya did...

The glistening armored unit punched the bandit 
in his gut hard enough to knock him out for 
several hours.
And with that, it turned its head to the scene.

The armored unit took the stolen goods and put 
the sack over its shoulder.

lines.speaker: Tatiana
lines.text:
I am not like you.

You stole from an old innocent woman to give to
yourself.

While I steal from corrupt nobles and their lackies to
give to the normal folk.
*Knock Knock*
The door opened.

lines.speaker: Old Lady
lines.text: Huh...?

She saw a sight illuminated by the candlelight from
within her home, and it showed a coin purse on 
her front porch.

lines.speaker: Old Lady
lines.text: This... purse...? I thought the bandits had taken it.

lines.speaker: Tatiana
lines.text: There we go...
She stretched out as she allowed herself to relax.

lines.speaker: Tatiana
lines.text:
Mmm... Ah~

That should take care of those bandits. Hopefully, 
they never steal again.

lines.speaker: Tatiana
lines.text: Another win goes to THE Armored Bandit!

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text: Are you proud of yourself?

Appearing from around a corner, Elliot had 
ambushed Tatiana.

She stepped back in unease, for once cursed by 
the shadows instead of blessed.

lines.speaker: Tatiana
lines.text: ...Pretty much, yeah.

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text: Do you think you could do better?

lines.speaker: Tatiana
lines.text:
Yeah, maybe I could've punched them both in one 
motion. Not like they were strong.

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text: That isn't... quite what I meant.

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text:
You have powers, powers that can be used for 
good, and yet you use them recklessly.

lines.speaker: Tatiana
lines.text:
Heh? Are you saying I should've let them steal from 
an old lady?

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text:
No. More that... sneaking around and ambushing 
them... is uncouth.

Rather than relying on scare tactics, you should 
fight your enemies head on.

lines.speaker: Tatiana
lines.text: *Sigh*...
Tatiana started walking past Elliot.

lines.speaker: Tatiana
lines.text:
Very funny.

Lettin' people see my face and identity defeats 
a lot of the purpose of the Armored Bandit.

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text:
I am not saying that you reveal your identity. I am
just saying to fight honestly.

Tatiana continued, and Elliot followed along as they
exited the area.

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text:
You lurk in the shadows, yet you wear a gallant suit 
of armor.

The clanking of the armor would make it pretty 
obvious to anyone with competent skills of 
detection.
Would it not be better place yourself as example? 
In a setting all can see and learn from? Like a duel.

lines.speaker: Tatiana
lines.text: *Sigh*... where do I even start?

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text:
But you could be... like a knight. An "Armored 
Knight", like the heroes from myths and legends of 
old.

lines.speaker: Tatiana
lines.text:
First of all, 'Armored Knight' doesn't have the same
zing as Armored Bandit.

lines.speaker: Tatiana
lines.text:
Second, it's not like I chose to be the "Armored
Bandit". They named me that way because of how 
I act.
The corrupt nobles were too proud of themselves 
to admit they were defeated by some random 
person they never heard of before.
But because I sneaked and ambushed them, they 
named me the Armored Bandit. I never chose that 
name.

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text:
You still have the opportunity to be more than 
that. An example for people to see and strive 
towards.

lines.speaker: Tatiana
lines.text:
Yeah, well, I'm here to help. Not play games and 
duel shit.

lines.speaker: Tatiana
lines.text:
You underestimate how easy they make it when 
you're hidden. Add to that the fear factor from the 
legend, and it's easy pickings.

lines.speaker: Tatiana
lines.text:
The frightful face of those snub bastards makes the 
job all the sweeter.

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text: Would it hurt to simply try, though?

lines.speaker: Tatiana
lines.text:
Ya think I haven't tried a direct approach before?

Even without the fact that they can call
reinforcements, it can make things worse.

She looked back at Elliot, who seemed doubtful of 
her conclusion.

lines.speaker: Tatiana
lines.text:
...

It was... a small-time noble closing an orphanage
because the building was "too ugly".

lines.speaker: Tatiana
lines.text:
I thought I taught him a lesson, but he was back at
harassing the orphanage a day later.

lines.speaker: Tatiana
lines.text:
This shit doesn't work on noble blood unless you
actually strike fear into their hearts, ya know?

lines.speaker: Tatiana
lines.text:
Besides, what's the problem with all this?

Isn't it good enough that the "Armored Bandit" is
helping people?

Why does it have to be in the middle of the day, or
honor-y and the like?

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text:
Heroes are meant to inspire hope, not fear.

I... used to listen to stories about how the 
Armored Bandit would come and take me away if I 
didn't behave.

lines.speaker: Tatiana
lines.text:
Heh, so you're one of them.

What, you scared of me or somethin'?

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text:
My concern is that you just validate them.

You strike fear into the hearts of your victims... but
you also strike fear into the hearts of those you 
want to help.

lines.speaker: Tatiana
lines.text: Hmm...

lines.speaker: Tatiana
lines.text: BOO!

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text:
...

As I was saying...

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text: Conserving hope is a very fragile endeavor.

lines.speaker: Tatiana
lines.text:
Tsk. Common folk love the Armored Bandit, I'll have 
you know.

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text:
For a time, perhaps.

The nobility is the original source for much of
culture. It trickles down, as it were.

With your actions, it is fertile soil to drive that
belief amongst even common folk.

If, for nobles, you are an uncouth evil thief, so will
the general opinion be in time.

lines.speaker: Tatiana
lines.text: I am NOT a dirty evil thief.

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text: I am not saying you are... but...

lines.speaker: Tatiana
lines.text:
Tsk... Look. If you are not going to offer any REAL
solutions, then I'm not going to hear it.

Fighting in broad daylight would not be as effective,
and way more dangerous.

'Til that changes, just keep your own fears of the 
dark and the boogeymen to yourself.
Tatiana turned on her heel, and she walked away.

As she disappeared into a tent, Elliot was left
standing there.
Elliot stood still, breathing calmly.

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text:
I am not afraid... 

...anymore.

title: SP-Kara x Charlotte C - New Event

lines.text:
Kara ate across from Charlotte, her attire and poise
with regality not befitting the simple camp chair.

In contrast, Charlotte had a more shabby look 
about her.

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text:
I honestly didn't expect to see you again after I
graduated from Theodal.

lines.speaker: Kara
lines.text: A good surprise, I hope?

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text:
Yes! You always seemed so unapproachable there, 
but now that I'm an alumni, too...

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text:
...I'm not so easily intimidated. I'd like to get to
know you better.

lines.speaker: Kara
lines.text: Of course. I look forward to it much the same.

Kara took a bite of her hard bread and salted pork,
chewed it, and put it down with a grimace.

lines.speaker: Kara
lines.text: Not exactly mansion food, is it?

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text: Not so much.

lines.speaker: Kara
lines.text:
I know of a delightful location in a nearby city
where we could acquire something better,
if you are so inclined?
My treat?

It was a market day, so they pushed through a 
crowd of townsfolk buying from the farmers.
The city smelled earthy and musky.

lines.speaker: Kara
lines.text:
How are you adapting to life in a mercenary 
company? It must be a far cry from Lockhart's 
luxuries.

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text:
Eh. It's not as bad as what other nobles would 
have you believe.

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text:
In the end, it'll mean that I can lead all sorts, from
knights to mercenaries. No need to pamper me. All 
of you can rely on me.

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text:
Still... 

Yeah, the food has been the worst part.

They turned and hiked up a hill away from 
the river.
A breeze blew fresh air down the cobblestone street.

lines.speaker: Kara
lines.text:
I'm glad to hear the trials of the road haven't been
too harsh. Is it tough for you, being away from
Lockhart?

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text: I've been away from Lockhart before.

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text:
Am I so forgettable that you don't remember where we
met?

lines.speaker: Kara
lines.text: Of course not.

lines.speaker: Kara
lines.text:
Simply... it's one thing to be away from home and 
know you can go back, another to know you 
cannot return.

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text: I'm taking Lockhart back.

lines.speaker: Kara
lines.text: I understand, but...

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text: Oh, we're here.

Kara introduced them to the hostess, asked for 
a table, and they waited off to the side of 
the anteroom.

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text:
Anyway, we've only talked about me so far. How'd 
you end up as the queen's handmaiden?

lines.speaker: Kara
lines.text:
Ah, that is a fanciful telling of it.

I attend court as my family's representative and
occasionally assist her majesty.

I am far from the only one, and I wouldn't classify
those activities as special.
As they talked, they were lead to a table.

After a short pause to peruse their menus - lots of
fish and fresh vegetables - they continued talking.

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text: You're always like this.

lines.speaker: Kara
lines.text: Like what?

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text: Never giving details. Mysterious and aloof.

lines.speaker: Kara
lines.text: I'm neither mysterious nor aloof... merely boring.

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text: Now you're making fun of me.

lines.speaker: Kara
lines.text: What would you have me do, play truth or dare?

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text: Good idea!

lines.speaker: Kara
lines.text: Charlotte...

lines.speaker: Kara
lines.text: Aren't we too old for that?

When their waitress came, Kara ordered sautéed 
trout with squash.

Charlotte asked for a tuna on salad with tomatoes,
peppers, and wild rice.

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text: Are you afraaaaaaaaaaaid?

lines.speaker: Kara
lines.text: Charlotte, do I seem the sort to be influenced like so?

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text: Yes.

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text: Truth or dare?

lines.speaker: Kara
lines.text:
…

Truth.

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text: Who did you have a crush on at Theodal?

lines.speaker: Kara
lines.text:
You're presuming I had a crush during our
schooldays, then?

lines.speaker: Kara
lines.text: *Sigh*...

lines.speaker: Kara
lines.text:
Let's say, hypothetically, you were right.

Do you recall the previous student council 
president? A year ahead of me and had 
curly brown hair.

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text:
Oh... I think I vaguely remember.. We talked a few
times, but we only were in the school together for 
my first year.

lines.speaker: Kara
lines.text:
Truly someone I looked up to and admired. A kind 
soul who had a thoughtful memory.

lines.speaker: Kara
lines.text:
I always wondered if there was more to it, but I don't
think it was mutual even if so.

The waitress brought their food, which distracted 
them both for a bit.

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text: So... you prefer... older partners?

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text: W- What's that look?

lines.speaker: Kara
lines.text: You already took your turn.

lines.speaker: Kara
lines.text: Truth or dare?

Charlotte stabbed a cherry tomato with her fork,
and it squirted tomato juice onto the table.
She hastily wiped it off with her napkin, giggling.

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text: Well, maybe... Truth?

lines.speaker: Kara
lines.text:
How did you feel about Alexei back during our school
days?

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text:
Alexei? You're talking about Rowan when he was...
normal?

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text:
Well, we were only friends, I think? He was a shy 
kid so he was easy to talk to, especially as a fellow 
heir.
...Why ask about him of all things?

lines.speaker: Kara
lines.text:
All in the proper order, my dear Charlotte.

I didn't say "truth" for your next turn yet, 
after all.

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text:
Heh, you... 

Hmm...

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text: Truth or dare?

lines.speaker: Kara
lines.text: Truth.

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text:
How did you and Cainan meet? He must have been
something special to catch your eye.

lines.speaker: Kara
lines.text:
I'm afraid our story is more practical than romantic. I
met him in the course of my duties for her majesty.

Kara delicately sliced a piece of fish off, speared it
with her fork, and stared at it for a moment before
eating it primly.

lines.speaker: Kara
lines.text:
We do pair well and work effectively together. His
Covenant connections are useful to both my family 
and Cartenan.
Likewise, my connections in Cartenan will help him 
as he curtails the misuse of the Oathbreakers.

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text:
So more like an arranged marriage?

Phooey. I'd hoped that you at least could marry for
love. He's how much older than you are?

lines.speaker: Kara
lines.text:
Seventeen years, I believe. 

I don't mind.

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text: Does he treat you well at least?

lines.speaker: Kara
lines.text:
He treats me with respect. And, he is a pretty 
man, isn't he? More than a few women sighed 
when they heard of our engagement.

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text:
I guess that will have to do. I wanted there to be
more.

lines.speaker: Kara
lines.text: A love story for the ages?

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text: Yes! You deserve that!

lines.speaker: Kara
lines.text: And you don't?

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text: I do too!

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text:
Sure, I probably won't get that choice, but its still
fun to think about.

lines.speaker: Kara
lines.text:
To marry for love - one of the few things you could
envy a commoner for.

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text: Oh, if only they knew how hard we had it...

lines.speaker: Kara
lines.text: Indeed, it is but a tragedy.

Self deprecating and joking smiles on their faces, 
they moved to finish their food.

Kara asked for the check, and both of them 
cleaned their plates.

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text:
This feels just like being back in school. I always
appreciated when you invited me out.

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text:
Maybe we have time for a walk, too? Don't really 
feel like I want to head back to camp yet.

lines.speaker: Kara
lines.text:
Do you know the area well enough to have a suggested
destination?

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text: Actually...

She gestured in the direction opposite of the 
camp. Kara nodded and paid for their meal.

They strolled along a ridge that overlooked the city,
river, and surrounding farms.

lines.speaker: Kara
lines.text:
I will say that I am flattered by your interest in my
life since school.

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text:
How could I not be? You always do everything so
effortlessly.

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text:
Even your hair is so sleek, shiny, and... stable!
Nothing like my own's tendency to become a 
wreck.

lines.speaker: Kara
lines.text:
Your affinity for hats might have something to do 
with that.

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text:
Don't scorn my hats! Their style is better suited to
the future leader of a merchant republic than an
ostentatious crown.

Charlotte adjusted her beret and smoothed 
out her hair.

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text:
And don't think I didn't notice you trying to change
the topic from you to me.

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text:
You deserve more praise! Your eyes are so pretty, 
you have such excellent fashion and are so 
effortlessly elegant.

lines.speaker: Kara
lines.text:
Saying as much in such succession makes each 
seem a little less sincere than the last...

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text:
I mean it, though. You're... like everything they say 
I should be to be Lockhart's heir.

lines.speaker: Kara
lines.text:
Do you... wish to discuss that topic? I know it has
caused friction with your sister.

lines.speaker: Kara
lines.text:
Do you... wish to discuss that topic? I know it has
caused friction within your family.

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text:
Ah... well, me not being a lot of people's first 
choice for the next leader isn't exactly a secret...

It'd... only cause trouble to talk about within my
family... even talking to my parents about it was...

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text:
Besides, it's other families that... well... 

Maybe... I shouldn't talk about it here either...

Kara reached to take Charlotte's hand, perhaps to 
pull her closer for a hug, but Charlotte stepped 
back.

lines.speaker: Kara
lines.text: Charlotte, you can talk to me about anything.

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text:
My home is conquered and that shitty wannabe 
fiancé was put in charge of Lockhart. At least 
you've got a decent one to look forward to.
It doesn't matter. This... this conversation doesn't
matter about heirs or whatever, it just needs to-

Charlotte flinched and looked down, hugging 
herself.

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text:
...

I didn't mean to snap at you. I'm sorry.

...

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text:
We should get back.

Before the others figure out we've been 
eating real food, not mercenary rations.

Especially Pup and that dog.

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text:
We should get back.

Before the others figure out we've been 
eating real food, not mercenary rations.

Especially Pup.

lines.speaker: Kara
lines.text:
I'm always available, if you need an ear to listen or a
shoulder to cry on.

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text: Thanks...
Charlotte nodded stiffly and left.

Kara sighed and wandered the city a bit more to 
gather her thoughts.

Eventually, she hunted down Rowan and pulled 
him away from the camp to a nearby location.

lines.speaker: Kara
lines.text: ...and that's how she left.

lines.speaker: Kara
lines.text:
I tried to help, but I'm afraid I pushed her away
instead. You were friends with her in those 
schooldays, so...

lines.speaker: Rowan
lines.text:
I don't know her as well as you think. We were 
friends, but since we met again, she's given me the 
cold shoulder.

lines.speaker: Kara
lines.text: You're still closer to her than I am.

lines.speaker: Rowan
lines.text:
Am I? Was I? I do not recall being idolized during 
that time as you were.

lines.speaker: Rowan
lines.text:
If anything strikes me as a potential way forward...
why not be that idol?

lines.speaker: Kara
lines.text: I have attempted to be a role model for her.

lines.speaker: Rowan
lines.text:
What about a role model for opening up on your
feelings?

lines.speaker: Rowan
lines.text:
I... as an open book that invites others to write 
within myself... see you as, my dear Kara...

lines.speaker: Rowan
lines.text:
Well, even in our schooldays, I don't recall many a
time you talked about yourself candidly.

lines.speaker: Kara
lines.text: Hmm...

lines.speaker: Rowan
lines.text:
Ah, even better yet, to talk on such a level as 
though equals?

Would it be the role of a lifetime for you, my 
dearest upperclassman.

lines.speaker: Kara
lines.text: ...Alexei.

lines.speaker: Rowan
lines.text: Ah, yeah, I'll seal my mouth shut for a time.

lines.speaker: Kara
lines.text: No... just...

lines.speaker: Kara
lines.text: Thank you.

Miming as though his mouth was sealed shut, 
Rowan smiled a sense of relief and to 
communicate his own gratitude.

The two parted to their tasks for the remainder of 
the day.
Rowan with an optimistic skip to his step.
And Kara, with a pensive look of worry on her own.

lines.speaker: Reagyn
lines.text:
Due to our recent skirmish, we are down 27.2% of 
our supply of weapons.

If we want to be ready for our next encounter, we 
will need to supply the camp with 22 kg of iron, 10 
kg copper, 1100 grams of tin, and 60kg of wood...
...by a conservative calculation, at least.

Reagyn stepped further into the tent, flipping 
through the pages of a report.

lines.speaker: Reagyn
lines.text:
Due to the state our weapons are at, I predict that
repairs will take two and a half weeks.

The number of skirmishes we are in outpace that, 
so we will need to rely on the local blacksmiths, or 
expedite the ones in camp.
Reagyn closed the report, and stood tall.

lines.speaker: Reagyn
lines.text: Furthermore, we-

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text: Zzzzz....

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text:
...!

W- What?

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text: *Yawwwnnn*... Morning.

Reagyn took a minute to take a breath and look 
around for the first time after entering the tent.

Expecting a full entourage of people, Reagyn had 
burst in dramatically and started explaining things.
However, the only person in the room was... me.

lines.speaker: Reagyn
lines.text: Pup... are you the only one in the room?

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text: Eh...? Yeah... Why?

lines.speaker: Reagyn
lines.text:
*Sigh*... I guess I can't really expect much outside
Her Majesty's courts...

I looked towards a magical time keeping device 
within the meeting tent.

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text:
Wait, isn't the meeting booked to start in 10 
minutes?

lines.speaker: Reagyn
lines.text:
Correct, but arriving on time is the same thing as
arriving late.

lines.speaker: Reagyn
lines.text: You are on time... surprising, actually.

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text: I'm just trying to avoid a repeat of last time.

lines.speaker: Reagyn
lines.text:
...

Then we are to not expecting anyone for another 
ten minutes, then.

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text:
Seems to be the case. Norde and everyone aren't 
always on time anyways.

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text: So...

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text: How was your day...?

lines.speaker: Reagyn
lines.text:
If you don't mind, I believe I'll use those 10 
minutes to double check the math.

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text: Oh... sure. That's a good thing to trust to you.

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text: Well... back to my nap, I guess?

lines.speaker: Reagyn
lines.text: If we move... calculate that...

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text: ...and we can-

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text: Oh, you're already here.

lines.speaker: Norde
lines.text: As well as Pup, it seems.

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text:
Sort of figured we'd get here first... We're five
minutes early, even.

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text: Heheh~

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text: Hmm...

lines.speaker: Reagyn
lines.text: Don't mind me. I just arrived early to...
Reagyn's gaze turned up to the others.

lines.speaker: Reagyn
lines.text:
...Norde?

What brings you here, I thought it would only be
Charlotte, Pup, and myself today.

lines.speaker: Norde
lines.text: Charlotte insis-

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text: I just wanted Norde to ask some questions on the topic.

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text:
I think those opinions would be... fruitful. Norde 
has a good way of putting these logistical 
questions.

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text:
Feel free to proceed as though it was just the 
three of us that you expected, though.

Charlotte said the words as she stepped 
towards one of the chairs to sit down.

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text:
Also...

Should we do something about... uhh...

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text: ZZzzzz...

lines.speaker: Norde
lines.text: Pup will wake up with the noise.

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text: ZZzzzz...

lines.speaker: Norde
lines.text: Maybe...

lines.speaker: Reagyn
lines.text:
Regardless, this is likely a good time to start the
meeting.

lines.speaker: Reagyn
lines.text:
And so, due to the current rate we found 
ourselves in skirmishes, we will need about 21.7 kg 
of iron and-

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text: *Clears throat*...

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text: If possible, how would that expand to battle strategy?

lines.speaker: Reagyn
lines.text: Hm? What do you mean?

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text:
Like those strategies that get trained into the 
Crows? Done so we can coordinate with each other 
when the fighting starts.

lines.speaker: Reagyn
lines.text:
I imagine that would fall out of the scope of a
logistics meeting...?

lines.speaker: Norde
lines.text: She has a point.

lines.speaker: Norde
lines.text: The logistics are battlefield maneuvers as well.

lines.speaker: Norde
lines.text:
Like these detours... they may invite more battles 
and more strategic considerations.

lines.speaker: Reagyn
lines.text: ...Perhaps.

lines.speaker: Norde
lines.text:
The optimized math you have also assumes 
predictable market conditions.

It is actually rare that small villages work on market
rates. They leverage the situation to 
barter, typically.

lines.speaker: Norde
lines.text:
Generally, smaller adjustments to our process are
better.

lines.speaker: Norde
lines.text: We can always take bigger swings later.

lines.speaker: Reagyn
lines.text: Ah... well...

Charlotte smirked, and she showed on her face 
that she saw it funny how the "all-knowing Reagyn" 
was being cornered by Norde's questioning.

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text:
Like maybe you could reforge the worn equipment? 
Or just reuse it, like using worn swords as lance 
tips.

lines.speaker: Norde
lines.text: Hmm... How much wood do we have?

lines.speaker: Reagyn
lines.text:
Not that much... but if we convert it into lances... I
would need to recalculate...

lines.speaker: Norde
lines.text:
Have you collected info on how much equipment 
we outright lose each battle, too? Like arrows.

lines.speaker: Reagyn
lines.text: Not... yet.

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text: Tsk...
Charlotte felt a bit of a knot in her stomach...

One could call it guilt. However, her pride didn't
allow her to acknowledge that.

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text:
I think they said that we could re-use some 
arrows...

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text:
But it depends on the quality. Some arrowheads 
are just... bad...

Especially if we pick up ones the bandits 
used... sheesh.

lines.speaker: Norde
lines.text: Then what about-

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text:
The smiths have the ability to fix the chipped 
weapons, yes. It would take some time.

Especially if they are smelting the arrowheads 
into ingots to help the process.

lines.speaker: Norde
lines.text:
But what about the wood? You said the arrows 
had minimal scavenge value, so how is our 
inventory?

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text: Ah... I don't know-

lines.speaker: Reagyn
lines.text:
We should have enough that we can create some 
emergency lances using the extra material from 
the arrowheads.

lines.speaker: Norde
lines.text: Then...

The meeting proceeded with the two taking
turns to answer Norde's thorough questioning.

lines.speaker: Norde
lines.text:
I think that should cement our plan and allow us to
move forward.

Well done.

Now, if you'll excuse me.

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text:
*Sigh*... I thought he'd never run out of 
questions.

lines.speaker: Reagyn
lines.text: Indeed. That was very thorough, yet to the point...

lines.speaker: Reagyn
lines.text: But... Norde does not pull any punches, it seems?

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text: Hah... once in a blue moon...

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text: One time, Norde just straight up told me I was fat!

lines.speaker: Reagyn
lines.text: Were you eating extra portions, again?

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text: H- Hey! That was one time.

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text:
It's not often we have delicacies from Lockhart
available...

lines.speaker: Reagyn
lines.text:
Perhaps I am speaking out of line at this time.
Apologies.

lines.speaker: Reagyn
lines.text: Though... I wanted to say... thank you.

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text: Hm? What for?

lines.speaker: Reagyn
lines.text:
The information you had regarding the smithies was
useful.

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text:
Ah, yeah. A bit of a mercantile habit, I suppose.

I tend to ask about that sort of stuff when helping
with the supply runs.

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text:
But your understanding of math, numbers and your
knowledge of our supply is also a commendable skill.

lines.speaker: Reagyn
lines.text:
It is the least I could do. As the younger sibling, I
must be prepared at all times... for both of us.

lines.speaker: Reagyn
lines.text:
Next time, I will be better prepared. That was... I
should have been better prepared.

lines.speaker: Reagyn
lines.text:
Perhaps I can join your discussions with the
blacksmiths?

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text: Well, if the opportunity arises.

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text:
They're not exactly scheduled, so... maybe 
sometime this next week?

lines.speaker: Reagyn
lines.text:
Next time, I will be better prepared. That was... I
should have been better prepared.

lines.speaker: Reagyn
lines.text:
Perfect. I should have some time at
9:15!

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text:
Perhaps we can be a bit more... flexible on the
specific time...

lines.speaker: Reagyn
lines.text:
Hmm... I should be available
between 8:30 and 9:30 tomorrow?

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text: Ah... so early.

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text: But it's a start I guess.

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text:
...?!

10kg of lumber!

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text:
Oh, man...

Zzzzz...

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text: How dare you!

Off in the corner of the mess tent, there sat two
"noble" "ladies"... as one may call them.

lines.speaker: Reagyn
lines.text: *Sigh*... You are making a scene.

One of them was a redhead with a somewhat 
diplomatic and subdued attitude, hands crossed 
across a lap until an opening to speak arose.

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text:
Making a scene!? You are the one that called me a dirty
pig!

While on the other side of the table, there stood a
feisty blonde speaking with gusto aplenty.

Even though her voice was raised, and her 
emotions were rampant, her voice was smooth 
and eloquent.

lines.speaker: Crow
lines.text: They are at it again, aren't they?

lines.speaker: Other Crow
lines.text: Hopefully without a food fight this time...

And on the other side of the tent, stood two 
Crows tasked with preparing the food...
With hopes in their hearts...
...that it would be eaten. Not thrown.
A show. Via both its drama and its audience.

lines.speaker: Crow
lines.text:
We are low on supplies as it is... And its those two
who have been managing the budget lately.

lines.speaker: Other Crow
lines.text:
...Hey, I bet you one gold Miss Charlotte starts it
this time.

lines.speaker: Crow
lines.text: Doesn't she always?

lines.speaker: Reagyn
lines.text: I did not say that!

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text: I heard you. Loud and clear.

lines.speaker: Reagyn
lines.text: I said...!

lines.speaker: Reagyn
lines.text: *Sigh*... forget it.

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text: Then you admit it?

lines.speaker: Reagyn
lines.text: Not in the context you are imagining...

Out on the sidelines, there entered an extra to this
conflict.

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text: Uh... did I miss something?

lines.speaker: Crow
lines.text: The usual.

lines.speaker: Other Crow
lines.text:
Think they'll almost collapse the tent again? Chicken
bones can get some velocity when whipped fast.

lines.speaker: Crow
lines.text: Is the dog around to catch it like last time?

lines.speaker: Crow
lines.text: Man, we had to move quickly.

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text:
While you two are cooking again, too. You're not 
adding something to the sauce, are you?

lines.speaker: Other Crow
lines.text:
By the Goddess, no. I've heard them argue in other
tents at night, too.

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text: That's it...

As she said the words, her hand hovered over the
remaining chicken bone from her meal.

lines.speaker: Other Crow
lines.text: Here comes the money shot...!

lines.speaker: Crow
lines.text: I didn't make the bet.

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text: I am...

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text: ...leaving.
...and she left the mess tent.

lines.speaker: Reagyn
lines.text: *Sigh*...

lines.speaker: Other Crow
lines.text: Tsk.

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text: Hmm... Interesting.

Later that day, a meeting was arranged to 
discuss the mysteriously depleted food supply.

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text:
...and therefore, I suggest approaching this village
due to their abundance of wheat.

Our recently gathered supply of legumes would be 
a good trade for it.

Reagyn was the first one to clap. Norde was 
second. And I... clapped last after realizing the 
meeting was over.

lines.speaker: Reagyn
lines.text:
Well done, Miss Charlotte. Your analytics have
improved. No objections come to mind.

Your oration has improved with your confidence 
too.
Norde's ears twitched.

lines.speaker: Norde
lines.text:
You did well, indeed. Now, if you'd excuse me. I 
must be on my way.

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text: Hm?

As though with a newfound purpose, Norde exited 
the tent quickly.

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text: Haha, yeah. Practice makes perfect, I guess?
Reagyn reacted with a small but warm smile.

lines.speaker: Reagyn
lines.text: Then... any feedback you'd relay back to me?

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text: Uh... You let me finish?

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text:
Which... might be better than barraging me with
questions, like I've done to others at times.

lines.speaker: Reagyn
lines.text: You were going out of your way for that?

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text: Uh... No. Maybe. No... What was the question again?

lines.speaker: Reagyn
lines.text: ...If you had any feedback for me.

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text: I gave the... incorrect answer, then?

lines.speaker: Reagyn
lines.text:
...

What of... outside the meetings? Do you have any
thoughts you'd like to share?

The two started back and forth on unimportant 
details like habits and logistical endeavors.

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text: (Is this...?)

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text: (Well, this is subtle as a brick.)

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text:
Now, you two, don't you think you should be more 
open in this olive branch?

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text: Charlotte, if you'd start.

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text: What's that supposed to mean?

I stared at her for a solid few seconds, then tilted 
my head slightly forward.

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text: (Ah... fresh relationship drama~)

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text: Now now, you two. Is this how "business partners" talk?

I leaned over unconsciously, with my arms on the 
table and hands to my mouth in excitement.

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text: What's that supposed to mean?

My fingers twiddles about as a soft smile rose into a
smirk.

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text: (Ah... this dog and pony show.)

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text:
You two. It's obvious there's a problem here you 
both want to get the horse going on.

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text: Why not just get on with it already?

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text: What's that supposed to mean?

I stared at her for a solid few seconds, then tilted 
my head slightly forward.

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text: F- Fine...!

I led the two to sit across from each other, 
each a red tint to their cheeks.

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text: *Clears throat*

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text: Charlotte starts. Begin.

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text: Reagyn just... is always throwing compliments my way.

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text: How well I do my job... How much I have improved...

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text: It just gives me this... weird tight feeling.

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text: Is it a backhanded compliment? Or... is it... Mmm...!

Charlotte began to do weird signs with her arms 
and hands. As if she was moving boxes from one 
side of the room to another.

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text: Well that's... a reaction.

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text:
Reagyn, this is your time for a rebuttal. You're on 
the clock.

lines.speaker: Reagyn
lines.text: *Sigh*...

lines.speaker: Reagyn
lines.text:
As Charlotte so mentioned, I have observed her 
growth into her role as an administrator and leader.

I only wish to be true and open on my honest 
feedback. That I admire what she has done.

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text: So what is causing the problem?

lines.speaker: Reagyn
lines.text: Charlotte, in turn... is not... doing the same.

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text: Same what?

lines.speaker: Reagyn
lines.text:
Acknowledging my... m- my own growth across our 
time together.

lines.speaker: Reagyn
lines.text:
It's growth of mine that I have her to thank for,
too...

I just was hoping for... a bit of... you know...?

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text: Ah...
I turned my whole body to Charlotte.

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text:
Translation: Reagyn wants you - Charlotte - 
to give compliments.

lines.speaker: Reagyn
lines.text: I- I... Asking such a thing would be uncouth!

Leaning to Reagyn, I paused and then tilted my 
head towards her.

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text: Am I wrong?
