lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text:
But... I've said nice things before... right? I'm
pretty sure I did.

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text:
Maybe it didn't come across like that? Can you give an
example?

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text:
*Clears throat*...

I like... your... analytical skills. It always feels
like...

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text: ...like you always are right on point.

Charlotte's comment made Reagyn fume with 
grateful embarrassment.

lines.speaker: Reagyn
lines.text: I- I am glad that you think of me... as an asset...

lines.speaker: Reagyn
lines.text:
I really appreciate your sense of honesty and
directness!

lines.speaker: Reagyn
lines.text:
...towards finding appropriate trade partners in our
travels.

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text:
I- I mean... is nothing compared to the way you 
speak. Its so eloquent and fancy...

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text:
...whenever you describe your relationship about
getting nobles to help our cause.

lines.speaker: Reagyn
lines.text: Well, I love the way you stand stall and confident...

lines.speaker: Reagyn
lines.text:
...whenever we present the information that we have for
Pup and Norde to assess.

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text:
But it doesn't compare to the way you elegantly sway as
you walk...

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text: ...whenever you are counting our weapon stock.

lines.speaker: Reagyn
lines.text:
It's nothing special. At least compared to how you
bravely act...

lines.speaker: Reagyn
lines.text: ...whenever there is a rowdy complaint.

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text: Aren't you two getting along better?

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text: (Hoho~ Maybe I should get a snack for the show?)

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text:
Happy to see you two getting along better. I knew 
you just needed to talk.

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text:
(Maybe this is a good time for me to get back to 
my business and leave.)

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text: I would love to be your partner...

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text: ...in mercantile affairs.

lines.speaker: Reagyn
lines.text: Excuse me...?

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text:
Or... maybe not mercantile? Logistics? Trading
associate?
Reagyn turned away.

lines.speaker: Reagyn
lines.text:
Are you...

...
...and turned back to Charlotte.

lines.speaker: Reagyn
lines.text: I would... love to be your trading partner.
Outside the tent, as I walked away...

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text: (A rustling sound?)

As I stepped towards my goal, I could hear some
rumbling noises from the tent I just left.

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text: (I... Maybe it's time for me to step away?)

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text:
(Let 'em figure out how bright this particular fire is
for themselves.)

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text:
(No, they wouldn't be fighting again, would they? 
After that?)

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text: (There's no way... right?)

title: SP-Atticus x Tatiana B - New Event

lines.text:
Elliot stood there, hesitating a bit before the tent
flap.

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text:
Excuse me, Castel? I received a message from 
you...

There were panicked sounds on the other side of 
the tent flap.

lines.speaker: Castel
lines.text: H- Hold on... for one moment... please...!

Elliot could hear a sound of shuffling, as though 
items were being hastily arranged.

lines.speaker: Castel
lines.text: And... perfect~

lines.speaker: Castel
lines.text: You may enter now.
Elliot pushed aside the tent flap, only to see...

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text:
...

Forgive me sir, but I don't understand what is
happening here.

There was a table set for two, with the rations of 
the day on them.

lines.speaker: Castel
lines.text:
When we last spoke on the subject, I alluded to 
the possibility of discussing your... heirloom 
situation...
...over dinner.

lines.speaker: Castel
lines.text: Well, this is that opportunity.

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text: I see.

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text: Far be it for me to refuse such a gracious invitation.

lines.speaker: Castel
lines.text: Ah, your heirloom?

Castel looked at Elliot's body. 
The current form of it.

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text: Right. Our arrangement. Apologies.
There was a flash of light.

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text: As agreed.

lines.speaker: Castel
lines.text:
That'll be much more conducive to studying it, 
thank you.
Without additional delay, the two sat at the table.

lines.speaker: Castel
lines.text:
I hope you enjoy the libations. I find it difficult to
think on an empty stomach.

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text: I feel much the same.

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text: Though... the wine?

lines.speaker: Castel
lines.text:
Ah, well... alcohol... s- stimulates the brain. It is
an established scientific fact.

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text: And the candles?

lines.speaker: Castel
lines.text:
Well, how else does one expect to read, if they do 
not have adequate lighting?

Elliot seemed content with the answer. 

He went to take an initial bite of the food... 
only to pause...

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text: What of the rose petals?

lines.speaker: Castel
lines.text:
That is just, eh... an effort of mine to counteract 
the smell of horses and sweat.

lines.speaker: Castel
lines.text: Mercenary camps can be so dirty, can't they?
A statement met by Elliot sniffing the air.

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text:
But... they do not keep the horses on this side of
camp.

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text:
And today is a rest day on the training schedule. 
Not even Pup is about.

lines.speaker: Castel
lines.text: Old habits... die hard...?

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text: I suppose so.
The pair ate and drank in silence for some time.

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text: So, when are we going to do it?
Castel choked on his food.

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text:
And for that matter, how are we even going to do 
it?

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text:
With us being so different and all. 

Our forms, I mean.
Coughing, Castel wiped his mouth.

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text: Are you okay?

lines.speaker: Castel
lines.text:
Fine... I just wasn't expecting such a forward
question.
Castel blushed bright red.

lines.speaker: Castel
lines.text:
Though I suppose I'm fine with skipping formalities 
if you are.

lines.speaker: Castel
lines.text: Fortunately, I've given this much thought.

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text:
Formalities? I was merely speaking of your intent to
discuss my ancestor...?
Castel's eyes went wide.

lines.speaker: Castel
lines.text:
Oh! That! Of course! Yes!

Not "do it", but-

lines.speaker: Castel
lines.text: Well, never mind.

lines.speaker: Castel
lines.text:
We're nearly done with the meal, so we can finish
and...

The two stepped to the research setup Castel had 
within the tent.

lines.speaker: Castel
lines.text:
You see, I have been pondering this matter with 
your ancestor and your unexpected transformation.

lines.speaker: Castel
lines.text:
Everything I have experienced recently, and 
throughout my professional experience, has made 
one thing clear.
The psychology of the individual who uses a 
heirloom is the most significant factor in how that 
heirloom expresses itself.

lines.speaker: Castel
lines.text:
This is doubly true for the case of transformations,
and your situation uniquely involves both.

Castel walked over to a table with a few heirlooms 
laid out on it.

lines.speaker: Castel
lines.text:
Specifically, the area of emotion. Attitudes. 
Feelings. Beliefs.

lines.speaker: Castel
lines.text:
Therefore, I propose we discuss your inner 
thoughts on your transformation in greater detail.

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text: I see... that does make a certain degree of sense.

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text: However, I'm not certain where to begin.

Castel responded with a fidget motion as though 
touch his no longer relevant glasses.

lines.speaker: Castel
lines.text:
Fair enough. Perhaps it would help if I speak about 
my own feelings first?

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text: I imagine that could help to see an example. Thank you.

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text:
Then I suppose to start...

How do you feel about... being a shade? And a 
feminine presenting one at that?

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text:
After all, it seems like you still identify as a man,
so doesn't that cause some friction?

lines.speaker: Castel
lines.text:
Hrm... it does. Or perhaps it would be more 
accurate to say that it should?

lines.speaker: Castel
lines.text:
I recognize most people would reasonably find the
situation somewhat distressing.

lines.speaker: Castel
lines.text:
After all, I didn't ask for this. And given the chance,
I would much rather return to my old body.

lines.speaker: Castel
lines.text:
However, I also view the situation with a sense of
detachment.

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text: As in, you don't view this body as... "your body"?

lines.speaker: Castel
lines.text:
Correct. It is merely a chance for me to study a 
unique situation up close

lines.speaker: Castel
lines.text:
One that has never been seen before, and one 
where one can come away from it with new 
scientific knowledge.

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text:
I appreciate that you shared that. I think it helps 
me work through some of my thoughts.

lines.speaker: Castel
lines.text: Should you be willing to share, I am glad to listen.

lines.speaker: Castel
lines.text: Not that... you must...

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text: I suppose for me, it is the opposite.

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text: I am a man. I've been a man.

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text:
But this form... it has been with me for years now. 
It would be a lie to say it feels removed from me.

Would I trade it to get rid of the shame of it? 
Remove it from my history?

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text: That? That I do not know.

lines.speaker: Castel
lines.text: "Shame"...? Because of the female form, or...?

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text:
Shame of my failure to my family.

This is not the legendary ancestor I was destined 
to cloak myself within. To raise our lineage back to
prominence.
How many more generations until we reach that 
point...?

...

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text:
With that all, I suppose that it is hard to deny that
the female form isn't a reminder of that guilt.

lines.speaker: Castel
lines.text: I see...
The two settled into a considerate silence.

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text:
Do you see a path forward, now? Did what I 
provided help see the next steps?

lines.speaker: Castel
lines.text:
The guilt and shame... could they be derived from
another ancestor?

Somehow strong feelings corrupt the access to the
familial history in the heirloom...?

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text:
But those feelings weren't around until after I
first transformed?

lines.speaker: Castel
lines.text:
True... true... maybe it can act as a starting point,
though?

Hmm...

lines.speaker: Castel
lines.text: You are absolutely sure it is the correct heirloom?

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text: Yes.

lines.speaker: Castel
lines.text:
Then yes, my theories will have to act as a starting
point.

lines.speaker: Castel
lines.text:
Have you ever had thoughts about being a woman 
before?

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text: What?

lines.speaker: Castel
lines.text: Before the first time you took this form.

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text: No.

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text: Or...  *sigh*...

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text: No.

lines.speaker: Castel
lines.text:
Did you have any strong feeling or wants before 
that point?

lines.speaker: Castel
lines.text:
I understand I am speculating from my theory, but 
if it is true then any source of 'deviating' influences 
may be relevant.

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text: I suppose... I wanted to feel more free.

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text:
I was essentially a child at the time, barely on the
precipice of adulthood.

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text:
A life of being raised to be my family's savior... and
a savior via another person's greatness over my 
own...

lines.speaker: Castel
lines.text:
Yes, I imagine such feelings would increase even in
one's later teenage years.

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text:
Indeed, it is not a rebellious phase I am proud of. 
Nor one I can take back.

lines.speaker: Castel
lines.text: But do you feel more "free"?

lines.speaker: Castel
lines.text: In this form, I mean.

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text: I... suppose so?

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text:
I feel more heroic. Confident. As if the rest of the
time, I'm only pretending.

lines.speaker: Castel
lines.text:
That would imply any emotional influence would've still
made this the form of a hero, then?

lines.speaker: Castel
lines.text:
And it is something to work with. I am happy I
stopped by that bookstore recently.

Castel gestured at a pile on his bed
containing a number of books.

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text:
You wish for us to read those? Could two people 
get through that many in one evening?

lines.speaker: Castel
lines.text:
Not if we simply check the appendices for anything
relating to your ancestor.

lines.speaker: Castel
lines.text:
Even then, we only have to skim those sections for
mentions of anything related to the emotions 
you're experiencing.

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text: What would we be looking for?

lines.speaker: Castel
lines.text:
Reasons you could subconsciously associate the 
heroic presence with a feminine form.

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text:
As a potential corruptive influence, like you
mentioned...

lines.speaker: Castel
lines.text:
And if without success, then we've eliminated one
avenue of inquiry.

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text: Indeed. Well, let's get started.

lines.speaker: Castel
lines.text: Hmm...

Castel's eyes scanned across the book's words 
made visible by the campfire's light.

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text:
Have you found anything yet? I've yet to find 
anything myself.

lines.speaker: Castel
lines.text: *Yawn*... I am afraid nothing from me either.

lines.speaker: Castel
lines.text:
And I was so sure this was the right way to 
investigate it...

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text: No, it is fine. As you said, it was worth a try.

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text: It is getting late. I think I should retire soon.

lines.speaker: Castel
lines.text: As should I...

lines.speaker: Castel
lines.text:
Though consider me glad that we were able to 
share this time together.

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text:
Indeed. It is rare to find another willing to delve
into the depths of Covenant myths.

lines.speaker: Castel
lines.text: Y- Yes, t- that's what I meant. Of course~!

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text: Haha, you can be humorously silly at times.

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text:
Thank you, Castel. Despite our lack of concrete
results, I'm glad we talked.

It helped, in at least some ways.

lines.speaker: Castel
lines.text: Truly? Then I am most pleased with the outcome.

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text:
In fact, I think I will continue reading some of these
titles and thinking on my feelings, as you 
suggested.

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text:
Might I ask to return to your forum? You've 
managed to transport an impressive amount of 
literature.

lines.speaker: Castel
lines.text:
Yes! Please do! And come speak with me in it, 
whenever you have the chance!

lines.speaker: Castel
lines.text: Erm, for science, of course.

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text: Yes, for science.

Elliot's relaxed laughter mixed with the hint of
nervousness from Castel's own.

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text: Goodnight, Castel.

lines.speaker: Castel
lines.text: Goodnight.

And so Elliot turned towards the tents while re-
entering his original form, leaving Castel with his
books and campfire.

lines.speaker: Castel
lines.text:
*Sigh*... Too close. 

I feared that I had come on too strongly.

lines.speaker: Castel
lines.text:
I think... I think Elliot didn't catch on to my...
advances...?

lines.speaker: Castel
lines.text:
*Sigh*... I can hope.

I do not wish undue stress on her...

lines.speaker: Castel
lines.text: Not that I don't sincerely wish to assist...
Castel looked at the pile of books ominously.

lines.speaker: Castel
lines.text:
...

We can only take so many when we move next, 
so...

lines.speaker: Castel
lines.text: I suppose one more couldn't hurt...

title: SP-Atticus x Tatiana B - New Event

lines.text:
The old Guardian was making his rounds around 
the busy town as part of the Crows' journey 
across the lands.

lines.speaker: Atticus
lines.text: Let's see...

He peeked down at the list in his hands,
refamiliarizing himself with the goals of his 
mission.

Supplies, and some recon were the order of 
the day.
A good ways behind him was a light footed woman.

lines.speaker: Tatiana
lines.text: This should be a good distance to stay out of sight.

She whispered it to herself as she peeked around a
corner.

The young einlyn continued to whisper to herself 
as she tailed the old guardian.

lines.speaker: Tatiana
lines.text:
Let's see what you're up to, old man, now that the
others' aren't around to keep an eye on you.

As she moved, she blended into crowds and 
jumped between various stalls, objects, and 
walls to keep herself out of line of sight.
All the while...
...keeping an eye on her target.

lines.speaker: Shopkeep
lines.text: Thank ya.

lines.speaker: Atticus
lines.text: No, I must thank you.

As the minutes turned to an hour, Atticus only 
seemed to perform the tasks given to him.

lines.speaker: Tatiana
lines.text:
Really? He's truly just dutifully handling the list of
stuff?

lines.speaker: Tatiana
lines.text:
*Sigh*... Maybe he's just used to following orders.
Like from the nobles he sold out to...

lines.speaker: Tatiana
lines.text: Wait...

It seemed that way... until the einlyn saw him start 
to go off the beaten path of his supposed task list.

She continued to track him, from an offshoot of 
the main market street, to the edges of the 
residential district...

...all the way into the doors of a comfy looking
bakery.

lines.speaker: Tatiana
lines.text: Interesting...

It wasn't long before he emerged back onto the 
street, the last of his free arm space full of 
aromatic freshly baked goods.

From there, still, he headed towards the outskirts 
of the town.

He came to a large cottage on the edge of the 
town's fields.

A number of children ran about, with some noticing 
as he approached the open door.

lines.speaker: Director
lines.text: Is that... you, Atticus?

lines.speaker: Atticus
lines.text: In the flesh.

lines.speaker: Director
lines.text:
In a sense...

I heard you were making a living being as sturdy as
stone but...

He stared on with a nostalgic smile, tinted with a
pang of concern.

Alongside him, more children gathered, looking 
on in awe.

lines.speaker: Atticus
lines.text:
It was a surprise to me, as well, at first. But I make
due.

lines.speaker: Atticus
lines.text: Here, before I forget. For the orphanage.

lines.speaker: Director
lines.text:
So many years later and you still feel the need... 
Your donations will always be welcomed.

Can I invite you in for-
Then like a warhorn, a scream tore through the air.

Eyes turned to see children running in from some of 
the empty fields from around.

lines.speaker: Child
lines.text: H- Help! They took her!

The shrill cry for assistance raised the hairs on the
necks of all those who heard it.

lines.speaker: Atticus
lines.text: Who did? Please tell me anything you can about them.

lines.speaker: Child
lines.text: U- Uh... Like... leather armor stuff... with a patch?

lines.speaker: Director
lines.text:
That sounds... a bit like what you wore before,
Atticus. All those years ago.

lines.speaker: Atticus
lines.text:
Do they still operate in this area?

Hmmm...

lines.speaker: Atticus
lines.text: Everyone. Inside. Now.

He commanded gently. The Director said nothing 
to him, but quickly gathered up the young ones 
inside the orphanage.
And with that, he was off.

lines.speaker: Tatiana
lines.text: No... no no no...

Tatiana stealthily headed off herself, using the 
sparse trees and cottages of the area to stay out 
of sight.

lines.speaker: Atticus
lines.text:
...

Footprints?

lines.speaker: Tatiana
lines.text: ...is that laughin'?

Atticus jumped into a forest clearing, with Tatiana
stealthily setup in the brush.

lines.speaker: Rouge Crusader
lines.text:
GAH! Quit squirming brat! Don't make us shut you 
up. You're worth more uninjured.

lines.speaker: Vile Crusader
lines.text:
Listen to your elders, squirt. Don't wanna become
damaged goods, do ya?

lines.speaker: Quiet Crusader
lines.text: *Sigh*...

On their armor was emblazoned a crest of the 
Covenant. The badge of the crusader emblazoned 
across three chests.

lines.speaker: Atticus
lines.text: You lot! What in the Goddess's name are you doing?!

Atticus lowered his hand to his hilt, and the three
depraved crusaders turned to him.

lines.speaker: Vile Crusader
lines.text:
Back off ol' man. We got this job. We'll deliver the,
uh... young miss.

lines.speaker: Rouge Crusader
lines.text: Wait, ain't that... one of the titled?

lines.speaker: Vile Crusader
lines.text: Really?

lines.speaker: Rouge Crusader
lines.text:
Yeah, the Ashen Fox. Didn't think he'd be so...
actually ash colored, haha.

lines.speaker: Vile Crusader
lines.text:
Tsk. He's half dead. Leave us to our work, old 
timer. We-

lines.speaker: Orphan
lines.text: H- Help...! I'm scar-

The child managed to wiggle their head free, but 
only long enough to get a few words out.

lines.speaker: Atticus
lines.text:
You say you were given orders for... this? You'd make
that claim?

lines.speaker: Rouge Crusader
lines.text: Confidential. Even to your titled'ness.

lines.speaker: Tatiana
lines.text:
Is he... is he actually talking with these kidnappers?
I should of known he couldn't be trusted.

Tatiana said quietly as she skirted around the outer
edge of the clearing.

She grew more and more sick to her stomach with 
each word she heard.

Her eyes threw daggers towards Atticus, but as 
she spun her head...

lines.speaker: Tatiana
lines.text: (Is... his stone arm moving...?)

It was a small semi-circle like pattern, over and 
over again.

lines.speaker: Tatiana
lines.text:
(There's no way. Is that the same as in training 
during camp? A signal?)

He would go over them with the Crows between 
training sessions, when he recounted his lifetime 
of combat wisdom.

lines.speaker: Tatiana
lines.text:
No... that's not for me. It could be for the other
crusaders for some plot.

...

She glanced again to the struggling girl. Air froze in
her throat in that moment.

lines.speaker: Tatiana
lines.text: *Inhale*...  *Exhale*...

lines.speaker: Tatiana
lines.text: Fine, ya old man.

lines.speaker: Atticus
lines.text:
Members of Her Crusade would have no reason to 
hide their deeds or mission.

Do you think she would... look kindly upon this?

lines.speaker: Vile Crusader
lines.text:
I'm sure she'd understand. We are her chosen, 
after all, heh.

He stepped forward, boastfully tapping on the 
crest he wore.

lines.speaker: Rouge Crusader
lines.text:
You questionin' the Goddess's protection? Maybe 
you should head back to the way you came.
The stone man stayed firm.

His eyes shifted from the would be crusaders to 
their captive and further still to the seemingly 
empty path in the forest.

lines.speaker: Atticus
lines.text: *Exhale*...

lines.speaker: Atticus
lines.text: I think it is time... to go.

lines.speaker: Tatiana
lines.text: Aaaahhhh!!! GO!

Tatiana burst forth, assuming it was a call to action,
and left no time for prejudice.

lines.speaker: Vile Crusader
lines.text:
W- What?! Where did-

Argh!

She sprung from behind and trees and downed the 
one of the three crusaders with one swipe of steel.

lines.speaker: Quiet Crusader
lines.text: Gk!  *Gurgle*...

He turned to see why his comrade had yelled,
but...

He was denied a word as Atticus swiftly struck at 
his throat, slitting it in a clean motion.

Two were down, one each by each of 
Tatiana and Atticus.

Atticus turned to the final one, who was holding 
the orphan, and rushed him without hesitation.

lines.speaker: Rouge Crusader
lines.text: Don't you dare!
He turned his blade to the child.

lines.speaker: Rouge Crusader
lines.text:
I'm gonna-

Grhk?!

But before he could even think of acting, an axe 
ripped through his back.

lines.speaker: Tatiana
lines.text: Move, kid!

lines.speaker: Orphan
lines.text: U- Uh huh!

The child jumped to the side, and Tatiana finished 
her follow-through, driving the crusader face first 
into the mud.

lines.speaker: Atticus
lines.text: Here.
Atticus shield the young child, turning away from it.

lines.speaker: Rouge Crusader
lines.text:
*Cough*...  *Sputter*... And...the Goddess... 
saw this... more worthy?

lines.speaker: Tatiana
lines.text: Shut up.

Tatiana raised her boot and stomped down onto 
the handle of her axe to drive it further in.

With a whimper of a final screech, the man went 
limp.

lines.speaker: Tatiana
lines.text: There. Did it.

lines.speaker: Tatiana
lines.text: You alright, kid?
She said, pulling the axe from the corpse's back.

lines.speaker: Orphan
lines.text: *Nods*

She tightly clung to Atticus, and he motioned 
Tatiana to start walking back with them.

lines.speaker: Atticus
lines.text: We've no business left here.

He wiped his blade, sheathing it, and taking the 
girl's hand to keep moving.

Even as he did, he glimpsed back and saw the 
fallen men. He wasn't sure if they were imposter 
crusaders or not.

lines.speaker: Atticus
lines.text: Tatiana. If you could.

The child's hand was moved to Tatiana's grip, and 
she led her away instead.

Atticus stepped back, and deftly sliced the crusader
emblems into nothing more than shredded fabric.

lines.speaker: Tatiana
lines.text: So, they were part of your order thing, yeah?

The three exited the forest, and Tatiana didn't let 
her guard drop despite the event.

The thoughts jumped through her head as she saw 
the connections and parallels form.

lines.speaker: Tatiana
lines.text:
I'm not stupid. I know your background. The 
people you kneel to.

lines.speaker: Atticus
lines.text: ...If they were... they are not any longer.

He leaned down, picking up the orphan and 
carrying her like she was his own daughter.

lines.speaker: Atticus
lines.text: Let's get you home, little miss.

His stride accelerated a gear, and Tatiana soon 
found herself separated from the two.

lines.speaker: Tatiana
lines.text: *Sigh*...

lines.speaker: Director
lines.text: Oh thank the Goddess!

lines.speaker: Orphan
lines.text: *Sniiiiiffffff*...!

The children and orphanage director lovingly 
swarmed the former missing girl with hugs and 
comfort.

lines.speaker: Director
lines.text: And thank you, both of you!

lines.speaker: Tatiana
lines.text: Heh. No problem.

As heart-warming as the sight was to Tatiana, her 
mind lingered with a question for the man at her 
side.

lines.speaker: Tatiana
lines.text: So... how long did you know I was there?

lines.speaker: Atticus
lines.text: Oh, when was it...?

lines.speaker: Atticus
lines.text: Around when we left camp, I believe.

lines.speaker: Tatiana
lines.text: Ack...

lines.speaker: Atticus
lines.text: Well, I didn't know the who.

lines.speaker: Atticus
lines.text: I was only confident in the lack of hostile intent.

lines.speaker: Atticus
lines.text:
Which, I think helping the young girl there is proof
of.

lines.speaker: Tatiana
lines.text:
*Sigh*...

I'm losing my touch, aren't I?

lines.speaker: Atticus
lines.text:
No, I would say your approach was spot on, 
Tatiana. What I noticed were eyes upon me, 
something I'm quite attuned to.

lines.speaker: Atticus
lines.text: It's been... nary a day without such a stare.

lines.speaker: Tatiana
lines.text:
Gah... I was just making sure some former crusader
wasn't plotting something nefarious.

lines.speaker: Atticus
lines.text: A nefarious former crusader?

lines.speaker: Tatiana
lines.text:
Yeah? Whatever would drive someone to kneel to 
that lot...

lines.speaker: Tatiana
lines.text:
And what are you complainin' about! After what just
happened.

lines.speaker: Atticus
lines.text: Haha... A fair thought.

lines.speaker: Atticus
lines.text: So, the results of your investigation?

lines.speaker: Tatiana
lines.text: Crusaders suck fucking ass.

Tatiana stood with a palpable show of 
determination.
A stance that stood defiantly... at least at first.

lines.speaker: Tatiana
lines.text:
Argh... I dunno. Maybe you're... one of the 
good ones.
Each word was slightly quieter than the one before.

lines.speaker: Tatiana
lines.text:
But... that doesn't mean I'm lettin' you outta my
sight!

lines.speaker: Atticus
lines.text: Haha...

A relieved look washed across Atticus's face, 
stone and all.

lines.speaker: Atticus
lines.text:
I thank you, Tatiana. Such is reassuring to hear.

I am not without my own doubts... 
or faults... after all...

lines.speaker: Tatiana
lines.text: *Sigh*... You got that right.

lines.speaker: Atticus
lines.text: I'll do my best to keep you on your toes, yes?

lines.speaker: Tatiana
lines.text: Hey...

Atticus simply chuckled as he stepped away, 
signaling the conclusion to their business here.

The two returned to camp, and they informed the 
town guard along that path.

Each stepped into camp, holding onto items from
the supply list that Atticus left with.
And a story to tell around the next campfire.

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text: Hmm...

As I approached the tent, I could hear a sound I 
didn't recognize.

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text:
...

Hmmmmm...

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text: Hm?

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text: C- Charlotte?

I stepped into the tent, only to find Charlotte in
front of a planning board.

They were boards that we setup to map out 
strategies or organize impending plans.

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text: JonesBakerBellDaviesBrown...

Charlotte was staring intensely at it, mumbling
something.

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text: You... okay...?

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text: TaylorSmithJohnsonEvansHughes

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text: (It's like... she's speaking another language...)
I took a step back towards the tent opening.

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text: If you need anything... just... let me know...
And I left Charlotte to her devices.

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text:
...

ARGGHHH!!!

How do you even do this without any of these 
guys on board?! Stupid oligarchies!

Charlotte threw her hands up, knocking the 
documents on the board off.
And also hitting...

Elliot stumbled back after being hit in the face by
Charlotte's motion.

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text: Oh... I'm sorry!

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text: It's... okay.
Elliot blinked a few times, shaking away the sting.

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text: Is something wrong?

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text: Ah, nothing much.

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text:
...Nothing that isn't of my own making 
at least.

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text: You were saying names before, right?

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text: Some of them sounded familiar. Are they from Lockhart?

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text: Recognize them?

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text:
Yes. Rare for them to come up, but they are 
distinct family names from that region, and I've 
seen them in the work I've helped audit before.

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text: That'd make sense. They're merchants.

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text:
Specifically, ones that hold a grip over specific
industries in Lockhart.

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text: Your talk of "oligarchy" of the city?

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text: ...or was that rude?

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text: Nah, we know the deal.

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text: Speaking of which, I should clean them up here, too...

Charlotte leaned down, picking up the small stack 
of notes that was knocked off the board from 
before.

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text: Here, I can...

And so Elliot followed and grabbed a few of the 
sheets of paper himself.

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text:
...

Is that what you're trying to do here?

Elliot stared at papers and saw the names they 
were just talking about.

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text: Yeah... Sort of not worth keeping a secret here.

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text:
Liberating Lockhart means a new power structure 
needs to be established.

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text:
For lots of reasons, but... in part cause I can't trust
this lot anymore.

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text:
The problem is that they are... invasive.

Every time I look it over, there's something else 
that sort of falls apart if I try to remove even half of
them.

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text: Why?

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text:
Because they're greedy assholes, but that doesn't 
mean they're incompetent.

There's too much you'd have to rebuild from 
scratch without them in each industry. Lockhart 
would fall apart.

Charlotte finished grabbing the papers, and 
stepped over to the board.

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text:
Lockhart requires rebuilding anyways, though. 
Would it not be an excellent chance to 
restructure?

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text:
Yeah... but its hard to imagine the people would 
just embrace a significantly longer rebuilding 
process.

Charlotte pinned a name into the board, 
then another.

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text: Hmm... this does remind me of an old tale.

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text:
Long ago, a small country led a revolution against 
the Emerald Empire, in the Covenant's name.

One famous for restructuring generations of kings 
into a collective rule by the merchants of the land.

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text: Ah...

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text: That was Lockhart, no?

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text: I saw that coming.

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text:
That's some niche knowledge to get your hands 
on.

But it was a different time. Half the world was rising
up against the Emerald Empire and their puppet 
kingdoms of the day.

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text: Hmm...

Elliot was left in thought.

As Charlotte ran out of names to pin, he 
handed the ones he picked up.

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text:
A fantastical time, touched by the light of the
Goddess...

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text:
I appreciate your help as a representative of the
Covenant, but we're not ordained by Her to retake 
the city and rebuild it.

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text: I didn't actually mean to refer to that.

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text:
The revolution I refer to was one created by 
people. Led by leaders of innovation who were 
exploited by the previous regime.
A revolution led by the people. In the name of the
Goddess, yes, but that was just a rallying cry.

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text: The Covenant is not gone, nor is the Goddess.

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text: And moreso, nor are the people of Lockhart.

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text:
It really is a nice story, but I can assure you I've
heard it before.

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text: Hmm...

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text:
Maybe we can talk about the story behind your 
own legend.

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text: You know, that lady you turn into.

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text:
Gray magic pulls from a memory of your ancestor, 
right?
Elliot tensed up.

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text:
Don't worry, there aren't weird rumors going 
about on you or anything.

I just have some common knowledge of
how it works from my education.

Elliot fidgeted with his fingers, trying to decide 
when to breathe next.

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text: I mean...

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text: Oh... sorry, I didn't mean it like that.

Elliot's tenseness alleviated some in the confusion.

Despite Charlotte's confident words,
her meaning was lost to Elliot.

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text:
You don't need to worry. She does herself proud, 
your ancestor.

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text: Very skilled, and very cute.

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text:
Seriously, no need to worry about it. She reps you 
and your family well.
Charlotte passed by Elliot and exited the tent.

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text: ...That's not... what I... was... concerned about...

Elliot struggled to get out the words. Each one 
with a pause.

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text: But...

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text: But I suppose... yes, it is a... good form...

But as he reached the apex of the thought, 
Charlotte was already long gone.

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text: ...Miss Charlotte?

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text: *Pant*... *pant*...

Elliot arrived in Charlotte's location after rushing to
catch up.

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text: Chasing after me, eh?

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text: *Pant*... Yes, but...

Elliot took a deep breath and regained his 
composure.

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text: I think you misunderstood me.

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text:
What's to misunderstand? Legends are inspiring and 
all, but they tend to dance around the details.

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text:
The situation now was not without precedent.

Lockhart was a kingdom that prospered as a 
western hub of the old world.

But it threw away that prosperity and built 
something new.

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text:
What I mean to say...

Why can it not do so again?

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text: But the details are still...

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text:
...also still there.

The Covenant is still there to act as a glue for the
people even in a transition to a new age.

Lockhart itself will not lose the international desire
for its services. It is too vital a port.

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text: The question is...

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text: Do you trust the people to rise to the occasion?

Charlotte was left a bit speechless. Her next words
failed to form despite a few attempts.

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text:
I get what you're saying, but...

It's hard to take that risk on a whim, ya know?

Hmm...

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text:
Maybe if we could test it? I do come from a 
product development background in my family.

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text: Then you could test it, no?

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text: Test what, though?

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text: I do suppose premise 1 of my concept was...

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text:
That the Goddess can be the glue that keeps the 
people together. Elevates them.

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text: Well... Hmmm...

Charlotte's wandering eye drifted, setting on a 
sight.

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text: Hmm... Maybe that?

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text:
...

RRAAAGGHH!!!!!

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text: *Pant*...
I swung my sword as I continued my training.

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text: Let's go go go!

And Charlotte stood there, organizing my training
session.
...for some reason.

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text: How was that one?

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text:
Good.

And after your break...

As we prepped another set, Charlotte's words 
started to repeat a few phrases more often.
Even into the next set itself.

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text:
Is that supposed to impress the Goddess? You got 
to do your best for her!

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text: *Pant*...  *pant*...

As I worked, Charlotte made a short note on a 
piece of paper.

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text: Improved?

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text: Yup. Against the control, at least.

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text:
We'll have to do one against the motivation of food 
at some point.

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text:
That is... surprisingly relevant for a revolutionary
city status.

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text: *Pant*... That one good too?

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text: Yes, and thank you again for letting me tag along.

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text: No problem.

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text: This might be a good place to sto-

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text: Now for the next round!

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text: Huh?!

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text: That was just test #1, my dear darling Pup...

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text:
...and of course, the movement didn't end there in 
that revolution.

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text:
I never realized there was such a cultural shift
underwriting that.
Charlotte and Elliot were walking around the camp.

Lunch had been served, so the two moved 
together towards the line.

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text: Huh...?

They reached that line and it proved to be 
particularly long today.
It extended out the camp's entryway.

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text:
Even the traveling merchants are closer to the 
camp than us...

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text: *Sigh*... It'll be what it is.

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text:
Maybe we can continue our conversation as we 
wait?

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text: I'd like that.

The two had become regular partners in such
revolutionary discussions.

Elliot's intrigue into myth and his Covenant 
education left him well equipped to have them.

And Charlotte's own experiences in government 
created a curious mind on such a topic. One she 
only served to gain from.

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text:
From my understanding, Cartenan was the first to 
rise up against the Emerald Empire.

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text:
I guess it would've been easier when they had that
Oathbreaker to control the weather.

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text:
The story goes that the revolution was led by an
uncorrupted soul.

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text:
Yeah... One of those they say are sent by the 
Goddess to lead humanity in times of strife...

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text: One with no Oath to break, yes.

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text: You think it was just a story?

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text: Well...

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text: Why else would they have kept it a secret?

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text:
Perhaps a better question for Lady Kara. I am not 
one to question the Covenant's teachings.

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text: Ah, I can get that. Given your position.

The line continued on, and the two began to pass 
a merchant group.

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text: Hm?

lines.speaker: Crow
lines.text: Sir, I can't just-

lines.speaker: City Planner
lines.text: You can, and you will!

lines.speaker: Crow
lines.text: S- sir...

lines.speaker: City Planner
lines.text: Well, then I'll just have to-!

The man stepped forward towards the Crow like he 
was about to strike.

lines.speaker: City Planner
lines.text: Argh!

The man fell to the ground as Elliot's nimble moves
took him down, pinning and immobilizing him.

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text: Calm down.

lines.speaker: City Planner
lines.text:
W- What are you doing? Unhand me... w- woman?!

You! You!

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text: I was not asking when I said to calm down.

lines.speaker: City Planner
lines.text: O- Ow ow ow!

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text: We get another scam artist here?

lines.speaker: Crow
lines.text:
Well, no.

He wanted to sell a picture of-

lines.speaker: City Planner
lines.text: YOU!

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text: ...Huh?

With what little flexibility the man had, he was
pointing at Elliot.
Specifically... Elliot in his gray magic form.

lines.speaker: City Planner
lines.text: You! You're the woman from the drawing!
The man furiously unfurled a piece of paper.

lines.speaker: City Planner
lines.text: Here!

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text: Hmm...

What sat before them was a drawing of what 
looked distinctly like Elliot's transformed form.

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text: What is this? And who are you?

lines.speaker: City Planner
lines.text:
I am a MASTER city planner, thank you very much.

And I am in town looking to sell some goods to 
fund...

Well... to fund some city planning.

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text: I'm not in a patient mood.

lines.speaker: City Planner
lines.text:
...?!

Right... so I was part of an investment group to
redevelop an old historic city not far from here.

The problem is that it is overrun with bandits and
scavengers...

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text: And why are you making this our problem?

lines.speaker: City Planner
lines.text:
I- I just wanted to sell some of the relics! The
bandits are too stupid to know their value.

lines.speaker: Crow
lines.text: Ma'am, we don't... buy things like that, right?

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text: Obviously.

lines.speaker: City Planner
lines.text:
I can assure you it is worth money...!

It is actually a famous city from a revolutionary story
many have heard of! It pre-dates the Covenant!

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text: We still aren't buying relics.

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text: ...Was that drawing one of the relics?

lines.speaker: City Planner
lines.text:
Yes, of course. Likely someone who fought in that
revolution.

lines.speaker: Charlotte
lines.text: Well, that is cool. Your ancestor won a revolution.

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text: Hmm...

lines.speaker: City Planner
lines.text:
Won?

No. 

It was a loss.

A... slaughter...

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text:
...

Where is this city?
A Paralogue has been unlocked!

Elliot stood there, hesitating a bit before the tent
flap.

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text:
Excuse me, Castel? I received a message from 
you...

There were panicked sounds on the other side of 
the tent flap.

lines.speaker: Castel
lines.text: H- Hold on... for one moment... please...!

Elliot could hear a sound of shuffling, as though 
items were being hastily arranged.

lines.speaker: Castel
lines.text: And... perfect~

lines.speaker: Castel
lines.text: You may enter now.
Elliot pushed aside the tent flap, only to see...

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text:
...

Forgive me sir, but I don't understand what is
happening here.

There was a table set for two, with the rations of 
the day on them.

lines.speaker: Castel
lines.text:
When we last spoke on the subject, I alluded to 
the possibility of discussing your... heirloom 
situation...
...over dinner.

lines.speaker: Castel
lines.text: Well, this is that opportunity.

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text: I see.

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text: Far be it for me to refuse such a gracious invitation.

lines.speaker: Castel
lines.text: Ah, your heirloom?

Castel looked at Elliot's body. 
The current form of it.

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text: Right. Our arrangement. Apologies.
There was a flash of light.

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text: As agreed.

lines.speaker: Castel
lines.text:
That'll be much more conducive to studying it, 
thank you.
Without additional delay, the two sat at the table.

lines.speaker: Castel
lines.text:
I hope you enjoy the libations. I find it difficult to
think on an empty stomach.

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text: I feel much the same.

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text: Though... the wine?

lines.speaker: Castel
lines.text:
Ah, well... alcohol... s- stimulates the brain. It is
an established scientific fact.

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text: And the candles?

lines.speaker: Castel
lines.text:
Well, how else does one expect to read, if they do 
not have adequate lighting?

Elliot seemed content with the answer. 

He went to take an initial bite of the food... 
only to pause...

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text: What of the rose petals?

lines.speaker: Castel
lines.text:
That is just, eh... an effort of mine to counteract 
the smell of horses and sweat.

lines.speaker: Castel
lines.text: Mercenary camps can be so dirty, can't they?
A statement met by Elliot sniffing the air.

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text:
But... they do not keep the horses on this side of
camp.

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text:
And today is a rest day on the training schedule. 
Not even Pup is about.

lines.speaker: Castel
lines.text: Old habits... die hard...?

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text: I suppose so.
The pair ate and drank in silence for some time.

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text: So, when are we going to do it?
Castel choked on his food.

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text:
And for that matter, how are we even going to do 
it?

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text:
With us being so different and all. 

Our forms, I mean.
Coughing, Castel wiped his mouth.

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text: Are you okay?

lines.speaker: Castel
lines.text:
Fine... I just wasn't expecting such a forward
question.
Castel blushed bright red.

lines.speaker: Castel
lines.text:
Though I suppose I'm fine with skipping formalities 
if you are.

lines.speaker: Castel
lines.text: Fortunately, I've given this much thought.

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text:
Formalities? I was merely speaking of your intent to
discuss my ancestor...?
Castel's eyes went wide.

lines.speaker: Castel
lines.text:
Oh! That! Of course! Yes!

Not "do it", but-

lines.speaker: Castel
lines.text: Well, never mind.

lines.speaker: Castel
lines.text:
We're nearly done with the meal, so we can finish
and...

The two stepped to the research setup Castel had 
within the tent.

lines.speaker: Castel
lines.text:
You see, I have been pondering this matter with 
your ancestor and your unexpected transformation.

lines.speaker: Castel
lines.text:
Everything I have experienced recently, and 
throughout my professional experience, has made 
one thing clear.
The psychology of the individual who uses a 
heirloom is the most significant factor in how that 
heirloom expresses itself.

lines.speaker: Castel
lines.text:
This is doubly true for the case of transformations,
and your situation uniquely involves both.

Castel walked over to a table with a few heirlooms 
laid out on it.

lines.speaker: Castel
lines.text:
Specifically, the area of emotion. Attitudes. 
Feelings. Beliefs.

lines.speaker: Castel
lines.text:
Therefore, I propose we discuss your inner 
thoughts on your transformation in greater detail.

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text: I see... that does make a certain degree of sense.

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text: However, I'm not certain where to begin.

Castel responded with a fidget motion as though 
touch his no longer relevant glasses.

lines.speaker: Castel
lines.text:
Fair enough. Perhaps it would help if I speak about 
my own feelings first?

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text: I imagine that could help to see an example. Thank you.

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text:
Then I suppose to start...

How do you feel about... being a shade? And a 
feminine presenting one at that?

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text:
After all, it seems like you still identify as a man,
so doesn't that cause some friction?

lines.speaker: Castel
lines.text:
Hrm... it does. Or perhaps it would be more 
accurate to say that it should?

lines.speaker: Castel
lines.text:
I recognize most people would reasonably find the
situation somewhat distressing.

lines.speaker: Castel
lines.text:
After all, I didn't ask for this. And given the chance,
I would much rather return to my old body.

lines.speaker: Castel
lines.text:
However, I also view the situation with a sense of
detachment.

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text: As in, you don't view this body as... "your body"?

lines.speaker: Castel
lines.text:
Correct. It is merely a chance for me to study a 
unique situation up close

lines.speaker: Castel
lines.text:
One that has never been seen before, and one 
where one can come away from it with new 
scientific knowledge.

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text:
I appreciate that you shared that. I think it helps 
me work through some of my thoughts.

lines.speaker: Castel
lines.text: Should you be willing to share, I am glad to listen.

lines.speaker: Castel
lines.text: Not that... you must...

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text: I suppose for me, it is the opposite.

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text: I am a man. I've been a man.

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text:
But this form... it has been with me for years now. 
It would be a lie to say it feels removed from me.

Would I trade it to get rid of the shame of it? 
Remove it from my history?

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text: That? That I do not know.

lines.speaker: Castel
lines.text: "Shame"...? Because of the female form, or...?

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text:
Shame of my failure to my family.

This is not the legendary ancestor I was destined 
to cloak myself within. To raise our lineage back to
prominence.
How many more generations until we reach that 
point...?

...

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text:
With that all, I suppose that it is hard to deny that
the female form isn't a reminder of that guilt.

lines.speaker: Castel
lines.text: I see...
The two settled into a considerate silence.

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text:
Do you see a path forward, now? Did what I 
provided help see the next steps?

lines.speaker: Castel
lines.text:
The guilt and shame... could they be derived from
another ancestor?

Somehow strong feelings corrupt the access to the
familial history in the heirloom...?

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text:
But those feelings weren't around until after I
first transformed?

lines.speaker: Castel
lines.text:
True... true... maybe it can act as a starting point,
though?

Hmm...

lines.speaker: Castel
lines.text: You are absolutely sure it is the correct heirloom?

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text: Yes.

lines.speaker: Castel
lines.text:
Then yes, my theories will have to act as a starting
point.

lines.speaker: Castel
lines.text:
Have you ever had thoughts about being a woman 
before?

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text: What?

lines.speaker: Castel
lines.text: Before the first time you took this form.

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text: No.

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text: Or...  *sigh*...

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text: No.

lines.speaker: Castel
lines.text:
Did you have any strong feeling or wants before 
that point?

lines.speaker: Castel
lines.text:
I understand I am speculating from my theory, but 
if it is true then any source of 'deviating' influences 
may be relevant.

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text: I suppose... I wanted to feel more free.

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text:
I was essentially a child at the time, barely on the
precipice of adulthood.

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text:
A life of being raised to be my family's savior... and
a savior via another person's greatness over my 
own...

lines.speaker: Castel
lines.text:
Yes, I imagine such feelings would increase even in
one's later teenage years.

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text:
Indeed, it is not a rebellious phase I am proud of. 
Nor one I can take back.

lines.speaker: Castel
lines.text: But do you feel more "free"?

lines.speaker: Castel
lines.text: In this form, I mean.

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text: I... suppose so?

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text:
I feel more heroic. Confident. As if the rest of the
time, I'm only pretending.

lines.speaker: Castel
lines.text:
That would imply any emotional influence would've still
made this the form of a hero, then?

lines.speaker: Castel
lines.text:
And it is something to work with. I am happy I
stopped by that bookstore recently.

Castel gestured at a pile on his bed
containing a number of books.

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text:
You wish for us to read those? Could two people 
get through that many in one evening?

lines.speaker: Castel
lines.text:
Not if we simply check the appendices for anything
relating to your ancestor.

lines.speaker: Castel
lines.text:
Even then, we only have to skim those sections for
mentions of anything related to the emotions 
you're experiencing.

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text: What would we be looking for?

lines.speaker: Castel
lines.text:
Reasons you could subconsciously associate the 
heroic presence with a feminine form.

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text:
As a potential corruptive influence, like you
mentioned...

lines.speaker: Castel
lines.text:
And if without success, then we've eliminated one
avenue of inquiry.

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text: Indeed. Well, let's get started.

lines.speaker: Castel
lines.text: Hmm...

Castel's eyes scanned across the book's words 
made visible by the campfire's light.

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text:
Have you found anything yet? I've yet to find 
anything myself.

lines.speaker: Castel
lines.text: *Yawn*... I am afraid nothing from me either.

lines.speaker: Castel
lines.text:
And I was so sure this was the right way to 
investigate it...

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text: No, it is fine. As you said, it was worth a try.

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text: It is getting late. I think I should retire soon.

lines.speaker: Castel
lines.text: As should I...

lines.speaker: Castel
lines.text:
Though consider me glad that we were able to 
share this time together.

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text:
Indeed. It is rare to find another willing to delve
into the depths of Covenant myths.

lines.speaker: Castel
lines.text: Y- Yes, t- that's what I meant. Of course~!

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text: Haha, you can be humorously silly at times.

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text:
Thank you, Castel. Despite our lack of concrete
results, I'm glad we talked.

It helped, in at least some ways.

lines.speaker: Castel
lines.text: Truly? Then I am most pleased with the outcome.

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text:
In fact, I think I will continue reading some of these
titles and thinking on my feelings, as you 
suggested.

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text:
Might I ask to return to your forum? You've 
managed to transport an impressive amount of 
literature.

lines.speaker: Castel
lines.text:
Yes! Please do! And come speak with me in it, 
whenever you have the chance!

lines.speaker: Castel
lines.text: Erm, for science, of course.

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text: Yes, for science.

Elliot's relaxed laughter mixed with the hint of
nervousness from Castel's own.

lines.speaker: Elliot
lines.text: Goodnight, Castel.

lines.speaker: Castel
lines.text: Goodnight.

And so Elliot turned towards the tents while re-
entering his original form, leaving Castel with his
books and campfire.

lines.speaker: Castel
lines.text:
*Sigh*... Too close. 

I feared that I had come on too strongly.

lines.speaker: Castel
lines.text:
I think... I think Elliot didn't catch on to my...
advances...?

lines.speaker: Castel
lines.text:
*Sigh*... I can hope.

I do not wish undue stress on her...

lines.speaker: Castel
lines.text: Not that I don't sincerely wish to assist...
Castel looked at the pile of books ominously.

lines.speaker: Castel
lines.text:
...

We can only take so many when we move next, 
so...

lines.speaker: Castel
lines.text: I suppose one more couldn't hurt...

Flynn found Rowan leaning against a supply wagon.

It was brought up from the village, and 
Rowan was idly tuning his lute.

In a short time, they would be loading it. So, the
laborers were gathering with Rowan and Flynn 
a part of their numbers.

lines.speaker: Flynn
lines.text: Rowan. Can I talk to you for a second?

Despite the chaos of the surrounding camp, Rowan 
seemed entirely in his own world.

He plucked soft notes that somehow rose above 
the din of barking orders and clanging steel.

lines.speaker: Rowan
lines.text:
Flynn! Of course, my friend.

I was just practicing a new tune to soothe your 
weary soul.

lines.speaker: Flynn
lines.text:
That's... actually what I wanted to talk about.

Could you... if it wouldn't be too much to ask... 
stop playing music for me?

lines.speaker: Rowan
lines.text: Stop?
Rowan tilted his head, his fingers halting mid-strum.

lines.speaker: Rowan
lines.text: Might I ask why?

lines.speaker: Flynn
lines.text: I know you're trying to help me...

lines.speaker: Flynn
lines.text: And I really do appreciate the effort.

lines.speaker: Flynn
lines.text:
But... it's a little, err... embarrassing to have
you... s- serenading me whenever we hang out.

Rowan lowered his lute, his expression falling as he
gave Flynn an acknowledging nod.

lines.speaker: Rowan
lines.text:
My deepest apologies, Flynn. I never meant to 
offend.

lines.speaker: Flynn
lines.text:
H- Hey, I wouldn't go as far as to say you offended 
me!

lines.speaker: Flynn
lines.text:
It's just... Well, I'm not sure how to explain it in
words.

Excessive maybe?

lines.speaker: Rowan
lines.text:
I might have gotten caught up in the drama of 
playing musician to your troubles.

lines.speaker: Rowan
lines.text:
Mayhap... like minstrels do for the kings and queens 
at court?

lines.speaker: Rowan
lines.text: Indeed, I simply have-

lines.speaker: Rowan
lines.text:
Ah, no... I get ahead of myself again.

If my melodies are unwelcome, then I shall withhold
them.

lines.speaker: Flynn
lines.text: R- Rowan, I... didn't...
A bit flustered, Flynn took a seat on a nearby sack.

lines.speaker: Flynn
lines.text:
I...

Mmm...

Starting and stopping a few times, Flynn tried to 
find the words to console a friend.
But Flynn got there, and calmly started again.

lines.speaker: Flynn
lines.text:
Rowan... you've been to a lot of places in your
travels, right?

Is it common to have minstrels on hand to... 
"soothe the souls of troubled rulers"?

lines.speaker: Rowan
lines.text: Hm? Oh certainly.

lines.speaker: Rowan
lines.text:
More often than not when you visit a court, you'll 
see their bard playing to all after the day concludes.

lines.speaker: Flynn
lines.text:
My family had a few, even as a smaller noble family.

I'm not sure I'd say their performances were "soul
soothing", though.

lines.speaker: Flynn
lines.text:
In fact, I'd say my father rather liked to be a little
riled up most of the time.

He said it kept him sharp and alert, and the bards
played music to match.

lines.speaker: Rowan
lines.text: Haha... mayhap he be a soul to reflect your sister's?

lines.speaker: Flynn
lines.text: Oh, certainly. Mother, too.

As the words left Flynn's mouth, a foreman from 
the town arrived.

With their contact at hand, the assigned Crows 
gathered around the wagon, ready to reload it.

Rowan and Flynn stepped into the gathering of 
workers, now distracted from their conversation 
by the job and their idling thoughts.
It was several minutes before Flynn spoke up again.

lines.speaker: Flynn
lines.text: You know... looking back...

lines.speaker: Flynn
lines.text: Mmmmrgh...!

Flynn breathed out, the huff of exertion winding 
the sentence's words.

lines.speaker: Flynn
lines.text:
Looking back, I knew a lot of people who might 
have benefitted from a minstrel or two to soothe 
their soul.

lines.speaker: Flynn
lines.text: Not that they'd have ever admitted it...

lines.speaker: Flynn
lines.text:
I think they liked the stress. Liked knowing that
success rested on their shoulders.

lines.speaker: Rowan
lines.text: But not fair Flynn, it seems?
Rowan grunted, dropping a box in the wagon.

lines.speaker: Flynn
lines.text: But maybe the good bard Rowan, yes?

lines.speaker: Flynn
lines.text:
I don't think I've seen you just... listening to music. 
At least any that you weren't responsible for.

lines.speaker: Rowan
lines.text: Heh. Guilty as charged~

lines.speaker: Rowan
lines.text: But not for lack of want.

lines.speaker: Rowan
lines.text:
I'm afraid if I weren't making music, these crows 
would live up to their dour namesake.

lines.speaker: Flynn
lines.text: So who soothes the soul of the poet then?

lines.speaker: Rowan
lines.text: Does my soul need soothing?

Their banter was interrupted by a particular female
mercenary dumping a box of supplies into the 
wagon.

lines.speaker: Rowan
lines.text: Ah...

Rowan hopped back in surprise, expecting to once 
again be on the receiving end of her icy glare...

...but to his surprise she did no such thing, and her
icy demeanor was entirely absent as she left for 
other duties.

lines.speaker: Rowan
lines.text:
I can hardly believe my eyes. She ignored me, not a
single death glare.

She must not have recognized me.

lines.speaker: Flynn
lines.text: Rowan, you're the most obvious man in camp.

Between loads, Rowan kept turning to look back 
at where the mercenary had disappeared to...
fruitlessly trying to puzzle out the change.

lines.speaker: Flynn
lines.text: Haha...

With the wagon reloaded, Rowan and Flynn began 
to make their way towards the camp for the 
mid day meal.
The two were on the path, when...
Abruptly, Rowan grabbed Flynn's hand.

lines.speaker: Rowan
lines.text: Over here!

lines.speaker: Flynn
lines.text: W- What's happening?

lines.speaker: Rowan
lines.text:
You know how they say a picture is worth a 
thousand words?

lines.speaker: Flynn
lines.text: Sure.

lines.speaker: Rowan
lines.text: What if I told you that the picture is worthless...

lines.speaker: Rowan
lines.text: ...if you do not stop to appreciate it?
Rowan gestured grandly, and Flynn looked.

Below them was a town nestled in the valley, 
framed by softly falling snow.

lines.speaker: Flynn
lines.text: What am I supposed to be looking at? The village?

lines.speaker: Rowan
lines.text: Just outside of it. You see there in the trees?

Rowan closed the gap between the two, and he 
used his arm to guide Flynn's eyeline to the scene.

lines.speaker: Flynn
lines.text: Yeah, I see...

lines.speaker: Rowan
lines.text:
An elderly couple, they're dancing together. Just 
the two of them.

lines.speaker: Flynn
lines.text: ...Cute.

As Flynn let the moment soak in, Rowan pulled out 
his loot.

lines.speaker: Rowan
lines.text: Absolutely wonderful~

Making some tentative strokes, Rowan's voice 
choked with emotion.

lines.speaker: Rowan
lines.text:
This is everything Flynn, why I make music, why we
fight each day.

lines.speaker: Rowan
lines.text: Not for revenge, not for survival...

lines.speaker: Rowan
lines.text:
But because our lives in this realm are as beautiful 
of the sun itself.

It is worth it to appreciate it.

The lute played deliberately in his hands, moved by 
the inspiration of the moment to create a melody 
caught in the wind.

Glints of tears amongst the light sculpted the 
emotion that Rowan gave with each note.

lines.speaker: Rowan
lines.text:
And such is true... even if you have to steal the 
moments, or fight for the chance to cherish it 
one more time...

The two stood side by side appreciating the scene 
as the bard composed.
The busy camp forgotten behind them.

It was calming tune, but one where each note felt 
like a beat of a story.

At least, it felt that way to Flynn as Rowan reached
the final note.

lines.speaker: Flynn
lines.text: Thank you.

So the two sat back, and let the moment soak in 
for the time.

lines.speaker: Flynn
lines.text:
Maybe we can make a deal, Rowan...

You help me to "steal" these worthwhile moments 
back periodically...

To help me see them, much like you've managed 
to...

Do that, and I'll let you play all the songs for me
that you want.

lines.speaker: Rowan
lines.text: Very well, if our lord does insist.

lines.speaker: Rowan
lines.text:
Haha... I think I'd very much enjoy such an
arrangement.
Rowan strummed away on the lute once more.
And Flynn listened along.

At least, until someone from camp realized
they were missing, and dragged them back 
by their ears.

title: SP-Pup x Mariel A - New Event

lines.text:
Footsteps blistered through the blades along the
ground.

Each blade of grass crinkled under the feet of the
passionate stride.

And as the steps rose to their horizon, so did their
view of the setting sun.

lines.speaker: Mariel
lines.text: And... here... it... is!

Mariel jumped with joy as she reached the peak of 
the local mountain.

lines.speaker: Mariel
lines.text: *Inhale*...  *Exhale*...

The crisp air was a relief as she took in the sight of
the sunset before her.

lines.speaker: Mariel
lines.text:
Yeah... This'd work well.

Sis and Pup would love this place for a date.

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text: For a... what?

Mariel jumped back a little, startled by my own
arrival.

lines.speaker: Mariel
lines.text: H- Hello...

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text: Hm?
I turned to the sunset myself.

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text: Wow... That's a sight.

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text:
I didn't expect to see that here of all places. We
picked a good place to camp this time.

lines.speaker: Mariel
lines.text:
I know, right? It's so pretty.

The sort of place where memories are made~

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text: Yeah...
I looked between Mariel and the sunset.
I did indeed feel a memory forming.

lines.speaker: Mariel
lines.text:
We're not gonna be camping here forever, so... no 
time to waste.

lines.speaker: Mariel
lines.text: First things first.

lines.speaker: Mariel
lines.text: How'd it go...!?

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text: How did... what go?

lines.speaker: Mariel
lines.text: You know? With Sis?

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text:
(With Charlotte? I guess there was that inventory 
thing a while back.)

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text: (Or the training thing...)

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text: (Or the...!)

So many memories passed through my mind over 
the course of our journey.

Memories of... lots of meetings... and lots of 
requests and questions we never actually 
followed up on.

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text: (So... much... unfinished... business...!)

lines.speaker: Mariel
lines.text: T- That bad...?

As I short circuited from a lifetime of small regrets
packed into one convenient journey...

...Mariel turned to the side, away from 
my prying ears.

lines.speaker: Mariel
lines.text:
So the confession really went that poorly...?

I guess it is Sis... and... Pup... 
Awkwardness was a given...

But what to do now?

lines.speaker: Mariel
lines.text:
Well, awkward doesn't mean she said no? How 
could either of them say no this far in...?!
Mariel spun back towards me.

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text:
I never... ordered... that new... training sword
set...!

lines.speaker: Mariel
lines.text: Pup!

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text: Huh?!
I jumped a little as I snapped out of it.

lines.speaker: Mariel
lines.text: I understand it went poorly.

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text: (Even Mariel realizes it!)

lines.speaker: Mariel
lines.text:
But... this could be the perfect excuse to practice 
for the real deal!

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text: Huh...?

lines.speaker: Mariel
lines.text: We can go on test runs of the local spots.

lines.speaker: Mariel
lines.text:
See the sights, try the food. Make a day of it, 
even.

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text:
...

O- Okay...

lines.speaker: Mariel
lines.text: Perfect~ I'll let you know when we can start.

Mariel grabbed my hand, patting it gently in a
reassuring manner.

With that and a smile, it wasn't long before she 
began her descent down back to camp.

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text: (Did... she just... ask me out...?)
Soon after...

...a day came where Mariel pulled me from my bed,
lights dancing about in my morning ridden vision.

lines.speaker: Mariel
lines.text:
*Clears throat*...

Welcome, my young student Pup...

lines.speaker: Mariel
lines.text: ...to a fun day... of learning!

I blinked a few times as the sunlight peaked 
through the alleyways of the town.

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text: (The town...?)
For the crack of dawn, the town was oddly busy.

People moved about and between each other like 
the market was at its height of activity.

lines.speaker: Mariel
lines.text:
Apparently, there is a festival in this town for the
next few weeks.

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text: Ah... okay.

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text: (So they're setting up? At least for the day.)

lines.speaker: Mariel
lines.text: Come on, time for some research~)
Mariel grabbed my hand...

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text: ...Sure...
...and pulled me along.

We walked through the market and talked to the 
locals.

Many of the stalls weren't open, but the locals 
were kind and inviting.

We assisted their setup on a few occasions, and in
return one kind stall owner offered us the first 
taste of the day.

lines.speaker: Mariel
lines.text: Tasty~

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text:
Yeah. It has that... fresh 'crisp' to it, while still
being soft.
I took another bite of the pretiola.

The heat of it was warm to the touch, and a steam 
rose from it in the cool morning air.

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text: Mm~

lines.speaker: Mariel
lines.text: Your face...
Mariel giggled softly with me still distracted.

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text: You know...

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text: ...is this what you had in mind? Is this really a dat-

lines.speaker: Mariel
lines.text: Here.
Her hand reached up to mine...

lines.speaker: Mariel
lines.text: There we go. You had some on your face.

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text:
T- Thanks...

...

lines.speaker: Mariel
lines.text: Oh sorry, did I interrupt you?

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text: Did you?

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text:
I don't know, slipped the mind somehow, 
haha...ha...

lines.speaker: Mariel
lines.text: *Giggles*

We traversed the area more and more 
as the day went on.

Before long, the sun held high up in the sky and 
tilted again before long.

So, before the sun started to set, Mariel pulled us
towards a restaurant.

lines.speaker: Mariel
lines.text:
Kara said this one was famous in the region. The 
sort you hear about in rumors and wives tales.

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text: T- That sounds good?

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text:
...

(What are the options on this menu... What's a...
"haggis"...?)

lines.speaker: Mariel
lines.text:
...and apparently that's when a hero returned,
returning home before passing away.

The Covenant stories say the tree over there grew 
from his grave...

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text: ("Colcannon"? Is that even a real thing?)

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text:
(Wait, is Mariel talking about a story about a
hero...?)
I peeked over my menu.

lines.speaker: Mariel
lines.text:
According to the store owner, they say the old 
hero watches over us as the tree even to this day.

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text:
I think I remember that story from when I was a 
kid. One where-

lines.speaker: Waitress
lines.text: You two ready to order?

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text: Gah...!

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text: I'll just... have a...
My eyes darted across the menu page.

lines.speaker: Mariel
lines.text: We'll have a slab of corned beef.

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text: (There was beef hidden on this page somewhere...?!)

lines.speaker: Mariel
lines.text:
I figure you want something more straightforward, 
yes?

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text: My hero~

Mariel just giggled a little at my words, and the
waitress scribbled down the order.

lines.speaker: Waitress
lines.text: We'll have it right out.

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text: This... is...

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text: ...great!

lines.speaker: Mariel
lines.text: The texturing is wonderful. I didn't expect it.

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text: It's so tender.

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text:
I'll have to thank Kara myself for the 
recommendation when we get back.
Satisfied, we two ate our fill and chatted away.

lines.speaker: Mariel
lines.text: Also, I had no idea you knew so much about old myths.

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text:
We used to be told them as bedtime stories when 
we were kids.

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text:
From what Rowan said, I think we were told the 
versions from the Emerald Empire...?

Ones from before the modern Covenant versions, 
at least.

lines.speaker: Mariel
lines.text:
I had no idea those stories were prevalent back 
then.

That one you mentioned before sounded like an
early version of the one I mentioned earlier.
I looked over the tree that Mariel mentioned prior.

As I did, I put another piece of meat into my 
mouth and started chewing.

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text:
The tale of 'Arbova'.

A sentient tree... said to stand up and fight 
alongside the village in times of turmoil.

lines.speaker: Mariel
lines.text:
It's so different than what they taught us at 
school. I wonder how the story diverted.

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text:
I wonder if that tree really is it? Or maybe the store
owner just likes it for marketing.

lines.speaker: Mariel
lines.text:
I'm mostly happy there's no 'turmoil' to test that
theory.

lines.speaker: Mariel
lines.text:
For all the strife we've seen, this village has avoided
being a part of it.

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text: Yeah... that is nice to see.

And so both of us leaned back, relaxing in our
chairs...
...taking in...
...peace.

lines.speaker: Mariel
lines.text: The sun is going to set soon, I think.

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text: Time to head back?

lines.speaker: Mariel
lines.text: One more item to check off the list.
It was not long...
And steps came again.

Ones that, as they strode along the grassy wild, so 
did their view of the setting sun.

lines.speaker: Mariel
lines.text: *Inhale*...  *Exhale*...

The crisp air was a relief as she took in the sight of
the sunset before her.

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text: This place again, then? With this sunset...

I said it quietly, as the chill of the night started to
settle on my skin.
And I could simply... smile.

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text: It's... pretty.

Stepping over to one of the rocks, I sat down and
Mariel followed me.

lines.speaker: Mariel
lines.text: It is.
So we sat there.
And enjoyed the moment.

lines.speaker: Mariel
lines.text:
I'm happy this went well today. I'm sure it'll be 
great research for you.

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text: ...research?

lines.speaker: Mariel
lines.text:
Mhm. You and Charlotte will have a lovely date, I'm
sure.

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text:
...

What?

lines.speaker: Mariel
lines.text: I sort of wish I could see the date for myself.

lines.speaker: Mariel
lines.text:
But...  *giggle*... I'll just have to ask Sis about it
afterwards.
I wasn't even sure what to say.

I had been pulled along so much this day that I 
hadn't had a real chance to think through what 
was happening.
Just... what my instinct told me.
What I was sort of hoping was really happening.

lines.speaker: Mariel
lines.text: Maybe we should start heading back?

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text:
...

I figured you already saw it.

lines.speaker: Mariel
lines.text: Saw what?

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text: The...

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text: The... date...

lines.speaker: Mariel
lines.text: That's... a funny joke?

lines.speaker: Mariel
lines.text: Haha... Ha...

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text: I had fun.

lines.speaker: Mariel
lines.text: You don't need to joke around with me, you know?
I wasn't sure if I regretted saying it.
It was too much to process.

As I squirmed internally, Mariel fidgeted next to 
me with her fingers.

lines.speaker: Mariel
lines.text:
You shouldn't joke around...

...when...

lines.speaker: Mariel
lines.text:
...when people might take you seriously...

...and get their hopes up.

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text:
...do I look like I'd be funny enough to tell a joke at
a time like this?

lines.speaker: Mariel
lines.text:
*Giggle*... Maybe... 

...with that funny face of yours.

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text: How would you know...

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text: ...with that cute face of yours?

lines.speaker: Mariel
lines.text: *Giggle*

lines.speaker: Mariel
lines.text: I guess that's one thing we have in common.
Mariel's head lowered to rest on my shoulder.
And my head rested atop of her own.
Slowly...
...our hands intertwined.
And we watched the sun set.

title: SP - Pup x Norde A - New Event

lines.speaker: Norde
lines.text: *Pant*... *pant*...

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text: *Pant*... *pant*...

lines.speaker: Crow
lines.text: Heh.

lines.speaker: Other Crow
lines.text: Backed into a corner, eh?

lines.speaker: Crow
lines.text: More like backed into a back.

lines.speaker: Pup
lines.text: (They're not wrong...)
I peeked behind me to see Norde there.

We had, in fact, both retreated and found
